2.1 The specific objectives of the TC are: (I) To analyze the composition, functioning, and performance of the implementation models used in health infrastructure projects; (II) To identify best practices, common challenges, and critical factors affecting the efficiency and effectiveness of the hospital infrastructure implementation models; and (III) To assess the link between implementation performance and the achievement of health governance and service delivery outcomes, particularly in the development of health integrated networks. 2.2 The portfolio of Health, Nutrition and Population (HNP) projects that finance infrastructure has been increasing in the several years. Fifty-six percent of health projects now include hospital infrastructure. Best practices and lessons from implementation experience of hospital infrastructure and integrated health networks have not been systematized at portfolio level. 2.3 Almost all projects with hospital infrastructure experience delays during implementation.

There are different implementation models for the hospital infrastructure. An analysis of the functioning of the different models used by HNP's projects will draw lessons to improve project design, supervision, and execution of infrastructure works. The analysis of the implementation mechanisms of infrastructure projects will focus on the composition and functioning of the three most common implementation models: (i) self-contained executing agencies; (ii) executing agencies that depend on other units (either internal or external) for the execution of activities; and (iii) external management entities. Delays of infrastructure works and good practices to avoid delays have not been systematized. 2.4 Projects that finance or have financed health networks have encountered challenges in achieving outcome indicators and in achieving targets related to health governance, which are critical for the establishment and strengthening of health networks.

While these projects have developed tools to support executing agencies in the analysis of health networks, there has not been a systematization of the tools used and important gaps remain in understanding the effectiveness of the interventions, limitations, and challenges associated with how the networks are functioning. Strategic alignment. This TC is aligned with the objectives of IDB Group's Institutional Strategy: Transformation for Greater Scale and Impact (CA-631) by: (i) reducing poverty and inequality by supporting the capacity to learn from operational experiences to improve project execution and project preparation.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: 2.1 The general objective of this Technical Cooperation (TC) is to enhance agricultural productivity and innovation, strengthen climate change resilience, and promote food security by supporting the governments of the Latin America and Caribbean (LAC) region through the following specific objectives: (i) improving the efficiency and effectiveness of agricultural policies and identifying innovative opportunities to mitigate the environmental impact of agricultural practices; (ii) implementing and monitoring - 2 - agricultural policies and programs; and (iii) designing policies that recognize and quantify the value of ecosystem services within agricultural systems. 2.2 The beneficiaries of the TC are the Ministries of Agriculture and the Agricultural Innovation Institutes, as well as the private actors of the agricultural sector of the countries included in the TC.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: 2.3 Latin America and the Caribbean (LAC) stands at a critical juncture where agricultural development and environmental sustainability must be addressed in an integrated manner. Agriculture remains a vital economic driver in the region, contributing nearly 7% of total GDP, above the global average. The region is home to several of the world's most biodiverse ecosystems, including the Amazon forest, the Meso-American and Andean hotspots, and the Atlantic Forest. However, the expansion of agricultural production has increasingly come at the cost of environmental degradation. Land-use change, nutrient runoff, greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, and biodiversity loss are all accelerating, undermining the ecological resilience of agricultural systems. The Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use (AFOLU) sector accounts for 43% of the region's total GHG emissions.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: Between 1990 and 2020, forest cover in LAC declined from 53% to 46%, and South America registered the world's second-highest rate of net forest loss between 2010 and 2020. Soil degradation is another serious concern, with nearly 50% of arable land in Central America and the Caribbean and 18% in South America facing high degradation severity, translating into economic losses estimated at 3% to 7% of agricultural GDP. 2.4 These challenges are compounded by structural constraints in the agricultural sector. Climate change, manifesting through droughts, flooding, and extreme weather events, continues to threaten yields and increase production volatility. At the same time, family farmers often face limited access to financing, technology, and markets, which inhibits their ability to adapt and compete. High production costs, driven by fertilizer and fuel prices, restrict profitability.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: Compounding these issues is persistent food insecurity: as of 2023, 28.2% of the region's population, roughly 187.6 million people, faced moderate or severe food insecurity, with 6.2% experiencing hunger. 2.5 In response to these multidimensional challenges, governments in LAC must adopt agricultural policies that not only drive productivity but also safeguard natural resources and strengthen climate resilience. A comprehensive strategy is required, one that addresses both the supply and demand sides of the food system, while tackling financial, technological, and institutional barriers. The Inter-American Development Bank (IDB) is well positioned to support its member countries in this transition, due to its extensive experience with the design and implementation of evidence-based policies and investment in sustainable agricultural practices. 2.6 Central to this effort is the use of agro-environmental indicators to inform policy decisions.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: These indicators provide policymakers with a comprehensive view of environmental risks and progress in the sector. They enable monitoring of critical variables-such as GHG and ammonia emissions, nutrient balances, and biodiversity impacts-and help identify problem areas that require corrective action. Moreover, they support LAC countries in aligning their agricultural strategies with international sustainability commitments, and in adopting a regional approach to climate and environmental governance. This evidence-based framework empowers governments to design balanced policies that protect the environment, promote long-term - 3 - sustainability, and ensure the resilience and competitiveness of the region's agriculture. 2.7 At the same time, conducting Producer Support Estimate (PSE) policy analysis is essential to enhance transparency, efficiency, and accountability in the allocation of public resources to agriculture.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: As part of the IDB's Agrimonitor initiative, the PSE methodology provides a harmonized and internationally recognized framework to quantify the level and structure of support provided to agricultural producers. This analysis allows governments to identify whether public spending is effectively promoting productivity, sustainability, and inclusion, or reinforcing distortions and environmental degradation. By shedding light on who benefits, how much, and through which instruments, the PSE serves as a valuable diagnostic tool to inform policy reforms, align support with climate and development goals, and foster evidence-based dialogue across countries. 2.8 The TC is aligned with the Bank's institutional strategy IDBStrategy+ Transforming for Scale and Impact 2024-2030 (CA-631), in the following core objectives: (i) Addressing Climate Change, and (ii) Bolstering Sustainable Growth.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: To realize these aims, the TC directs its efforts toward the following focus areas: (i) Productive Development and Innovation through the Private Sector: This TC seeks to boost productivity and innovation by measuring and assessing the level of government support provided to agricultural producers, measuring agri-environmental indicators, supporting key programs, and providing robust evidence to foster a more resilient, productive, and innovative agricultural sector. These studies are important for LAC countries because agriculture plays a significant role in the region's economy, and the PSE and other studies related to agricultural policies can provide valuable information on the extent and nature of government support to the sector; (ii) Institutional capacity, rule of law, and citizen security: The TC will strengthen the dialogue between different national and regional institutions.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: This aims to generate greater technical capacity and knowledge on sustainable agriculture and efficient spending allocation. For instance, PSE and agri-environmental indicators are used as benchmarks to compare agricultural policies across countries and regions, enabling policymakers to learn from each other's experiences, identify best practices, and incorporate them to build institutional capacity; (iii) Biodiversity, Natural Capital and Climate Action: IDB has set a goal of aligning all its operations with the Paris Agreement. This TC seeks to build capacity, develop inputs and tools to measure the relationship between commodity- specific policies and the environmental impact of these commodities, and boost ecosystem conservation; (iv) Regional Integration: The TC promotes regional integration by generating harmonized agro-environmental indicators, policy evaluation methodologies, and support measurement tools (PSE/FSE) that facilitate comparability and policy dialogue across countries.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: It also fosters cross-country collaboration through joint studies, peer learning, and dissemination workshops involving multiple LAC governments and regional institutions 2.9 The TC also aligns with the three challenges of the IDB Agriculture Sector Framework (GN-2709-16): (i) Improve food and nutrition security through agriculture; (ii) Increase income and climate resilience; and (iii) Promote agricultural practices that foster environmental sustainability. It also aligns with three of four of the cross-cutting lines of action: (i) Strengthen agricultural institutions; (ii) Reduce gender and ethnic gaps in agriculture; and (iii) Maintain an active and relevant knowledge agenda. Measuring the - 4 - Producer Support Estimate (PSE) and developing robust studies on the effects of agricultural policies is important for boosting productivity and improving resource allocation in a more efficient and effective way to address the challenges the sector faces in a timely manner.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: 2.10 In addition, it aligns with the IDB Environment and Biodiversity Sector Framework (GN- 2827-8) by focusing on one of the three challenges it addresses: (i) Insufficiency of protecting mechanisms and gaps in governance. The TC will contribute to this challenge by assessing how different agricultural policies are affecting key biodiversity indicators and the mechanisms that exist in these agricultural policies to improve biodiversity.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: 2.11 The TC also aligns with the GN-2819-14 OC-SDP, specifically with the following priority areas: (i) Climate Change and Environmental Sustainability (W2A) as it promotes opportunities for the productive sectors of LAC that directly depend on healthy and functional ecosystems (especially agriculture, and associated segments) to improve the transition towards sustainable production and development techniques; and (ii) Competitive Global and Regional Integration (W2D), by strengthening countries' capacity to design and implement agricultural and environmental policies that meet international standards, improving their ability to compete in global markets. By promoting harmonized indicators, transparency in public support, and climate- smart practices, it enhances regional policy coherence and supports the region's integration into sustainable and rules-based agri-food value chains.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: 2.12 The TC aligns closely with the Country Strategies of Brazil (GN-3243-3, validity period 2024-2027), Chile (GN-3140-3, validity period 2022-2026), the Dominican Republic (GN-3084-2, validity period 2021-2024), Ecuador (GN-3103-1, validity period 2022- 2025), El Salvador (GN-3046-4, validity period 2021-2024), Guatemala (GN-3260-1, validity period 2024-2028), Honduras (GN-2944-3, validity period 2019-2024), Mexico (GN-2982, validity period 2019-2024), Panama (GN-3289-1, validity period 2025- 2029), Paraguay (GN-3261-3, validity period 2025-2029), and Uruguay (GN-3056, validity period 2021-2025). It supports environmental sustainability, climate resilience, institutional strengthening, and evidence-based agricultural policymaking across the region. In Brazil (GN-3243-3), the TC supports Pillar 1: Green Transition and Climate Resilience by evaluating the ABC+ Plan, advancing low-carbon agriculture, soil management, and institutional capacity through impact evaluation and policy learning.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: In Chile (GN-3140-3), the TC aligns with goals for inclusive and sustainable economic growth, climate action, and innovation, through its evaluation of the TAS program and use of agro-environmental indicators to enhance sustainability among small and medium-sized farmers. In Uruguay (GN-3056), the TC contributes to Pillar 1: Sustainable Productive Development by evaluating the National Soil Rotation Plan, supporting soil conservation and agro-environmental monitoring aligned with the strategy's cross-cutting environmental objectives. In the Dominican Republic (GN- 3084-2), the TC supports Pillar 2: Sustainable and Inclusive Productive Reactivation, promoting transparency in public support through PSE studies and providing tools for more sustainable agricultural policy design.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: In Ecuador (GN-3103-1), the TC contributes to Pillar 1: Promote productive development in a sustainable and inclusive manner by applying PSE methodology and analyzing GHG emissions from agricultural policies, aligned with goals on green growth and institutional efficiency. In El Salvador (GN-3046-4), the TC supports the third priority area, revitalizing and restructuring - 5 - production, by modernizing the agricultural sector through policy evaluations and sustainability indicators. It also addresses cross-cutting issues such as climate change, institutional capacity, and resilience to natural disasters. In Guatemala (GN-3260-1), the TC supports Pillar 3: Climate Action and Food Availability, advancing sustainable agriculture, GHG mitigation, and capacity building in agro-environmental management.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: In Honduras (GN-2944-3), the TC aligns with Priority Area III: Expansion of Sustainable Production Opportunities by offering tools and analysis to support rural development, climate adaptation, and agricultural sustainability, despite not conducting a direct evaluation. In Mexico (GN-2982), the TC supports goals for inclusive and sustainable growth, particularly through its extension of agro- environmental indicators and support for climate adaptation and transparency in rural public expenditure. In Panama (GN-3289-1), the TC contributes to the goals of productive diversification and modernized public management, offering PSE/FSE analysis, policy studies, and GHG assessments, aligned with cross-cutting themes of environmental governance and digital modernization. In Paraguay (GN-3261-3), the TC supports Pillar 2: Sustainable and Resilient Productive Transformation and Pillar 3: Institutional Capacity and State Modernization, advancing low-carbon agriculture and transparent evaluation of agricultural and fisheries support systems.

3.1Component I. Agro-environmental Analysis and Policy Impact Evaluation (US$300,000). The agri-environmental indicators developed by the OECD capture key aspects of the relationship between agricultural activities and environmental performance. This includes: (i) characterization of the agricultural sector; (ii) agricultural land-use change; (iii) production and input use; (iv) nutrients; (v) greenhouse gas emissions; (vi) ammonia emissions; and (vii) farmland birds' biodiversity (OECD, 2023)1. The indicators highlight the progress and challenges in balancing agricultural productivity with environmental sustainability, including the risks of nutrient runoff, greenhouse gas emissions, and biodiversity loss. Currently the OECD has analyzed four LAC countries: Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica and Mexico. This component aims to expand and deepen the analysis in other LAC countries as well. The goal is to support evidence-based policy-making that promotes sustainable agricultural development in LAC countries, aligning regional performance with global environmental goals.

3.2 This component will produce a set of outputs aimed at strengthening the analytical foundations and monitoring tools for agro-environmental policymaking in LAC. First, it will deliver a regional review of existing agro-environmental policies, providing a comparative analysis of policy frameworks and identifying key gaps and opportunities. Second, it will develop and systematize a set of agro-environmental indicators to improve the monitoring of sustainability outcomes in agriculture, adapted to the specific contexts of at least one participating country. Third, a cross-country analytical study will examine the relationship between agricultural policies and greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, identifying key policy drivers and potential mitigation pathways. Fourth, three rigorous impact evaluations will assess the environmental effects of specific agricultural policy instruments, with a focus on GHG emissions and other agro-environmental outcomes.

In Chile, the analysis will focus on the environmental 1 OECD (2025), Environmental Performance of Agriculture in OECD Countries: Key Trends and Insights, OECD Publishing, Paris, https://doi.org/10.1787/2679ba38-en. - 6 - impacts of the "Transición a la Agricultura Sostenible" (TAS) program implemented by INDAP. This program supports small and medium-sized farmers in adopting sustainable production practices through technical assistance, incentives for agroecological transition, and sustainable land use planning. The evaluation will examine the program's effects on soil quality, input use efficiency, and GHG emissions, particularly in regions with significant TAS implementation. In Uruguay, the study will conduct an in-depth evaluation of the National Soil Rotation Plan, assessing its environmental impacts on soil loss and quality. The plan promotes sustainable soil management by requiring farmers to submit planting plans aligned with land use capacity and erosion risk criteria.

In Brazil, the focus will be on the Plan for Adaptation and Low Carbon Emission in Agriculture (ABC+), assessing its environmental impacts on soil quality, deforestation and GHG emissions. The plan integrates landscape-level approaches, environmental compliance, adoption of low-carbon technologies, capacity-building, and improved rural management systems. Finally, the component will include three participatory workshops (one in person and two online) to present and discuss findings with stakeholders, and a set of communication and dissemination products to support knowledge sharing and policy dialogue. 3.3 The expected outputs of this component include: (i) a regional review of agricultural policies; (ii) agro-environmental indicators developed in one country; (iii) a cross- sectional analysis on the relationship between agricultural policies and GHG emissions; (iv) three impact evaluations; and (v) three dissemination workshops.

3.4 The activities will include contracting local research consultants in each country and partnering with specialized regional universities with extensive experience in agricultural sector research. Also, a peer review process will be conducted, in which the studies will be evaluated by experts in the field. 3.5Component II. Agricultural and Fisheries Policy Analysis (US$320,000). This component will enhance transparency and support evidence-based decision-making by analyzing both the level and structure of public support to agriculture and the effectiveness of agricultural policy implementation. Developed within the framework of the IDB's Agrimonitor initiative, it builds on the Bank's ongoing efforts to promote harmonized measurement of agricultural support and informed policy dialogue in the region.

Key outputs will include four Producer Support Estimate (PSE) studies conducted at the national or subnational level, applying internationally recognized methodologies to assess the magnitude, composition, and trends of government support in Ecuador, Paraguay, Panama, and the Dominican Republic. Additionally, two Fisheries Support Estimate (FSE) studies will evaluate public support to the fisheries sector, contributing to a more comprehensive understanding of support across food production systems. The component will also produce three technical studies on the implementation of key agricultural policies or programs, focusing on institutional design, coordination mechanisms, operational challenges, and lessons learned.

These analytical products will be complemented by four workshops (two in person and two online) that combine results validation with training sessions for government officials and technical staff, and by communication and dissemination activities aimed at sharing findings and encouraging regional dialogue on policy reform and implementation. - 7 - 3.6 The expected outputs of this component include: (i) four national PSE studies that quantify and analyze public support to agriculture; (ii) two FSE studies assessing support to the fisheries sector; (iii) three technical studies on the implementation of key agricultural policies or programs; (iv) four workshops that serve both as validation and capacity-building events for government officials and technical counterparts; and (v) a set of communication and dissemination products, such as policy briefs, summaries, and infographics, to promote broader visibility and facilitate the use of findings in policy processes.

3.7 The activities will include the contracting of local consultants in each country as well as the contracting of specialized regional agencies, such as FAO and/or IFPRI, which have extensive experience in the agricultural sector, the PSE and FSE indicators. For Component 3, the hiring of IFPRI is planned through a direct contracting, as the activities included in the Component are part of the AVANZAR 2030 initiative, that IFPRI is leading in the region. Therefore, no other company on the market can provide similar services. 3.8Component III. Evidence Synthesis on Carbon Sequestration Interventions in Agriculture (US$80,000). This component will support the implementation of a study led by the AVANZAR2030 initiative, in collaboration with IFPRI, IICA, and Juno Evidence Alliance, aimed at synthesizing evidence on interventions that promote carbon sequestration in agrifood systems as a key strategy to address climate change.

In line with AVANZAR2030's guiding principles of rigor, inclusiveness, transparency, and accessibility, the study will generate actionable evidence for policymakers through a structured synthesis of available research. It will focus on two countries, considering their diverse ecological, climatic, and production contexts, including variations in cattle breeds and land use practices. The analysis will identify, prioritize, and assess the impact of promising carbon sequestration practices, particularly in the livestock sector. Drawing on both scientific and grey literature in Spanish and English, the study will involve a systematic screening process using predefined inclusion and exclusion criteria, followed by in-depth review, data extraction, and both quantitative and qualitative analysis. The final output, a research paper, will provide policy recommendations tailored to national contexts and contribute to building a regional public good that supports evidence-informed decision-making for climate-smart agricultural policies.

3.9 The expected outputs of this component are: (i) one working paper; (ii) one participatory workshop (in person) with government officials and key private sector actors from the selected countries; and (iii) one dissemination event. The activities will include the direct contracting of IFPRI, as the activities included in Component III are part of the AVANZAR 2030 initiative, that IFPRI is leading in the region. Therefore, no other company on the market can provide similar services. Also, a peer review process will be conducted, in which the research paper will be evaluated by experts in the field. 3.10 The financing of the operation is provided by the IDB (W2A and W2D). 4.1 This operation will be executed by the IDB given the regional coverage of the activities to be performed and possible synergies and complementarities with Bank operations and research. The execution and disbursement period will be 30 months. Carmine Paolo De Salvo (PTI/ARD) and Gonzalo Rondinone (PTI/ARD) will jointly share execution responsibilities of the proposed TC. Sectoral specialists in the respective countries will also participate in the studies and their supervision. The Climate Change Division (CSD/CCS) will also support the implementation of the TC. The technical counterparts in the respective governments will be public policy planning offices in the Ministries of Agriculture and Fisheries. The TC will be executed by the IDB in accordance with the Bank's Policy for Technical Cooperation (GN-2470-2) and the corresponding Operational Guidelines (OP-619-4).

4.2 The principal reason for this execution scheme is that the Bank has the expertise, capacity and experience identifying and filling knowledge gaps and building institutional capacities at the regional scale. A second reason is related to dissemination given that the policy implications from the proposed studies will be informative and helpful to other countries in the region. The ARD team has a proven track record of executing similar TCs with satisfactory results. The team has executed similar TCs in the Caribbean Region and Central American Region. In addition to the ongoing TC RG-T4292 being implemented for selected countries in the region. Three country studies have been completed under TC RG-T4292 so far, and two are currently under finalization.

ARD has collaborated with the Climate Change Division on similar studies, such as the ongoing Producer Support Estimate (PSE) analyses in Belize and El Salvador. These studies include an examination of agricultural policies and programs across LAC countries. Another study was conducted at the regional level in 2023 and successfully published. It was disseminated at the IDB Agrimonitor 10-year event in 2024, targeting a wide audience interested in agricultural policies. This report, the third in its series, systematically analyzed agricultural support policies in 25 LAC countries, using the OECD's PSE methodology. In addition, other ongoing studies include analyses of the maize tortilla value chain in Mexico and the rice value chain in Colombia. - 9 - 4.3 These studies have significantly contributed to improving policy dialogue in the countries that are the focus of this TC.

The forthcoming studies funded by this TC will provide a closer examination of domestic agricultural, fisheries, and environmental policies. They will generate the necessary information to update the studies mentioned earlier and will be of great help in addressing the challenges faced by the LAC region in the areas of agricultural productivity and innovation, food security, and enhancing climate change resilience. Prior to the initiation of activities in the beneficiary countries the corresponding letter of non-objection will be sought from the Bank's liaison entity in the country. 4.1 The supervision of the TC will be led by the PTI/ARD team, in coordination with PTI/ARD sector specialists in the respective countries who will also act as focal points. The data collection and research activities will be carried out by local contractuals, who will be hired and remunerated through the TC.

The work of the contractuals will be closely monitored bi-monthly, and as often as required by the TC team. Given that this supervision will be conducted remotely and by sectoral specialists in the countries, there will be no additional cost associated with monitoring and data revision. The three components can be worked on in parallel during the TC period, as they are independent and do not rely on one another. This approach allows for efficient progress across all of them simultaneously. Most of the workshops will be conducted remotely in order to save time and resources. 4.2Procurement.

All procurement to be executed under this Technical Cooperation have been included in the Procurement Plan (Annex IV) and will be hired in compliance with the applicable Bank policies and regulations as follows: (a) Hiring of individual consultants, as established in the regulation on Complementary Workforce (AM-650) and (b) Contracting of services provided by consulting firms in accordance with the Corporate procurement Policy (GN-2303-33) and its Guidelines

5.1 The main risk during the execution of the TC is the availability of information to carry out the analysis. Limited access to reliable and up-to-date data could make it challenging to analyze the effectiveness of agricultural policies and develop evidence- based recommendations. To mitigate this risk, governments will express their interest and commitment in each specific initiative and will assign technical counterparts for supporting the gathering and analysis of information. Another risk is the change of policy priorities in countries that will change their administration during the execution of this TC and, therefore, the sustainability of the efforts made. This risk is mitigated by the permanent dialogue of the IDB, including a strong continuous coordination effort with the Country Representative and Chief of Operations, in the different countries and the neutral, evidence-based nature of the proposed studies.

5.2 The knowledge products generated from Bank-executed activities within this TC will be the property of the Bank and may be made available to the public under a creative commons license. However, at the request of the beneficiaries, in accordance with the provisions of AM-331, the intellectual property of said products may also be licensed through specific contractual commitments that shall be prepared with the advice of the Legal Department. - 10 -

2.1 Since 2017, the city of Salvador has been implementing a program aimed at increasing employment and income generated by tourism in the municipality, Prodetur Salvador (BR-L1412). The general objective of the program is to promote tourism development to increase income and formal employment generated for the population of Salvador, with an emphasis on local culture and Afro-descendants. The specific objectives are to increase the spending by tourists in Salvador, as well as the portion of that spending that benefits the community, particularly the Afro-descendant population, through the promotion of cultural and beach tourism, infrastructure improvement, and institutional support for tourism management. 2.2 With a range of varied actions, the program included specific activities aimed at qualifying workers and entrepreneurs for the tourism sector labor market.

These specific projects aimed to qualify vulnerable workers for the tourism sector, as well as qualify entrepreneurs for Afro-ethnic tourism related activities (including a wide array of activities, such as gastronomy, culture, guiding services, etc.). Prodetur had its last disbursement in June 2024, and its PCR is under preparation. - 2 - 2.3 The IDB will also finance a second loan operation with the city, Salvador Capital Afro (BR-L1636), in design stage. The new Program aims to improve the quality of the experience of tourists visiting the municipality, as well as contribute to reducing the socioeconomic inequalities affecting the Afro-descendant population within the local tourism sector's value chain. The loan will include a component focused on Afro- tourism and is expected to be approved in 2025.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: 3.1Objective. The objective of this TC is to develop and implement an impact evaluation of the Afroestima Training Program (AFE), financed by operation BR-L1412 (Prodetur Salvador), and provide inputs for the design of optimal interventions under the scope of the new loan in preparation, BR-L1636 (Salvador Capital Afro). 3.2Main questions to be focused. The evaluation aims to compare what happened to individuals who were trained by the AFE with what would have happened to those same individuals that had not taken the training course. Using technical resources, we will evaluate five training cycles carried out in the AFE, financed between 2021 and 2024, with the aim of answering some key questions: Was the AFE successful in increasing the average income and employability of those trained? Are there heterogeneous effects - men vs women, spec. age groups, different levels of education?

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: Was the AFE capable of increasing formalization and accreditation of participants? 3.3Justification and theory of change. Public training policies for owners of small and medium-sized businesses have become common around the world, especially in developing countries. Such initiatives are mostly aimed at increasing productivity, income, and the skills of more vulnerable workers. According to the literature, there are several reasons to believe that minorities benefit even more from these types of programs than non-minority populations. First, networks are generally an important asset for the success of businesses, and there is evidence that minorities have experienced smaller and less connected networks (Ibarra, 1993; Aldrich and Waldinger, 1990; Seidel, Polzer, and Stewart, 2000)1. Moreover, training programs for small and medium-sized businesses can provide access to knowledge that would otherwise be difficult for minorities to obtain (Card and Giuliano, 2016)2.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: Another important factor is that minorities are disproportionately exposed to self-employment and have less access to capital to start their businesses, thus potentially benefiting more from training (Dunn and Holtz-Eakin, 2000; Fairlie and Robb, 2007; Fairlie, 2006)3. Lastly, minorities may face discrimination from investors and consumers 1 IBARRA, HERMINIA (1993). "Personal Networks of Women and Minorities in Management: A Conceptual Framework." section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: 3.5The context of Salvador, Bahia. A study conducted by the IDB under the preparation of Prodetur Salvador5 shows that the leisure tourism chain in Salvador heavily relies on the Afro community for its existence and competitiveness in two ways: (i) as producers and owners of the unique cultural tourism content that distinguishes Salvador from other tourist destinations; and (ii) as the workforce, accounting for up to 77% of formal employees in the sector.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: However, the study also demonstrates that the Afro-descendant community faces racial inequality within the tourism industry: (i) they are the least benefited racial group (receiving 67% of tourist spending despite being 77% of formal employees, while other races, comprising 23% of formal employees, receive 33% of spending) and earn less (1.8 times less than other groups); (ii) they have less career progression and occupy fewer high positions than other races, even when they have similar educational levels; few access managerial positions, even in cultural activities (between 0.5 and 4% depending on the chain link); and (iii) they face high informality: for every formal Afro tourism employee, there are 0.8 informal ones, who suffer greater social vulnerability. The study also reveals that all these indicators of racial inequality worsen if the Afro-descendant is a woman.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: To conduct this evaluation, this TC intends to employ two separate methodologies: (i) Synthetic Differences-in-Differences + Matching; (ii) Stepped Synthetic Differences-in-Differences. 3.8 In the first method, we plan to use enrollment data of past participants as the treatment group (T). Due to the low representativeness of the waitlist (small sample), missing information will be corrected using synthetic control, creating a control group (C) with characteristics similar to the treated population. Historical data from the RAIS (Brazilian Registry of Employed and Unemployed Persons) and databases from the Salvador Economic Development Secretariat will be utilized for this modeling. 3.9 For the second method, the treatment group (T) remains the same, but the control group (C) will consist of yet untreated groups to be drawn from newly registered participants for the upcoming training cycle starting in August 2024 (approximately 350 participants).

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: Historical information from existing databases will be sought for this population, ensuring the creation of a control group with characteristics closer to those of the treated population. 3.10 It's worth mentioning that, although there is an established methodology for evaluating the effectiveness of similar tourism programs to generate employment and income (Castillo et al., 2015; Blackman et al., 2012; UNESCO, 2014), there is no specific assessment of the effects of training and development of Afro-entrepreneurship in the tourism sector, such as AFE, on income and labor supply of individuals. 3.11Strategic relevance. The IDB has as one of its strategic priorities to work to address the exclusion of Afro-descendants due to origin, racial or ethnic status. Projects like Afroestima include economic empowerment, identification of racial gaps through data collection and harmonization, and promotion of policy development at national and subnational levels.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: The proposed evaluation fills a crucial knowledge gap by investigating the impact of tourism projects with a racial focus, as there is a shortage of comprehensive studies that have systematically and empirically evaluated the effect of these training programs on the Afro descendant community, particularly in terms of increased income, employability, and possible heterogeneous effects. A specific evaluation of AFE is of utmost relevance for guiding better resource allocation in future Bank-financed operations, both in tourism sector or others related.6 3.12Data and main variables.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: The data to be used will be sourced from: RAIS (Registry of Employed and Unemployed Persons), information on formalization of micro- entrepreneurs provided by SEBRAE (Brazilian Support Service for Micro and Small Enterprises), CadÚnico (Unified Registry for Social Programs), Federal Revenue Service, as well as data from the Salvador Economic Development Secretariat related to beneficiaries of training programs conducted by the Municipality such as name, locality, race, gender, income, type of business . The Municipality has already shared with the IDB team data on the profile of the AFE beneficiaries in each cycle (1.066 people).

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: This data set includes contact information and national registry identification 6 It is worth noting that, if possible, information from AfroBizz (a program aimed at Afro-entrepreneurs in the tourism sector in Salvador) will also be used and evaluated to enhance the robustness of the analyses, considering that most participants of AfroBizz also participated in Afroestima. - 5 - numbers, that will make possible the connection with other datasets previously mentioned - such as RAIS, CadÚnico, etc. Furthermore, the Municipality also possesses data from the survey of tourist demand, which includes valuable information about the population that can be utilized as context. Additionally, the registry of micro and small entrepreneurs in the city provides inputs such as profit data, challenges faced in business, and other relevant information. 3.13Strategic alignment.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: The TC is aligned with the IDB Group's Country Strategy with Brazil 2024-2027 (GN-3243-1), specifically with the specific objectives of strengthening policies for the protection and welfare of women and diverse population and empowering sustainable investments. Furthermore, the TC is consistent with the IDB Group's Institutional Strategy: Transformation for Scale and Impact (CA 631) and aligns with the objectives of: (i) reducing poverty and inequality; and (iii) fostering sustainable regional growth. The TC is also aligned with the following operational focus areas: gender equality and inclusion of diverse population groups; institutional capacity, rule of law and citizen security; social protection and human capital development.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: The TC is also aligned with the Ordinary Capital Strategic Development Program (OC SDP), Window 2, Priority Area 1: Climate Change and Environmental Sustainability (W2A) (GN-2819-14), especially with the priority area of inclusive social development and inclusive economic growth, considering it will generate knowledge products, data and relevant operational inputs to guide future interventions in those areas. Finally, the CT is aligned with the Tourism Sector Framework (GN-2779-12), especially in its area focused on expanding the economic benefits of tourism and its distribution to the most vulnerable groups. 3.14Synergies. Inputs provided by the studies conducted within the scope of this TC will also be valuable inputs for future programs developed by IDB Invest related to training and entrepreneurial assistance in the tourism sector, providing evidence-based data for future investment opportunities. 3.15Beneficiaries.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: The main beneficiary of the TC is the Municipality of Salvador, that will benefit from the results of studies conducted in order to better design future training interventions. The IDB and other financial institutions will also benefit from the results, considering the ample dissemination strategy to be conducted, and that results achieved might be widely adapted to other training programs contexts.

4.1 The activities to be financed by the TC have been grouped into two components as described below: 4.2Component 1: Impact assessment of the Afroestima program (US$200,000). This component focuses on the design and execution of the impact evaluation of the Afroestima program. The component will finance consultancy services aimed at (i) collecting the data needed to carry out the evaluation from both public databases (RAIS, Cadúnico, Receita Federal, etc.) and the information provided by Salvador Municipality; (ii) designing and implementing the selected methodologies. The component will finance - 6 - consultancy services to (i) carry out a detailed interpretation of the results, highlighting the main economic and social impacts achieved by the participants; (ii) prepare comprehensive reports that will include robust statistical analysis and explanatory graphs, as well as recommendations for improving public policies and future strategies focused on the tourism value-chain, specifically producing inputs for further incorporation under the BR-L1636. The main inputs generated through the analysis will be disseminated to internal audiences in the IDB Group so they can be incorporated in future program designs - not only in BR-L1636. The expected result for this component is to analyze and disseminate information on the impact assessment for both internal and external audiences, contributing for better planning of future interventions financed by the IDB and the Municipality of Salvador.

Expected results derived from the analysis include an increase in the average income and employability of the participants, demonstrating the program's effectiveness in improving their economic conditions. It is expected to identify heterogeneous effects, with results varying between men and women, different age groups, and educational levels, revealing how different subgroups benefited from the training. Additionally, the AFE is anticipated to have contributed to the formalization and accreditation of participants, increasing their inclusion in formal and recognized employment, thus highlighting the program's positive impact on professionalization and the recognition of the participants' work. 4.7Sustainability. The establishment of guidelines related to the registration and selection of participants of training programs will set the basis for future rigorous analysis of such interventions in the city of Salvador and provide more sustainability for the results expected from the TC. - 7 -

Basic Information for TC Objectives and Justification of the TC The objective of this TC is to strengthen institutional capacity within the quality infrastructure system to promote Micro, Small, Medium Enterprises (MSME) competitiveness under a sustainable development framework. Context: Quality Infrastructure systems facilitate competitiveness and growth. In the context of chronic low growth (GDP growth in Jamaica averaged 0.73% per year between 2001-2024 compared to a global average of 3.4% and a Caribbean regional average of 1.3%) and steadily declining total factor productivity (TFP), understanding the factors that influence MSME innovation and competitiveness are important for long term growth. Quality Infrastructure Systems (QIS), which consist of standards development, accreditation, metrology, and conformity assessment, are one such enabling factors vital for economic growth.

Promoting regulations and standards have been evidenced to increase GDP between 1% and 2.4% in the short term (Maskus and Tsunehiro 2001). Several studies also evidence the effect of certifications on competitiveness. Certifications like ISO 9001 are associated with larger reductions in product costs (Corbett et al 2005); better financial performance (Sharma, 2005); and higher rates of corporate survival as well as increasing sales, employment, and wages (Levine and Toffel 2010). Moreover, literature has shown that certification increases revenues because quality certification allows firms to access new markets and customers (Singh et al 2010), has positive impacts on innovative behavior (Manders et al 2016) or improves the capabilities of human capital (Lo et al 2013). Low levels of quality certification among firms, especially women-led firms.

According to the 2020 Innovation, Firm Performance and Gender (IFPG), the percentage of Jamaican firms that had obtained an internationally recognized quality certification was 21.88% compared to 29.16% in Guyana and 33.34% in Suriname (the OECS countries have the lowest percentage, averaging around 14%). Only 17.63% women owned firms compared to 24.18% male owned firms have an internationally recognized quality certification in Jamaica. Several factors may be at play such as cost of quality certification, access to quality certification, information asymmetry regarding certifications required for operating and exporting, etc. yet there is limited data to fully understand the level of awareness and types of constraints MSMEs face in accessing quality infrastructure services and in obtaining quality certification. Institutional capacity gaps of the National Quality Infrastructure.

Jamaica's National Quality Infrastructure (NQI) includes institutions such as the Bureau of Standards, Jamaica (BSJ), the National Certification Body of Jamaica (NCBJ), and the Jamaica National Agency for Accreditation (JANAAC) Global Accreditation that provide quality infrastructure services to MSMEs, laboratories, conformity assessment bodies, and others. The 2024 Quality Infrastructure Index for Sustainable Development (QI4SD) ranked Jamaica 126th globally, and 16th within the Latin America and Caribbean region, placing it behind Barbados (109th globally and 13th regionally) and Trinidad and Tobago (110th globally and 14th regionally). Significant weaknesses persisted in metrology (score of 8.8/100), standardization (23.2/100) and conformity assessment (7.1/100), highlighting areas that require improvement to enhance Jamaica's overall quality infrastructure (UNIDO, 2024).

These findings align to the WB's recent study on Jamaica's "National Coordinated Laboratory Strategy Framework and Implementation Plan for Jamaica" which emphasized the need for modernization and improved service delivery to various industries and private enterprises including the need for upgrading "modern equipment and digital systems to improve turnaround times, enhance test accuracy, and streamline laboratory information management systems". Expected Results and Beneficiaries. To address these constraints, it is critical to enhance the national quality infrastructure, especially physical facilities and service offerings, in alignment with MSME needs. This TC will provide the Government of Jamaica with a detailed roadmap to guide future investments to improve quality infrastructure services for Jamaica and the region.

As such, the project ultimately aims to benefit MSMEs, especially women-led firms, as well as other entities that may have demand for QI services (such as laboratories, conformity assessment bodies, etc.). Indirect beneficiaries include the wider public that consume MSME products and services. The TC also seeks to strengthen the public's sector's capabilities in private sector development (PSD) public investment program design, implementation, monitoring, and evaluation with the value-added focus of building advanced econometric and data analytics expertise amongst public sector officials responsible for private sector and innovation policy and instrument design. Complementarities. This TC is complementary to national development priorities contained in Vision 2030 which seeks to create a prosperous economy through the development of internationally competitive industry structures, namely: maintaining economic stability; enabling business environment, strong economic infrastructure; and entrepreneurship.

Specifically, (GOAL -3, National Outcome -8) states that Jamaica will develop the capabilities of the MSME sector and "improve the channels in which they participate in economic activity." The project is firmly anchored in the priority programs and objectives of Ministry of Industry, Investment, and Commerce (MIIC's) Strategic Business Plan 2023-2027 such as identifying and engaging MSMEs to participate in targeted activities aimed at supporting their growth and development. Policies such as the National Quality Policy (NQP) of Jamaica 2019 and 2018 MSME and Entrepreneurship Policy in Jamaica aim to improve Jamaica's quality infrastructure and MSME access to business support services, standards and certification. Finally, at the regional level, the TC will complement capacity building efforts at CARICOM Regional Organization for Standards and Quality (CROSQ).

The TC draws lessons from operations such as 3824/BL-GY "Enhancing the National Quality Infrastructure for Economic Diversification and Trade Promotion" and 5594/OC-GY "Enhancing the National Quality Infrastructure for Competitiveness"; Reformulation and Additional Financing" is the importance of firm level data for monitoring and evaluation of large national quality infrastructure programs. Another key lesson learnt is the importance of stakeholder coordination to address bottlenecks that may arise during execution. It builds on previous work completed under ATN/OC-20171-JA "Support for National MSME Innovation, Competitiveness and Productive Growth" where a roadmap was developed to identify business support programs/services from over 20 government agencies, commercial banks, and universities in Jamaica that participated in roadshows across the country where MSMEs were able to directly access business support services in one location.

The TC will complement ATN/OC-21285-JA "Strengthening the National Quality Infrastructure for Competitiveness and Green Growth in Jamaica" which intends to provide training in accreditation and to develop a pilot to promote the adoption of green standards and certifications which can be incorporated into Component 1 of this TC. Strategic Alignment. This TC is consistent with the IDB Group Institutional Strategy 2024-2030: Transforming for Scale and Impact (CA-631) and is aligned with the objectives of Bolster Sustainable Growth by building the capacity of institutions within the quality infrastructure system to encourage competitiveness and quality service offerings for MSMEs.

It is also aligned with the operational focus areas of: (i) Institutional Capacity, Rule of Law, and Citizen Security as it relates to institutional strengthening of the MIIC and BSJ in Monitoring, evaluation and learning, specific to private sector development programs; and (ii) Productive Development and Innovation through encouraging demand for quality services to promote competitiveness of MSMEs. This TC also aligns with the objectives of the IDB Group's Country Strategy with Jamaica 2022-2026 (GN-3138) and the specific strategic objective 1.1 "to create and expand channels for sustainable businesses" as it aims to support private sector productivity and sustainable growth.

This TC is aligned with the objectives and activities of The Ordinary Capital Strategic Development Program (OC SDP) Window 2, Priority Area 3: Effective, Efficient, and Transparent Institutions (W2C) (GN-2819-14), given that the TC activities aim to strengthen the institutional capacity of actors in the NQI ecosystem. This TC is aligned with the priorities defined in the Innovation, Science and Technology Sector Framework Document (GN-2791-13) as it relates to line action 2 "Boost investment in key public goods for innovation", where specific mention is made to support countries in the region in implementing quality certification standards. This TC hopes to strengthen collaboration between partners and the IDB Group (IDB Lab, IDB Invest, and other sectors) which have conducted studies and projects related to promoting quality certification amongst firms. Alignment with One Caribbean Framework.

The TC aligns with the IDB One Caribbean Framework (GN-3201-5) and its priority area of private sector engagement, as it will be providing technical inputs to the design of a regional center of excellence in quality infrastructure. Thus, it will provide services across the region, which has potential for replication across the Caribbean countries. It also aligns with One Caribbean's cross-cutting area of strengthening technical capabilities and institutional capacity given that Component 2 of the TC, which focuses on building the capacity of selected public sector officials in data analytics and the design, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of private sector development programs, will develop training materials that can be disseminated across the region. Description of activities Component 1: Roadmap for Improving Quality Infrastructure Services (US$130,000.00).
This component will finance technical studies that will provide a roadmap for modernizing and expanding QI service offerings primarily targeted to MSMEs in Jamaica and across the Caribbean region.

The following outputs are expected: (i) design and implementation of a survey to collect data to map current and future demands for quality infrastructure services amongst MSMEs, particularly to understand constraints of exporting MSMEs and women-led firms; (ii) a detailed demand analysis utilizing survey results and other data to provide insight on sector specific and gender sensitized quality infrastructure service needs, as well as recommendations for streamlining and digitalization of services; (iii) an institutional gap analysis to identify the equipment, technologies, facility upgrades, accreditation processes, and training/capacity development required for modernizing the quality infrastructure and improving/expanding services tailored to MSMEs, especially women-led firms; and (iv) a feasibility study for establishing a Centre of Excellence (COE) in Jamaica for quality under a sustainable development framework. The study will assess similar models, incentives, and strategies for long-term sustainability.

It will include recommendations for key services to be offered, detailed architectural design, financial requirements analysis, legal and regulatory analysis, risk assessment, and an operating model. Component 2: Strengthening Monitoring, Evaluation, and Learning Capacity. (US$20,000.00). This component will finance activities intended to strengthen the institutional capacity of the MIIC, particularly the BSJ, to monitor and evaluate private sector development public investment programs. Specifically, the TC will finance the design and implementation of a training workshop that will develop the capabilities of at least ten competitively selected public sector professionals to design, implement, monitor and evaluate private sector development programs.

The training workshop will utilize existing IDB courses(such as Development Effectiveness and Project Management for Results) and will include additional modules focused on data analytics for monitoring and reporting and advanced quantitative methods for conducting economic analyses and robust impact evaluations of PSD programs. Outputs include (i) the development and dissemination of training materials; and (ii) the implementation of one in-person training workshop for at least 10 public sector officials. The total cost of the TC will be US$150,000.00, and it will be executed and disbursed for 24 months. The funding source of this TC is the OC SDP Window 2 - Institutions (W2C). There will be no local counterpart funding.

The funds will be used as follows: Indicative Budget Executing agency and execution structure In adherence to the Bank's Technical Cooperation Policy (GN-2470-2) and the Procedures for the Processing of Technical Cooperation Operations and Related Matters (OP-619-4), the beneficiary has requested the TC to be executed by the Bank. This TC will thus be executed through the Bank's Competitiveness, Technology and Innovation Division of the Productivity, Trade and Innovation Sector (PTI/CTI) in coordination with the Country Office of Jamaica (CCB/CJA) which will be the Unit of Disbursement Responsibility. This is justified by the limited institutional capacity of the BSJ to design, implement, monitor and evaluate projects and to procure qualified expertise. CTI will support the identification and supervision of consultancies to ensure the quality and timeliness of the products, according to section 4.5 of the Bank's Technical Cooperation Guidelines (GN-2629-1).

The project intends to build capacity within the beneficiary to design, execute, and monitor future PSD projects and investment loan programs. The project team will closely coordinate implementation of the TC with the MIIC and BSJ and other institutions and/or entities identified as key stakeholders in the project. All procurement to be executed under this TC has been included in the Procurement Plan (Annex IV) and will be hired in compliance with the applicable Bank's established procurement methods, namely: (i) contracting of individual consultants, as set forth in Section AM-650 of the Administrative Manual "Complementary Workforce" for individual consultants; and (ii) contracting of consulting firms for services of an intellectual nature, in accordance with the IDB's Corporate Procurement Policy (GN-2303-33) and its associated guidelines. Monitoring.

Project output indicators will be monitored by the Project Team in accordance with the proposed results matrix. Intellectual Property. The knowledge products generated within the framework of this TC will be the property of the Bank and may be made available to the public under a creative commons license. Major issues One major risk is a low response rate to the proposed demand survey. This will be mitigated through targeted campaigns that clearly communicate the benefits of participating and highlight any available incentives for MSMEs to complete the survey. Another key risk is potential delays in receiving timely inputs from various participating agencies, which could impact the project timeline. To address this, dedicated project management will be implemented to monitor timelines, facilitate effective communication, and promote coordination across agencies.

Exceptions to Bank policy There are not exceptions to the Bank's policy. Environmental and Social Aspects This TC is intended to finance pre-feasibility or feasibility studies of specific investment projects and the environmental and social studies associated with them; therefore, the terms of reference and products of this TC will be consistent with the applicable requirements of the Bank's Environmental and Social Policy Framework (ESPF). section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: 2.1 Soacha is a municipality in the department of Cundinamarca adjacent to the city of Bogotá with a population of 645,205 inhabitants ( DANE, 2018). According to the Unit for the Victims Assistance and Reparation, out the 7,580,241 people displaced by the armed conflict experienced in Colombia between 1984 and 2017, Soacha received an amount of 58,471 ( DNP,2018). On the other hand, 24,026 venezuelan migrants are - 2 - already registered and have settled in Soacha1,in accordance to Migration Colombia. The arrival of migrants in this municipality is mainly motivated by the proximity to Bogotá.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: Although the national and local government have developed programs to serve both internally displaced and migrant population, they face a vulnerable situation given that in some cases they live in informal settlements, with low habitability conditions, poor access to roads, insufficient public and social services and limited employment opportunities. 2.2 Currently, the municipality has 342,240 people classified in the Identification System of Potential Beneficiaries of Social Programs - SISBEN ( DNP, 2018), so it is estimated that 53% of the population belongs to the lowest socioeconomic tiers (1 and 2) and under vulnerable conditions. The coverage of aqueduct and sewerage is 91.69% and 88.58% respectively, being the lowest in the Cundinamarca department. Also, the percentage of students enrolled in preschool, basic and middle levels is 76% and the unemployment rate in 2018 reached 13%.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: In Soacha, as in the rest of the country, there are great difficulties for young people to access jobs, among other factors, due to lack of training. According to DANE (the National Statistics Office), the youth unemployment rate was 18.1% (in 2019), increasing 1.6% in relation to 2018. In addition to this, drug micro trafficking, social cleansing, victimization of young people and the presence of illegal armed actors persist, with young people being an easy target for illegal activities. 2.3 For more than 30 years, the municipality of Soacha has stood out for promoting music as an expression of its traditions, seeking to strengthen the identity and sense of belonging of its inhabitants.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: Since 1988 the Sol y Luna Festival has been held, which is an important stage for the promotion and dissemination of the artistic and cultural products of local musical groups, which day by day contribute and strengthen the cultural development of the municipality. Likewise, since 2002 the Hip-Hop festival has been held with the purpose of spreading hip hop culture and to promote local groups, cultural organizations, alternative events and strengthening the cultural agenda of the municipality. This culture has been consolidating and brings together young people around different artistic expressions such as musical creation, graffiti, dance and clothing design, as well as production activities, which presents a great opportunity for the local economic development. 2.4Creative and cultural economy.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: According to multiple studies, the creative and cultural economy (also known as orange economy2) has been recognized as an important vehicle for the economic development of countries, represented in its added value, exports, employment, investments and productivity. Estimates show that creative and cultural industries generate revenues of US$2,250 billion and 29.5 million 1 As of December 31st, 2019, 1,771,237 venezuelans have been established in Colombia, being Soacha the municipality in the interior of the country, apart from the main capital cities and border municipalities, that has received the most population, ranking 14 out of 61.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: 2 According to Benavente, and Grazzi, 2017 ( http://dx.doi.org/10.18235/0000841) "the orange (or creative) economy is the group of activities through which ideas are transformed into cultural and creative goods and services whose value is or could be protected by intellectual property rights (IPRs)." Previous studies (Quartesan, Romis, and Lanzafame, 2007; Buitrago and Duque, 2013; Oxford Economics, 2014) and definitions coincide in the following aspects of the orange economy: (i) the recognition of creativity, arts, and culture as productive endeavors; (ii) the relationship with generating and exploiting intellectual property rights, in particular copyright; and (iii) the direct role of these activities in the value chain that transforms ideas into products. The creative economy includes activities related to three main concepts: (i) traditional and artistic activities, (ii) the creative industry, and (iii) activities that provide creative support to traditional industries.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: - 3 - jobs worldwide (per year), employing approximately 1% of the world's active population (Ernst & Young, 2015). In Latin America and the Caribbean, estimates indicate that creative industries generate revenues of US$124 billion and 2.2% of regional GDP. For Colombia in the period between 2014 and 2018, 32 activities included in this sector accounted for 1.9% of the national added value, close to the reported for the civil engineering construction sector of 2.1% (Ernst & Young, 2015). Between August 2018 and September 2019, exports from the Creative and Cultural Industries reached more than US$246 million to 58 countries (ProColombia, 2019).

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: In that purpose, since 2010 the " National Policy for the Promotion of Cultural Industries in Colombia" (CONPES 3659) was formulated and through Law 1834 of 2017 (Orange Economy Law) is recognized as an economic sector with the capacity of generating quality employment, and as an engine of development, which fosters the social cohesion as well as identity and equity. The Government has set the goal to position Colombia among the top 20 service exporting countries at the end of 2022. 2.5 Considering that Soacha could be known as a hub of activities that can be registered within the creative economy, it is worth highlighting the possibilities of job creation and job training in these fields.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC

To that extent, sectoral operations that address current development gaps, which are further stressed by migration, may access non- reimbursable resources from the IDB Grant Facility4 or Donors resources (or a combination of both).

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: This technical cooperation meets the IDB Migration Initiative objectives of (i) supporting countries that have received intraregional migration that represents over 0.5% of its total population; and (ii) focusing investments in migrant receiving communities. 2.11Objective. The main objective of this TC is to contribute to the socio-cultural, emotional and economic inclusion of youth in a condition of exclusion from the labor market in Soacha, Cundinamarca, through job training, as well as management and entrepreneurship skills in the culture and creative sector. Specifically, it seeks to: (i) develop skills in artistic practices and project management framed in cultural and creative economy (orange economy); (ii) increase access to job offers in the cultural sector, and (iii) increase access to comprehensive quality education, nutrition and early childhood services for the artists' children.

4.1 Given the experience that Fundación Gratitud and aeioTU Fundación Carulla have had in the activities proposed by this TC, and in the Soacha community, it is pertinent that these organizations be the EAs for this TC. Its mission is to promote access to art and culture as tools for emotional well-being and social transformation by developing a sustainable and replicable model.

The Foundation has conducted cultural empathy workshops and artistic-creative experiences within the Partnerships for Reconciliation Program of ACDI-VOCA and USAID benefiting 110 young people. Through collaboration with allies, gastronomic and artistic experiences have been provided to spread the wealth of the municipality of Tumaco (Nariño), - 7 - reaching more than 210 people and in Soacha itself through spaces for interaction with art and culture impacting 15,000 people. Together with the British Council, storytelling workshops have been carried out as a healing tool in the midst of colombian armed conflict, with 273 participants so far. 4.3 Fundación Carulla is a non-profit organization that was founded in 1961. In the last 10 years, it has worked to improve the quality and coverage of the ecosystem of comprehensive early childhood care services in vulnerable communities of Colombia.

It operates 30 schools of its own, has provided attention to more than 236,000 children (between 0 months and 5 years), has trained more than 14,000 educators and influenced the parenting practices of more than 425,000 parents or caregivers. section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: 2.1Justification. Amazonia, spanning nine countries and covering about 40% of the South American territory, harbors the world's largest tropical rainforest, representing 35% of the total primary forest land. It not only stands out due to its great biodiversity - 2 - but also influences regional and global climates. It is home to 47 million people1 amongst them 2 million being indigenous peoples2 and spans 6.7 million km2 divided between Brazil (62%), Peru (11%), Bolivia (8%), Colombia (6%), Venezuela (6%), Guyana (2%), Suriname (2%), Ecuador (2%) and French Guiana (1%).3 2.2 Since the 1970s, the clearing of Amazonian forests has intensified, and millions of hectares of primary forest cover have been lost. In addition to direct land conversion and ecosystem degradation, climate change is intensifying disturbances and altering the dynamics of the Amazonia biome.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: The combined effect of anthropogenic land use change and climate change places its people to a series of social, economic, security and conservation challenges and threats, especially for Indigenous Peoples, Afro- descendants and local communities. 2.3 In addition, structural factors such as low productivity, illegal activities, logistical challenges and infrastructural deficiencies (electricity, Internet, etc.) exacerbate deforestation, poverty and exclusion. A recent study in the Andean Amazon region shows that over 85% of the population in 94% of the study territory experiences at least one development gap.4 In terms of area affected, the gaps in access to drinking water, access to primary and secondary education in rural areas, and investment in green and inclusive activities are the most severe. The financial impact gap in Amazonia is a significant issue, primarily driven by the region's complex environmental, social, and regulatory landscape.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: 2.4 In this context, Bioeconomy5 acts as a paradigm shift that promotes an alternative and transformative economic model based on the sustainable use of biological resources. It connects global agendas on biodiversity, climate and sustainable development with the potential to reverse biodiversity loss, increase resilience to climate change and protect vulnerable populations and ecosystems. However, for Bioeconomy in Amazonia to flourish, it is critical to look beyond ecosystems, climate and rural areas. To increase the flow of funds to bio-businesses in the bioeconomy of the Amazon region, it is essential to understand how Bioeconomy intersects and interacts with different sectors, such as social protection, labor markets, health, education, infrastructure and cities, which ultimately also shape the overall enabling environment for Bioeconomy.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: This cross-cutting framework/sectorial-nexus approach does not aim to respond to technical and governance barriers and risks that are also relevant for the sustainable and inclusive development of the region, such as local infrastructure and connectivity gaps, or deficiencies in land tenure and rights. 2.5 In 2024, the Amazonia Forever program expanded from $1 billion to $4.2 billion in the eight Amazon countries, including $118 million in technical cooperation. This expansion involves mobilizing financial resources from the public and private sectors to increase our impact. Meanwhile, the number of regional networks grew to more than 10, covering sectors such as finance, politics, science, indigenous organizations, 1 Science Panel for the Amazon 2021 Amazon Assessment Report 2021 (New York: United Nations Sustainable Development Solutions Network) 2 2 RAISG, 2020. It comprises activities related to the invention, development, production, and use of biological products and processes. For the purposes of this proposal, in the Amazon the bioeconomy aims to be climate and nature-positive, encouraging sustainable land-use practices that lead to reduced emissions, higher carbon stocks, net gains in natural capital, and increased climate resilience of vulnerable populations and ecosystems.

chunk_text: - 3 - cities, private companies and non-profit organizations, such as the RedBioAmazonia (network of Biodiversity Research and Innovation Institutes), the network of Ministries of Education, the MINURVI (forum of ministries of housing and urbanism), and the Amazonian Cities Forum, among others. 2.6 Placing Bioeconomy and Amazonian People at the center requires a multi-sector (i.e. traditional, non-traditional), multi-level (i.e. local, subnational, national and regional) and multi-stakeholder (i.e. private, public, civil society, IP.AD.TC) scope for better targeted interventions. Working through a sectoral-nexus approach can enhance systemic coordination, articulation, collaboration, knowledge transfer and regional integration to increase ambition, impact and scale and thus increase the flow of funds to bio-businesses in the bioeconomy of the Amazon region. 2.7 Bioeconomy (together with creative economies) is one of the five pillars of IDB's Amazonia Forever6, an umbrella program for both internal and external audiences.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: The other pillars of Amazonia Forever are: Combating deforestation, People, Cities Connectivity, and sustainable Infrastructure, Sustainable and low carbon Agriculture and Forestry. The transversal areas of action are: Inclusion of Women, Indigenous Peoples, Afro-descendants and Multicultural Communities; Conservation of Climate, Biodiversity and Forests; and Strengthening Institutional Capacities and Rules of Law. Within the IDB, Amazonia Forever acts as a framework to coordinate and foster synergies with key sectors to increase financing and coherent impact interventions in Amazonia. Several partnerships and networks were boosted in this context to tackle different aspects of Amazonia's sustainable development challenges. 2.8 As such, Amazonia Forever works as a mechanism for collaboration and coordination in critical lines of action and sectors in the territories, based on countries' priorities.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: It is expected for Amazonia Forever to be an important articulator and contributor with the aim to addressing critical gaps, scale up financing, knowledge intelligence and collectively support the implementation of the different Treaties7, Declarations8 and Action plans aimed at closing social, ecological and economic gaps in Amazonia. Thus, AF advocates for a strengthened sectorial and economic-financial coordination in the region to scale-up the impact of interventions. 2.9 Multilateral and global Summits and Forums to advance Global Agendas, such as the Conference of the Parties (COP)9, present a great opportunity for representatives from governments, the private sector, and civil society to gather, discuss and negotiate efforts to tackle climate change and biodiversity. The 30th Conference of the Parties (COP30) in 2025 will be hosted for the first time in Belém, Brazil - also called the Amazon COP.
