Based on the progress of Amazonia Forever, tThe objective of this TC is to generate, capitalize and disseminate knowledge from Amazonia Forever to increase the flow of funds to bio-businesses and advance enabling conditions to foster bioeconomy in the region through a sectoral-nexus approach.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: The specific objectives are: (1) develop knowledge stocktaking products that allow to demonstrate results and impacts of the Amazonia Forever Program and its Bioeconomy pillar, as well as support regional dialogue and networks to strengthen south-south knowledge transfer, coordination and coherence; (2) strategic support for high-level dialogue for the generation of public policies on issues of common interest in Amazonia, with a focus on Bioeconomy and cross-sectorial interventions and integration of natural capital in decision-making both at the national and sub-national level; and (3) facilitation of actions for the coordinated mobilization of climate, biodiversity, bioeconomy and innovative finance opportunities for supporting means of implementation in Amazonian countries (i.e. activities that close the finance-impact gap). 2.13Beneficiaries.

chunk_text: The main beneficiaries of the TC will be public sector officials from relevant sectoral ministries in the seven Amazonian countries10, such as the Ministries of Environment. Indirect beneficiaries will be bio-businesses in the Amazon region, that will benefit from national policies, regulatory frameworks and the increase of funds. 2.14Strategic Alignment. section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: This TC is also aligned with the operational focus areas of: (i) biodiversity, natural capital and climate action; (ii) regional integration, by promoting multi-sector and multi-level cooperation system of countries in the Amazon basin; and (iii) social protection and human capital development. It aligns with IDB Integrated Strategy for Climate Change Adaptation and Mitigation, and Sustainable and Renewable Energy (GN-2835-13), by enabling the Bioeconomy and targeting activities that reduce GHG emissions, enhance carbon stocks, and/or increase resilience, and relates to at least two sectoral frameworks: (i) Environment and Biodiversity Sectoral Framework (GN-2827-8) and (ii) Climate Change Sectoral Framework (GN-2835-8). The operation is also aligned with the Amazonia Forever Regional Program through its five pillars and three transversal areas of action.

chunk_text: 2.15 Finally, this TC is consistent with the Country Strategies that prioritize sustainable and inclusive development of Amazonia and conservation of its ecosystems.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: Specifically, the TC contributes to knowledge generation for stocktaking, decision-making and mobilization of sustainable financing towards priority areas in the country strategies and their Amazon region, such as inclusive and sustainable social development by promoting access to quality basic services for the indigenous population, farmers, and Afro-Bolivians, incorporating cultural relevance and climate change mitigation, adaptation, and monitoring actions (Bolivia, 2022-25, GN-3088), promoting sustainable practices to curb deforestation and protect biodiversity in the Amazon, while enhancing access to essential services for communities (Brazil, 2024-2027, GN- 3243-3), boost social and territorial inclusion in strategically important areas such as the Amazon region (Colombia, 2024-2027, GN-3238-3), promoting sustainable practices to protect biodiversity and curb deforestation, while implementing innovative financing (Ecuador, 2022-2025, GN-3103-1), supporting economic diversification of the non-oil economy (Guyana, 2023-2026, GN-3187), strengthening social progress in the context of environmental sustainability with a decentralized approach that prioritizes rural areas, as well as the sustainable development of the Amazon region (Peru, 2022-2026, GN-3110-1), supporting a sustainable recovery by supporting evidence-based policies and governance frameworks (Suriname, 2021-2025, GN- 3065) amongst others.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC

chunk_text: This TC will build on RG-T4624 - Knowledge Generation and IDB Group Synergies for Bioeconomy in the Amazon region, which amongst others seeks to evaluate IDB interventions in Amazonia, by leveraging the evidence generated on good practices of IDB interventions in the region mainly for component 3 of this TC. chunk_text: 2.18Synergies will also be sought with ongoing efforts under RG-T4493 "Positioning Latin America and the Caribbean as an ambitious region on climate and nature at COP29 and COP16" which began implementation in July 2024 to create a space for dialogue to help identify common policy issues for the Latin American and Caribbean (LAC) region in the context of the international climate and biodiversity negotiations and the Multilateral Development Bank (MDB) Reform Agenda to facilitate regional collective action, as well as dialogues and strategies to generate and showcase its strategic focus on natural capital, biodiversity and climate change. chunk_text: Finally, this TC will coordinate with other research activities that are being carried out within the IDB Group, or at the level of the countries of the Amazon Region, through the cross-referencing of information and data, and discussion on the results obtained with the purpose of building a consolidated and accessible repository of knowledge.

3.1 Component 1. Knowledge stocktaking using a sectorial nexus approach to support regional dialogue, knowledge transfer and networks (US$600,000). The objective of this component is to develop knowledge stocktaking products that allow to demonstrate results and impacts of Amazonia Forever11 and its Bioeconomy pillar as a crosscutting framework that encompasses multiple sectors. In addition, this component also aims to advance dialogue on regulation in bioeconomy and its enabling conditions, as well as support regional dialogue and networks. This aligns with the broad vision of Amazon Cooperation Treaty Organization (ACTO), to promote and strengthen South-South collaboration and cooperation processes.

These activities include: (i) generation of knowledge products and stocktaking, such as a stock-taking of the updated Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) of Amazonian countries; (ii) support communication and dissemination of knowledge products through activities and events to advance the understanding of bioeconomy and strengthen south-south knowledge transfer, aligned with COP30 prioritized tracks, (iii) support sectors, partners and networks in the development and dissemination of strategic positioning 11 Considering only GCF's Bioeconomy Fund geographical eligibility scope. - 7 - products, such as white papers, positioning papers, action plans on matters aligned with the thematic pillar on Bioeconomy, but seeking nexus with other pillars of Amazonia Forever and related sectors, given its cross-sectorial dimension. Expected outputs.

(1) Knowledge products, mainly studies including publications aligned with Amazonia Forever and its Bioeconomy pillar with a focus on sectorial nexus approach; (2) Sectorial positioning or white papers including action plans demonstrating Amazonia Forever's sectorial approach and its link to Bioeconomy; (3) Workshops, dialogues and technical meetings for technical teams of Amazonia Forever partners and networks. Expected results: (1) Strengthened national and regional dialogues and networks of practice through the use and application of high- quality knowledge products related to aligned with Amazonia Forever and Bioeconomy, including the identification of Pre-COP and post-COP30 agendas. 3.2 Component 2. Strategic support for bioeconomy high-level dialogue and networks for decision-making both at the national and sub-national levels (US$450,000).

The objective of this component is to support high-level and regional dialogue to coordinate national policies and regulatory frameworks (not only across countries but also across different sectors), promoting sustainable use of forests and production systems, including value chains, foster technological transfer to encourage sustainable business development, and strengthen financial programs and mechanisms. These dialogues also aim to contribute to the generation of public policies on issues of common interest in Amazonia, rooted in bioeconomy at the regional, national and sub-national levels.

The activities to be financed include: (i) organize regional exchanges and activities with key partners and established networks under Amazonia Forever on strategic themes that foster communities of practice in Amazonia using a sectorial-nexus approach, being them in person and virtual meetings; (ii) organize workshops, technical and high-level meetings and country representatives; (iii) technical support to national and sub-national sectorial entities with a focus on cross-sectorial interventions and integration of natural capital, climate change and bioeconomy in decision-making. Expected outputs: (1) High-level national and regional workshops (Virtual and presential); (2) Technical Seminars with high-level and country representatives (Virtual and presential); (3) Reports capturing policy and thematic agendas pre-/post COP 30.

Expected results (1) A better articulated vision among high-level stakeholders and country representatives through the identification of new policy and thematic agendas to support countries in the implementation of climate and nature-related agreements and decisions. 3.3 Component 3. Actions for the coordinated mobilization of innovative finance for the sustainability of the bioeconomy regional/sectoral networks in Amazonia (US$400,000). This component will support the facilitation of actions for the coordinated mobilization of sectorial and innovative finance opportunities to increase the flow of funds to bio-businesses in the bioeconomy of the Amazon region, as well as for supporting means of implementation and the sustainability of the regional networks.

The activities to be financed include: (i) Technical analysis for a funding to close the finance-impact gap; (ii) Technical support to implement COP30 agreements (iii) Technical studies and diagnostics to assess the viability of financial instruments for fostering sectorial nexus themes and networks; (iv) Organize activities and regional exchanges and dialogues for coordinated mobilization of innovative finance. Expected outputs. (1) At least one technical study to assess the viability of financial instruments to increase the flow of funds to bio-businesses; (2) A technical proposal - 8 - including sector-specific analyses to unlock international climate finance access to promote the bioeconomy; (3) Regional/sectoral seminars and events in the framework of COP30 for better coordinated mobilization of innovative finance. Expected results: (1) Unlock international climate funding to increase the flow of funds to bio-businesses, sectorial and innovative finance opportunities.

Overall, the basis for the sustainability strategy of this TC lies in the strengthened operational regional and sectoral networks under Amazonia Forever, closing knowledge and evidence gaps, which will foster strategic dialogue and decision making at national and subnational levels and by mobilizing innovative financing for the Bioeconomy in Amazonia. 3.5. 5.1 No major risks are expected for the execution of this technical cooperation, but certain risks were identified. First, there is an operational risk, considering the diversity of actors, activities, and the number of participating countries. The risk will be mitigated through close coordination between ACU, and the different countries and sectors involved and by working closely with strategic regional partners. The coordination risk will be mitigated by ensuring close coordination between the project team and the different sector teams in VPS, and with VPC. 5.2A second risk is the relevance of products for policy dialogue and decision making. The risk will be mitigated by dedicated efforts in dissemination and engagement of relevant stakeholders during preparation as well as after completion of activities, both in national and regional levels.

This mitigation measure will also include the systematization and documentation derived from the activities under each component. 5.3A third and final risk identified relates to temporal challenges due to COP30 taking place in the last quarter of 2025 and some knowledge products aiming this milestone. This hard deadline poses additional temporal limitations to accomplish products on time. A mitigation measure will be to design implementation timelines that follow COP30 preparatory schedule, with the adequate and prompt communication to all individuals and firms to be procured for the implementation of the different activities. Important to note that COP30 is an important milestone but shall not be considered as an end game in the context of this TC. The risk is mentioned since COP30 will be instrumental for many of the sectoral tracks that Amazonia Forever supports.
Additionally, there is a risk related to having to adapt any of the activities plan as a result of the outcome of COP30.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: 2.1 Empowering Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) is essential for a successful green transition in Latin America and the Caribbean (LAC). The emergence of the green growth paradigm has highlighted the critical link between economic and environmental performance in business. Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs) in LAC represent 99.5% of all businesses in the region and account for 61.1% of employment, yet they contribute only 24.6% of total productivity1. While each MSME generates relatively low greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions individually, their collective environmental impact is significant accounting for over 13% of global energy consumption. The objective of this TC is to enhance the capacities of policymakers in 1 International Energy Agency (2015). Policy Pathway - Accelerating Energy Efficiency in Small and Medium-sized Enterprises. IEA, Paris.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: - 2 - Brazil and Colombia to design and implement strategies that promote the green transition and climate resilience of SMEs, through the assessment of current practices, international benchmarking, and targeted policy recommendations in areas such as green innovation, skills, technologies, energy efficiency, and entrepreneurship. 2.2 According to the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD), SMEs contributed between 60% and 70% of industrial sector GHG emissions. Similarly, recent UK studies indicate that SMEs are responsible for 43% to 53% of the country's industrial emissions2. Despite 60% of SMEs being familiar with key net-zero concepts, 53% are not yet prepared to prioritize decarbonization in their operations, and 56% have taken no action at all. Only 3% of surveyed SMEs have measured their carbon footprint and developed emission reduction strategies3.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: 2.3 At the same time, SMEs in LAC face high vulnerability to climate change. Their limited adaptive capacity, resource constraints, and exposure to extreme weather events pose serious challenges. Many operate in climate-sensitive sectors such as agriculture, tourism, and manufacturing, making them especially susceptible to droughts, floods, and hurricanes. Unlike larger firms, SMEs often lack financial buffers, technical know-how, and institutional support to invest in resilience measures or adopt more sustainable business models. In addition, supply chain disruptions, infrastructure damage, and volatile energy costs further jeopardize their stability-often resulting in reduced productivity, higher operating costs, or even permanent closure. 2.4 In the case of Colombia, the country has made ambitious commitments, including reducing its GHG emissions by 51% by 2030, and achieving carbon neutrality by 20504.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: Although the country accounted for only 0.32% of global energy consumption in 2020 and reported a per capita energy use of 36 GJ and emissions of 1.85 tons of CO‚ÇÇ per inhabitant in 2021, it faces major challenges. The industrial sector, responsible for 22% of final energy consumption, uses energy efficiently in only 31% of its processes. The 2021 Climate Action Law established a legal framework with 237 goals at national, subnational, and business levels, including achieving net-zero deforestation and reducing black carbon emissions by 40% by 20305. However, GHG emissions have increased since 2000, mainly from land use and energy consumption. Without adequate investment in adaptation, the national GDP could fall by 1.5% to 2.5% by 2050.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: Moreover, over 50% of Colombia's exports depend on fossil fuels- mainly oil and coal-putting up to 10% of export revenues and 8% of GDP at risk in a global low-carbon transition6. 2.5 Considering this, SMEs, which make up 99.7% of the country's business fabric, are key to the green transition, yet they face significant gaps. Fewer than 3% have measured their carbon footprint, and over 50% are not prepared to prioritize decarbonization. The green finance market remains small: in 2023, only 10 green bonds and 5 sustainability bonds were issued, and green loans made up just 5% of 2 OECD (2021). (2023).

While progress has been made, such as Colombia's first local green bond in 2021, and the adoption of a national green taxonomy in 2022, green businesses still face limited domestic demand, export barriers, and restricted access to finance. This is compounded by the local financial sector's low risk appetite, especially toward small firms that often operate with survival rather than growth models8.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: 2.6 In the case of Brazil, the country holds a strategic position to lead in the global green economy, leveraging its abundant natural resources, renewable energy capacity, and emerging low-carbon industries. The industrial sector plays a central role in this transition, particularly SMEs, which represent most of firms and employment in the country. A coordinated green transition could add up to USD 100 billion to GDP and generate 6.4 million new jobs by 2030 through the expansion of sustainable exports, such as green pig iron, bioproducts, and low-carbon technologies. At the same time, Brazil's bioeconomy could reach an annual value of USD 284 billion by 2050 if the country strengthens the integration of its SMEs into global green value chains9.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: 2.7 From this standpoint, energy efficiency emerges as one of the most cost-effective and impactful levers for greening the industrial sector, especially among SMEs, which often operate with aging infrastructure and limited access to technical assistance or financing. The industrial sector consumes 32.3% of Brazil's final energy and 37.3% of electricity, with thermal energy accounting for 80% of industrial energy use. Despite these high levels of consumption, most companies have not yet adopted available efficient solutions such as cogeneration systems, high-temperature heat pumps, waste heat recovery technologies, and insulation improvements. Increasing awareness and supporting the adoption of these technologies can significantly reduce energy costs, improve productivity, and contribute to a more competitive and sustainable industrial base10.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: 2.8 In this context, public policies play a critical role in enabling the green transition of SMEs, particularly by addressing barriers these firms face in adopting sustainable practices. Across OECD countries, governments are actively supporting this process by designing environmental regulations tailored to the realities of smaller enterprises, and by promoting measures that help them improve energy efficiency, adopt circular economy models, acquire new green skills, and access sustainable finance. Considering this, a comprehensive assessment of the main challenges and opportunities for SMEs is essential not only to strengthen technical capabilities, enhance access to sustainable markets, and increase green resilience, but also as a key input for designing public policies and instruments that can more effectively promote the green transition of SMEs.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: These efforts are critical to ensuring that SMEs can contribute meaningfully to green goals while improving their productivity and long- term competitiveness. 2.9Results. As a result of this TC, the project will contribute to strengthening the institutional capacities of the governments of Brazil and Colombia by generating additional evidence to inform decision-making processes related to the green 7 Climate Bonds Initiative (2023). chunk_text: The effectiveness of this project will be measured through outcome indicators such as the number of downloads of the SME green transition assessments and the number of citations of the project's findings in official policy documents in both countries. 2.10Beneficiaries. This TC will directly benefit policy-making institutions in LAC, particularly in Colombia and Brazil that are responsible for industrial development, innovation, and SME support. In Colombia, key institutions include the Ministry of Commerce, Industry and Tourism, The National Planning Department, The Ministry of Science, Technology and Innovation, and iNNpulsa Colombia. chunk_text: In addition to public institutions, the TC will also generate indirect benefits for a broad range of private sector actors, including micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises, business associations, chambers of commerce, industry federations, among others. 2.11Strategic Alignment. The TC aligns with the IDB Group's Institutional Strategy (CA- 631) 2024-2030: Transforming for Scale and Impact; specifically, its objective of Bolstering Sustainable Regional Growth by generating knowledge and policy recommendations for stimulating SMEs green transition as a channel to foster firm investment, innovation and competitiveness. Also, aligns with the operational focus areas of: (i) Productive Development and Innovation through the private sector; (ii) Institutional capacity, Rule of Law and Citizen Security; and (iii) Biodiversity, Natural Capital and Climate Action.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: Furthermore, the TC contributes to the strategic priorities: (i) IDB CLIMA, as it aims at strengthening knowledge and stimulating SME green transition, contributing to demonstrate climate action toward national commitments; and (ii) COP-30, by developing policy recommendations to promote SME decarbonization and climate-resilient actions, aligned with the NDCs that beneficiary countries will present at COP-30. Also aligns with the Innovation, Science, and Technology Sector Framework (GN-2791-13), particularly Action Lines 5 of strengthening key institutions to drive innovation, and 6 of knowledge agenda, by enhancing institutional capacity to design and implement policies that support SME decarbonization and climate resilience through the generation and use of novel data.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: Therefore, this TC supports the Climate Change Sector Framework (GN-2835-13), contributing to Action Line 1 of adaptation and climate resilience, and Action Line 2 of rapid decarbonization, by fostering an enabling environment tailored to SMEs that promotes their green transition and improve competitiveness through targeted adaptation and mitigation measures.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: The TC is aligned with key strategic pillars of the Country Strategy of Brazil with the IDB Group (GN-3243-3) 2024-2027; by the support of green transition and climate resilience of SMEs, and by identifying key barriers and best practices, fostering sustainable business models, and enabling policy instruments that promote productive investments and long-term competitiveness. Also, aligns with the Country Strategy of Colombia with the IDB Group (GN-3238-3) 2024-2027; by the contribution to higher productivity and growth, supporting climate action and biodiversity protection, enhancing financial inclusion and business innovation, and advancing in the integration into global value chains and decarbonization of energy and transport sectors. Overall, it strengthens institutional frameworks and policy action toward a low-carbon economy, improving resource allocation, economic competitiveness, and climate resilience.

3.1 The project will coordinate with several other IDBG efforts and initiatives both at regional and at national level. In particular, at regional level, it will complement the activities of: (i) ATN/OC-19612-RG aimed at improving LAC policymakers' capacities to design and monitor strategies for SME decarbonization and climate resilience through the design, application, analysis, and dissemination of the results of a survey on SMEs decarbonization transition and climate resilience readiness; (ii) ATN/OC- 20099-RG aimed to strengthen institutional capacities to guide carbon-intensive industrial sectors and their value chains toward net-zero emissions and resilience by 2050, through the development of transition roadmaps and tools to support the adoption of current and emerging climate technologies. In Colombia, the project is complementary to the ongoing TC agenda that support the country's green growth.

It includes ATN/SX-19191-CO to support businesses in developing climate mitigation and adaptation plans, and ATN/OC-18845-CO, to contribute to the update of the National Green Business Plan 2022-2030 led by the Ministry of Environment. It will also inform the operational program related to SME financing, including 5796/OC-CO, a US$77 million program to promote long-term productive investments for environmental sustainability. And 5169/TC-CO which channels US$16 million into credit lines for energy efficiency. Additionally, it is connected to IDB Lab TC of Tángara Investment Readiness (still in certification status CO-T1801), which aims to accelerate access to financing for 40-50 climatech and decarbonization-oriented SMEs. 3.2 In Brazil, this TC complements the policy-based loan 6001/OC-BR - Institutional Reforms for Competitiveness and Improvement of the Business Environment, particularly Component 3: Promoting a business environment conducive to innovation, inclusion, and sustainability.

This component includes the approval of the Industrial Sector Mitigation Plan (part of the Climate Plan 2024-2035), the creation of the Sello Verde Brasil Program to foster the green economy and boost sustainable consumption, and the launch of an updated Monitor de Inversiones - Innovación y Sostenibilidad platform, which integrates subnational infrastructure projects and provides tools for climate risk and resilience analysis. These policy measures support broader efforts to strengthen the enabling environment for SME greening and sustainable industrial transformation.

- 6 - 4.1Component 1. SME Green Transition assessments (US$240,000). This component will support the research and development of a comprehensive assessment of the potential for green transition of SMEs in Brazil and Colombia, analyzing the environmental performance, capabilities, and readiness of SMEs to adopt sustainable practices. It will comprise: (i) two in-country information-gathering missions (one in each country) with key governmental and non-governmental stakeholders involved in the SME green transition, aimed at fostering open dialogue around the main challenges, opportunities, and policy options to support SMEs in this process; (ii) two diagnostic reports compiling primary and secondary data collected in each country, including the identification of the key barriers, opportunities, and policy gaps related to SME decarbonization and climate resilience; and (iii) two action plans (one per country) outlining priority policy measures to accelerate the green transition of SMEs11.

4.2 The activities of this component will be carried out in close collaboration with the Centre for Entrepreneurship, SMEs, Regions and Cities (CFE) of the OECD. The OECD has internationally recognized expertise and leadership in the development of evidence-based policies to support the green transition and climate resilience of SMEs. Its work - grounded in rigorous analysis, robust data generation - has allowed the formulation of targeted policy recommendations that inform and strengthen government strategies of its member and partner countries.

Among other key initiatives in the area, the CFE has developed key tools such as the Pilot Dashboard of SME Greening and Green Entrepreneurship Indicators12, which addresses critical information gaps on SMEs' environmental performance, and it leads the Platform on Financing SMEs for Sustainability, a global initiative that facilitates the design and dissemination of financial instruments and good practices to promote green entrepreneurship. 4.3Component 2. 5.1 The Bank will execute this TC through the Competitiveness, Technology and Innovation Division (PTI/CTI). CTI's experience in green innovation, green technologies, SME policy, and green entrepreneurship in the region will play a catalyzing role in the success of this TC, and as a request from the beneficiaries. Considering that this is Regional TC, as per the OP-619-4, Annex II, C 2.2, the Bank is the proposed EA. Execution by the Bank will ensure effective coordination between the activities in the two countries, stakeholders involved, and centralization of efforts and knowledge. Therefore, PTI/CTI will guarantee the quality and timeliness of the financed products, according to section 4.5 of the Bank's Technical Cooperation Guidelines (GN-2470-2).

This section requires that for Bank executed technical cooperation: (a) the beneficiary country agrees and (b) the proposed activities are aligned with the strategies and programs of the Bank in the Country. 5.2 The activities to be carried out under this operation have been included in the Procurement Plan and will be executed in accordance with the Bank's established procurement methods, namely: (i) Corporate procurement of individual consultants, as set forth in Section AM-650 of the Administrative Manual "Complementary Workforce" for individual consultants; and (ii) contracting of consulting firms for services of an intellectual nature, as well as logistical and other non-consulting services, in accordance with the IDB's Corporate Procurement Policy (GN-2303-33) and its associated guidelines.

In accordance with these regulations, the unique combination of technical expertise, innovative policy tools, and active engagement with policymakers positions the OECD as a uniquely qualified partner for the assessments. 5.3 The CTI Division (PTI/CTI) will be responsible for the supervision, monitoring, and evaluation of this TC, in close coordination with the Bank's Country Offices in Brazil and Colombia. Monitoring activities will include regular follow-up meetings with executing entities and stakeholders, review of interim deliverables, and the use of output and outcome indicators defined in the Results Matrix. The final evaluation will synthesize lessons learned and inform future operations, in alignment with the Bank's results-oriented approach and TC guidelines.

6.1 The first risk identified is the limited access to information in both countries, as the quality of the diagnostics will largely depend on the availability and reliability of existing data. To mitigate this risk, it is proposed to complement secondary data with primary inputs such as surveys and interviews. Additionally, with the support of local consultants, it will be essential to engage key local actors, such as think tanks and business associations, that can contribute additional data and facilitate access to relevant information. 6.2 The second risk is related to the level of engagement of public and private stakeholders, which could affect both the sense of ownership over the diagnostics and the action plans. To address this, the TC aims to foster early and sustained involvement of key actors from both sectors, starting from the planning phase through implementation.

This includes identifying focal points within relevant institutions and establishing follow-up mechanisms. It is important that stakeholders are not only recipients of the deliverables but are actively engaged as partners throughout the process. 6.3 The third risk is the potential impact of the 2026 electoral cycle in Colombia and Brazil, which could lead to shifts in institutional priorities and leadership. These dynamics, along with varying levels of institutional capacity, may influence the continuity of stakeholder engagement. To help mitigate these risks, the TC will prioritize early and sustained engagement with key counterparts, support institutional capacity-building, and ensure that outputs are closely aligned with national long-term strategies, thus contributing to the sustainability of results.

chunk_text: -ii- PROJECT SUMMARY (TT-T1172 ) Micro, small, and medium enterprises (MSMEs) significantly contribute to GDP and employment in Trinidad and Tobago, yet face barriers such as limited mentorship, networking opportunities, and targeted skills development. These challenges hinder founders' a bility to scale their businesses and contribute to regional economic growth and innovation. The Ignite the World project aims to reduce barriers related to mentorship, networking, and skills development for founders in Trinidad and Tobago. The project will engage participants annually, focusing on innovative business models in sectors such as Fin Tech, HealthTech, AgriTech, and ClimateTech. Activities include mentorship, networking events, mini -MBA courses, startup weekends, and workshops for high school and university students from marginalized backgrounds.

chunk_text: Ignite the World is innovative due to its deep stakeholder engagement through ethnographic interviews and community co -creation sessions, ensuring relevance to the Caribbean context. It prioritizes foundational business skills and business model developmen t for highly innovative start-ups and fosters regional collaboration. The primary expected results include engaging 500 unique founders, 40% of whom are women, accelerating 50 founders/startups, and launching a mini -MBA program with 150 enrolled participants. The project has a total cost of US$ 600,300 , of which US$ 300,000 (49.98 %) will be a non - reimbursable technical cooperation grant provided by IDB Lab with resources from the European Commission and Restarted Framework Agreement (ECR) , and US$ 300,300 (50.02 %) in counterpart by the Executing Agency . The project aligns with the IDB Group's institutional strategy, supporting private sector innovation and gender equality.

chunk_text: A. Problem Description 1.1. The contribution of micro and small businesses to GDP and employment in Latin America and the Caribbean is well documented. According to the Caribbean Development Bank (CDB) , in 2021 micro, small and medium enterprises (MSME) in the Caribbean region account for 70-85% of firms, contribute between 60 -70% of Gross Domestic Product (GDP) and account for an estimated 50% of employment . The CDB estimated that 40% of these businesses are owned by women .1 2In Trinidad and Tobago, the International Labor Organization (ILO) published a 2023 study which cited Central Bank of Trinidad and Tobago data that there are approximately 20,000 -25,000 small and medium enterprises (SME) representing about 85% of formal businesses and contributing an estimated 30% to GDP .3 1.2.
pdf_file: TT-T1172 Approval Document Memo public version.pdf

chunk_text: In terms of contribution to poverty reduction, the United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs (UNDESA )'s publication "MSMEs and their role in achieving the Sustainable Development Goals "4 examines the role of MSMEs to each of the SDGs. The report unpacks the role of MSMEs in economic activity, in creating employment and incomes, particularly for the poor and marginalized groups, as service providers (for example in education, health, water and sanitation) and examines the private sector led contributions of MSMEs globally to achievement of SDGs including contributing significantly to poverty reduction via employment. 1.3.
pdf_file: TT-T1172 Approval Document Memo public version.pdf

chunk_text: A growing MSME sector is critical to the growth and development of Tri nidad and Tobago and the wider region, however founders encounter significant barriers that hinder their ability to establish and scale their businesses, including limited mentorship and networking opportunities, and the need for targeted skills development .5 These challenges can impede founders' ability to grow their business and to contribute to economic growth and innovation in the region . 1.4. Whereas Caribbean economies have historically relied on traditional industries like agriculture, tourism, and natural resources, there has been a significant shift towards diversified economic activities in recent years, with a growing emphasis on digital technologies and innovative business models. Digital technology has been a game - changer for Caribbean entrepreneurs.
pdf_file: TT-T1172 Approval Document Memo public version.pdf

chunk_text: With the proliferation of mobile devices and internet 1 https://www.investincaribbean.org/news -center/news/p/item/37115/supporting -micro -small -and-medium -enterprises - the-backbone -of-caribbean - economies#:~:text=According%20to%20the%20Caribbean%20Development,estimated%2050%25%20of%20total %20employment . 2 https://www.caribank.org/newsroom/news -and-events/msme -sectors -big-impact -economies 3https://www.ilo.org/sites/default/files/wcmsp5/groups/public/%40americas/%40ro -lima/%40sro - port_of_spain/documents/publication/wcms_883104.pdf 4 https://sdgs.un.org/sites/default/files/2020 -07/MSMEs_and_SDGs.pdf 5 Between 1Q and 2Q 2024, Caribbean Dragons undertook an extensive primary study to map the Innovation ecosystem in Trinidad. In a series of interviews, group discussions and surveys, data was collected from 123 participants to identify challenges, opportun ities and needs of Founders and Entrepreneurs within the island. 2 connectivity, even remote islands now have access to global markets. This connectivity has enabled the rise of startups in various sectors, including fintech, agritech, healthtech, and edtech. These startups address local problems and create solutions with global applicability6. 1.5.
pdf_file: TT-T1172 Approval Document Memo public version.pdf

chunk_text: With the acceleration of technology driven b usinesses, there are now greater opportunities and activities for tech led businesses to develop models and value propositions to solve problems that disproportionately affect lower income populations, specifically in areas such as financial inclusion, heath technologies, climate adaptation, climate smart agriculture and citizen security. These types of businesses typically find access to finance and support more difficult, in part as they are not based on a typical asset basis. In this regard these types of inclusive business models struggle to secure support for growth.7 1.6. Supporting a new generation of founders and fostering the growth of the MSME sector involves developing and deploying founder -centric, cost -effective, practical, and sustainable solutions to overcome key barriers that hinder their ability to establish and scale businesses. This is a critical component of the business ecosystem.
pdf_file: TT-T1172 Approval Document Memo public version.pdf

chunk_text: Caribbean Dragons, through ongoing engagement with ecosystem actors and start -ups identifies the most pressing problems / needs as defined by founders as follows: • Challenges with starting up and scaling a new business : It can be difficult for aspiring entrepreneurs to successfully navigate the administration and legal requirements of registering their business. Respondents8 cited a l ack of experience and knowledge in how to establish and scale businesses that are not based on typical asset bases : Start Ups , particularly those that are tech -focused, express a need for increased knowledge support in specialized areas such as early -stage financing, product development, market growth strategies, and management of intellectual properly . • Limited Networking Opportunities : Founders need and value community, especially start -ups.
pdf_file: TT-T1172 Approval Document Memo public version.pdf

chunk_text: There is a clear demand for more events, seminars, and introductions to key players within specific ecosystems to help entrepreneurs grow their personal networks and connect with potential partners. Respondents indicated a need for entrepreneurial support and exposure. Entrepreneurs are looking for more visibility for their ventures, including the development of a directory of skills and resources to present their work to a broader audience. • Mentorship for Innovation and Market Understanding : Entrepreneurs seek mentorship to better understand market needs and implement innovative ideas, favoring collaborative learning environments for exchanging insights. 6 Innovating in the Caribbean: The Evolution and Impact of Start Ups in the CARICOM region: July 2024 7 Between 1Q and 2Q 2024, Caribbean Dragons undertook an extensive primary study to map the Innovation ecosystem in Trinidad.

In a series of interviews, group discussions and surveys, data was collected from 123 participants to identify challenges, opportun ities and needs of Founders and Entrepreneurs within the island. 3 • Professional Development and Coaching: There is a significant need for guidance and one -on-one coaching in various startup specific skills such as: non - traditional/alternate forms of early -stage financing (e.g. crowdfunding, angel investing, and venture capital), customer need identification, market segmentation for emerging technologies, technical knowledge (e.g. cod ing and U/X design), growth hacking, regulatory compliance (e.g.

Project Beneficiaries: The project aims to engage 500 participants during the execution term in its core service delivery . These will be Founders , primarily in Trinidad and Tobago (TT), that are seeking to accel erate growth of an innovative business. In the context of this project, innovation will be represented by a business which is disrupting its industry vertically by either (a) offering a new product or service , (b) using new technologies , (c) leveraging a new /novel business operational model , or (d) entering a new market ; and that has an identifiable path to scalability. Companies focused on fossil fuel exploration and production will be excluded .

chunk_text: Within this group , 10% of beneficiary founders will be leading disruptive technology - driven business models that can impact / provide viable solutions to low income, poor / vulnerable segments of the population(s) they aim to serve. These firm s will be selected based on fintech and health tech providers and /or other businesses , that are primarily focused on delivering value for low-income population segments of the market . In addition to building capacity of 500 businesses in Trinidad and Tobago, with 40% of these (200) being women and 10% or 50 leading b usinesses that primarily target low income/vulnerable market segments, in order to encourage innovation in the next generation, Caribbean Drago ns will deliver training to the project intervention will offer a series of interactive workshops on innovation for 200 high sc hool students . 1.8.

chunk_text: Gender Equity : Although women in in Latin America and Caribbean make up 43.1% of entrepreneurs operating in export -oriented businesses9, the global participation average for women in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) spaces is 13.2% as of 202310. Based on Caribbean Dragons experience in the ecosystem and its 2024 study, the rate of participation/leadership of women in STEM enterprises in TT is even lower than the global average with less than 10% of technology founders interviewed being women (out of 123 technology founders participating in the study ).
pdf_file: TT-T1172 Approval Document Memo public version.pdf

chunk_text: As such , the project is seeking to deliver support to female technology business founders as a specific and under -represented segment and has set a target of least 40% of benefic iaries being (a) women who have founded technology -led or technology -assisted businesses, (b) women who are working for technology -led or technology -assisted businesses as managers, (c) women who are working in traditional businesses but in technology disciplines (e.g. Information Technology teams) or (d) female leaders and managers of traditional busine sses/sectors . 9 Global Entrepreneurship Monitor (GEM) 2022/2023 Women's Entrepreneurship Report - "Challenging Bias and Stereotypes" (Nov 2023) 10 Carta - Gender Gap Among Startup Founders (analysis of 2018 -2023 data, published Jan 17, 2024 4 1.9. To achieve this, the project will take a two -fold approach of recruiting and content development.

chunk_text: For recruiting efforts, the team will source participants by working with existing IDB Lab ecosystem programs, such as Sh aping the Future of Innovation, as well as several Trinidad -based organizations that focus on female professional engagement, including but not limited to : The Women in Tech Network of Trinidad and Tobago, Women Techmakers Trinidad and Tobago, Caribbean Tech Women, The SheTrades Hub run out of the Ministry of Trade and Industry, The Association of Female Executives of Trinidad and Tobago, The Women in Busin ess Association of Trinidad and Tobago, The International Women's Forum of Trinidad and Tobago, and Th e Caribbean Women's Network.

chunk_text: Customized outreach material will be developed and disseminated via partners and recommended channels to actively encourage these women to participate, by clearly defining the importance placed on women business leadership and the value proposition for female participants . 1.10. With respect to content development , the team will engage with expert organizations that have extensive experience in understanding and address ing female challenges within STEM and entrepreneurship such as : The Center for Gender and the Economy (GATE) at the Rotman School of Management, University of Toronto which focuses on increasing female participation in business, and The Firehood: an established network of women in technology, that builds leadership acumen through specialized training.

chunk_text: Some of the key challenges to be addressed by IGNITE that are particularly relevant on the context of encouraging greater gender parity in STEM and technology businesses include: (1) Gender Bias and Stereotyping, (2) Acce ss to Funding, (3) Networking Opportunities, (4) Work -Life Balance, (5) Representation and Role Models, (6) Cultural and Societal Expectations and (7) Access to Training. 1.11. The participant group is expected to be representative of the country's dominant ethnicities reflecting current d emographics (Afro descendants 34%, East Indian Descendants 35% and Mixed Race 23%) . 1.12. Poor & Vulnerable : The education system in TT is structured in a way where students from low -income and rural backgrounds face systemic disadvantages. Family income and poverty levels strongly influence students' educational outcomes, and socioeconomic status is a significan t predictor of academic performance.
pdf_file: TT-T1172 Approval Document Memo public version.pdf

chunk_text: Children from poorer households lack access to private tutoring, books and supplementary learning support that wealthier families can provide. As such, students from poorer backgrounds are typically placed into lower -tiered schools. 1.13. Secondary schools are ranked from top -tier to lower -tier11. Top -tiered schools are categorized by (1) geographical location within the main cities of the islands (Port of Spain, Chaguanas, San Fernando), (2) are often overseen by a religious board (Catholic, Presbyterian or Hindu), (3) receive more funding from private entities/corporations where alumn i of these schools tend to work and have leadership/decision making positions.

chunk_text: A. Project Description 2.1 Ignite the World seeks to catalyze the support that is needed for accelerated growth and viability of start -ups in the Caribbean, piloting its approach in Trinidad and Tobago which has the Caribbean Region's largest industrial base and an urgent mandate for diversification . The project's main objective is to reduce the barriers related to mentorship , networking opportunities, and skills development that founders in Trinidad and Tobago face when trying to establish and scale their businesses. 2.2 The targeted beneficiaries of this project will be engaged as follows : • Founders : These founders will commit to creating meaningful changes through the application of new technologies, driving innovation in their respective industries.

chunk_text: They will be exposed to networking, learning opportunities and have the option to be matched with experienced international founders within their verticals, to access specialized knowledge not available within T T. Firstly, the program was designed on deep stakeholder engagement through a series of quali tative research methods including deep ethnographic interviews, and community co -creation sessions. This was done to ensure that proposed activities are re levant and fit -for- purpose, as compared to adopting North American and Eu ropean Startup Community frameworks and imposing it to a Caribbean audience. 2.4 Additionally, within the region, there are very few non -profit accelerators that focus on innovation and technology -driven pre -seed companies in the Caribbean.

chunk_text: There is a disproportionate emphasis on supporting more established and traditional companies. 7 Consequently, this project will prioritize foundational business skills and business model development, which are critical for disruptive and highly innovative start -ups. Further , startup programs that exis t in the Caribbean tend to be limited to their country of origin and do not typically collaborate across the wider region. At the core , Caribbean Dragons are ecosystem builders seek ing to connect the region in the hopes of leveraging relational capital to bring cross -geography resources for their founding community in T T.

chunk_text: 2.5 The project is structured to include three technical components as follows : 2.6 Component I: CONNECT - The objective of this component is to c urate and activate a network of individuals engaged as founders or ecosystem players in startup development and growth. The project aims to connect 275 founders within 2 years . Early -stage founders will benefit from guidance provided by seasoned innovators, as well as peer support and access to local talent. By establishing a platform for engagement, Caribbean Dragons will facilitate critical connections through: • IGNITE Innovation Summit: This annual event will convene the key actors in the Regional Innovation Ecosystem and allow stakeholders to overcome geographic and social boundaries, integrate and foster conditions for greater innovation output.
pdf_file: TT-T1172 Approval Document Memo public version.pdf

chunk_text: • Quarterly Community Series: These small pop -up events will facilitate spontaneous connection making and reinforce existing relationships among founders and other ecosystem actors through in -person interactions. • Online Engagement: Caribbean Dragons will create an online community which enables self -directed engagement among members and facilitates data collection and sharing. • Monthly Newsletter: Caribbean Dragons will use this mechanism to share success stories of Innovators and Investors which inspire and educate the community. • Mentorship : This element of the program will match 50 founders with mentors for a total of 8 hours. To be accepted into the mentorship program, founders must complete at least four of the mini-MBA modules , participate in a startup weekend (as defined in Component 2 Learn) , and participate in a Mentorship Onboarding Workshop.
pdf_file: TT-T1172 Approval Document Memo public version.pdf

chunk_text: Mentees will define and agree priority areas for the interactions and both mentors and mentees will operate within guidelines developed by Caribbean Dragons. Mentors will be sourced from the Caribbean Dragons community and will include experienced founders, funders/investors, entrepreneurial hubs, service providers (e.g., coders, marketers, accountants), as well as multilateral agencies a nd organizations. Matching will be done on a skills -needs basis. 2.7 By the end of the project, the expected results are: 10 networking events for founders and ecosystem actors, 40 founders benefiting from startup weekends and 275 active users within the online community . 2.8 Component II: LEARN - The objective of this component is to deliver comprehensive training and experiential learning tailored to accelerate startups .

chunk_text: The key activities are as follows ; • Mini-MBA: Caribbean Dragons will develop a n online mini-MBA program that will offer specialized and target ed micro -learning s that can be applied directly into participants' startups . chunk_text: 2.1Component 1. Governance of the National Statistical System (NSS) (US$30,000). The objective of the component is to strengthen governance and coordination within the NSS by supporting the establishment and operationalization of the National Statistics Committee (NSC) and updating and aligning the National Strategy for the Development of Statistics (NSDS) with the National Development Plan. 2.1.1 The main activities include organizing and facilitating two workshops, structuring and operationalizing the NSC, and providing technical assistance for the update, validation, and approval of the NSDS. These actions will be implemented by the IDB, as executing agency, in coordination with the Bahamas National Statistical Institute (BNSI) and the Ministry of Finance. 2.1.2 Procurement will include the hiring of one individual consultant to organize and facilitate the workshops and one individual to update and align the NSDS, consistent with the Procurement Plan.

2.1.3 The expected outputs of the component are: (i) two workshops organized to strengthen the NSC's coordination capacity; and (ii) one updated and approved NSDS aligned with the National Development Plan, as reflected - 6 -in the Results Matrix. The organization of workshops will be subject to prior non-objection from the KPR Fund Coordinator. 2.2Component 2. Capacity Development (US$40,000). The objective of the component is to strengthen the institutional and human-resource capacities of the BNSI through the design and delivery of a structured training program for senior management and technical staff, focusing on leadership, change management, communication, advocacy, and statistical-quality standards. 2.2.1 The main activity involves designing and implementing two training sessions, both to be delivered during 2027 by specialized trainers in coordination with the BNSI and the Ministry of Finance.

Implementation will take place over approximately eight months, as reflected in the Procurement Plan. 2.2.2 Procurement will include contracting an individual training provider to design and deliver the sessions, in accordance with the Procurement Plan. 2.2.3 The expected output of the component is two training sessions delivered to enhance BNSI's managerial and technical competencies, consistent with the Results Matrix. The organization of training activities will be subject to prior non-objection from the KPR Fund Coordinator. 2.3Component 3. Data integration and monitoring and evaluation (US$80,000). The objective of the component is to enhance data integration, coordination, and modernization of IT systems across the NSS.

2.3.1 The main activities comprise preparing a diagnostic report on current IT and datamanagement systems within the NSS, conducting two technical workshops with data-producing agencies to validate findings and strengthen coordination, and developing a proposal for an integrated IT system to improve interoperability and data exchange among institutions. The IDB, as the executing agency, will coordinate these actions in collaboration with the BNSI. 2.3.2 Procurement will include an individual consultant for the diagnostic report, an individual consultant to facilitate the workshops, and an individual consultant to design the integrated IT system proposal, consistent with the Procurement Plan. 2.3.3 The expected outputs are: (i) one diagnostic report produced; (ii) two workshops organized; and (iii) one IT system proposal designed, aligned with the Results Matrix. The organization of workshops will be subject to prior non-objection from the KPR Fund Coordinator. 2.4Expected Results.

This TC will strengthen the capacity of the Bahamas National Statistics Institute (BNSI) to design and implement the National Strategy for the Development of Statistics (NSDS), providing a coordinating mechanism for the National Statistical System (NSS) that ensures the production and dissemination of quality and timely official statistics. It is expected that the National Statistics Committee will be established, the NSDS will be updated and approved in - 7 -alignment with the National Development Plan, the BNSI's institutional capacity will be reinforced through training and academic partnerships, and a proposal for an integrated IT system will be developed to improve coordination and data integration. As a result, the Government of The Bahamas will have access to better data to design and monitor programs, and the IDB will be able to measure the impact of its operations in the country.

In addition, the TC is expected to strengthen BNSI's institutional leadership within the NSS, enhance stakeholder confidence in the quality and reliability of official data, and increase coordination among government entities producing and using statistics, thereby improving the Government's capacity to design, monitor, and evaluate public policies and development programs based on evidence. 2.5Beneficiaries. The direct beneficiaries of this TC are the Government of The Bahamas through the Bahamas National Statistics Institute (BNSI), which will be strengthened in its institutional capacity and technical resources, and the National Statistics Committee (NSC), including the public entities represented in it such as the Ministry of Finance, the Central Bank, the Ministry of Education, and the Ministry of Health.

The final beneficiaries are government agencies, the private sector, academia, civil society, and the citizens of The Bahamas, who will benefit from more timely, accessible, and high-quality official statistics to support evidence-based policymaking and improved public policies.

3.1Budget. The total cost of this TC is estimated at US$150,000. The project will be financed entirely with non-reimbursable resources from the Korea Poverty Reduction Fund (KPR) administered by the Inter-American Development Bank. No counterpart resources, either in cash or in-kind, are expected for this operation. Budget in US$ Components IDB/KPR Total Component 1. Governance of the National Statistical System (NSS).30,000.00 30,000.00 Component 2. Capacity Development. 40,000.00 40,000.00 Component 3. Data integration and monitoring, and evaluation.80,000.00 80,000.00 Total 150,000.00 150,000.00

4.1 At the request of the Government of The Bahamas, the TC will be executed by the Inter-American Development Bank (IDB), in accordance with the Bank's Technical Cooperation Policy (GN-2470-2) and the Procedures for the Processing of Technical Cooperation Operations and Related Matters (OP-619-4), Annex II, literal c: (i) Institutional Capacity, through the División of Institutional Capacity of the State (IFC/ICS) in coordination with the Caribbean Country Department (CCB) - 8 -and the IDB Country Office in The Bahamas (CBH). This arrangement is justified by the limited institutional and human resource capacity of the Bahamas National Statistics Institute (BNSI) to manage externally financed operations at this stage, and by the Government's interest in ensuring the timely and effective implementation of project activities.

4.2 This execution structure will enable the Bank to provide direct technical and fiduciary supervision, ensure efficient use of resources, and strengthen the institutional capacity of the BNSI through continuous engagement during implementation. 4.3Procurement. All procurement to be executed under this Technical Cooperation have been included in the Procurement Plan (Annex IV) and will be hired in compliance with the applicable Bank policies and regulations as follows: (a) Hiring of individual consultants, as established in the regulation on Complementary Workforce (AM-650) and (b) Contracting of services provided by consulting firms in accordance with the Corporate procurement Policy (GN-2303-33) and its Guidelines. 4.4Execution and Disbursement Period. The execution and disbursement period for this Technical Cooperation will be thirty-six (36) months from the date of approval.

This period includes the implementation of all project activities described in the Results Matrix and the Procurement Plan. 4.5Monitoring, Reporting, and Supervision. Monitoring and supervision of this TC will be the responsibility of IFD/ICS, which will serve as the Sector Division responsible for execution. The operation will be supervised in close coordination with the Caribbean Country Department (CCB) and the IDB Country Office in The Bahamas (CBH), which will act as the local focal point for day-to-day coordination with the beneficiary. 4.6 Project progress will be monitored through periodic technical and financial reviews, including the tracking of activities, milestones, and outputs as specified in the Results Matrix and Procurement Plan. Progress reports will be prepared annually and recorded in the Technical Cooperation Monitoring and Reporting System (TCM) of the Bank.

Supervision costs will be financed with the Bank's own administrative budget in accordance with internal procedures. 4.7 Monitoring and evaluation will be conducted in coordination with the BNSI and the Ministry of Finance. The Bank will be responsible for preparing progress reports and a final report summarizing the main results achieved, in accordance with the Bank's procedures.

5.1 The main potential risks that could affect the successful implementation of this Technical Cooperation are related to institutional capacity, governance, and inter-agency coordination within the National Statistical System (NSS). A key risk is the limited human and institutional capacity of the Bahamas National Statistics Institute (BNSI), which could delay the implementation of activities and the timely - 9 -delivery of outputs. This risk stems from the still-recent establishment of the BNSI as an autonomous entity under the Statistics Act of 2021, and from the ongoing process of staff renewal and capacity strengthening. To mitigate this, the project will be executed directly by the Inter-American Development Bank (IDB), as requested by the Government of The Bahamas, and will include targeted training and technical assistance activities to strengthen BNSI's capacity.

5.2 Another potential risk concerns coordination challenges among data-producing agencies, given that the National Statistics Committee (NSC) is not yet fully operational. Weak coordination could affect the approval and implementation of the National Strategy for the Development of Statistics (NSDS) and limit data sharing and integration. This risk will be mitigated through stakeholder engagement and workshops designed to strengthen governance and promote the NSC's effective functioning. 5.3 Finally, delays in the approval of the NSDS or in the validation of the IT system proposal could affect project timing. To mitigate this, the TC will maintain close coordination with the Ministry of Finance and other key institutions and ensure early involvement of relevant stakeholders in validation processes. 5.4Intellectual Property. No special intellectual property provisions are anticipated under this Technical Cooperation.

All reports, databases, software, and materials produced under the project will be considered public goods and will be owned by the Inter-American Development Bank (IDB), in accordance with the Bank's intellectual property policies and procedures. Integrity clauses will be applied as per standard Bank agreements.
6.1 No exceptions to Bank policies are anticipated under this TC. All activities will be carried out in accordance with the applicable policies and procedures of the IDB.
