section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: 2.1 The objective of this TC is to contribute to improve agricultural productivity and climate resilience of small and medium landholder farmers by promoting climate-smart agricultural practices through digital technologies related to weather and soil management. The activities proposed will be implemented in Bolivia, Peru and Colombia, with a focus on gender and diversity with the goal of identifying the best approaches to scaling up access to these digital services. 2.2 Latin America's diverse topography, ranging from mountains to coastlines, introduces complexities in predicting local weather patterns (WMO, 2022). Seasonal rainfall patterns are variable and further complicated by phenomena such as El Niño and La Niña (Parente de Souza et al, 2021).

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: Climate change will exacerbate this uncertainty, with variation in daily precipitation increasing by 4-5% and temperature variability increasing by 10-15 percent per degree Celsius of warming (Pendergrass et al., 2017; Bathiany et al., 2018), increasing farmers' production risks and affecting agricultural productivity (WMO, 2022). In the context of increased weather variability, better forecasts can benefit farmers through reduced losses, increasing yields and farmer income, particularly if these forecasts are carefully crafted to be relevant to farmers, including women and ethnic groups. 2.3 There is evidence that farmers adapt farming practices and investment decisions in response to weather information. Randomized control trials in Benin and Colombia estimate annual benefits of $103-$356 per farmer ( Yegbemey et al., 2023; Camacho and Conover, 2019). In Ghana, India, and Pakistan, farmers in communities that received forecasts altered their planting and investment behavior.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: 2.4 New technologies, including artificial intelligence (AI), allow for more accurate and location specific weather forecasts to be generated and provided to farmers to help them optimize their agricultural decisions. But the benefits of the AI revolution in weather forecasting are yet to be experienced in LAC. Much of the focus of the AI developments in forecasting has been on commercial applications in wealthy countries or technological demonstrations by major technology corporations. Forecasts produced in many LAC countries, typically by national meteorological services are often at an unsuitable time scale or cover too broad of a geographic region to inform farmers' management decisions. AI-based weather forecasting models can generate accurate short- and medium-term forecasts at fine spatial and temporal scales and can be optimized to provide the information that is most important for farmer decision- making.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: These forecasts can be produced more quickly and cheaply than traditional forecasts since they require less computational power. 2.5 Farmers need access to soil health and land management information to counter the growing effects of soil erosion, degradation, and salinity. Latin America faces multifaceted challenges related to soil health. First, soil erosion, driven by deforestation, improper land management, and intense rainfall events leads to the depletion of crucial topsoil, diminishing fertility and affecting yields (WMO, 2022). Second, the excessive use of fertilizers contributes to soil degradation (FAO, 2019). Third, soil salinity is a significant challenge in arid and semi-arid regions, where high salt concentrations can impede plant growth and limit agricultural productivity (FAO, 2021).

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: Poor water management practices, such as inefficient irrigation systems and inadequate drainage, exacerbate issues related to soil health and compromise overall - 4 - soil health negatively affecting yields (FAO, 2021). Effective soil health management can contribute to climate change mitigation efforts and help farmers overcome climate challenges thereby enhancing resilience, yields and income, and minimize environmental and climate consequences of current agricultural practices (FAO 2015, Qiao et al 2022). 2.6 Digitally delivered services, including weather forecasts and soil health data, could have significant benefits for farmers in the context of climate change. These services have very low marginal costs when operated at scale since once a digital services system is set up the cost of an additional user is minimal. This makes digital services highly cost-effective (Fabregas et al. 2019; Cole and Fernando 2020).

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: Many governments are already providing digital services to farmers, as are the private sector and non-governmental organizations. However, current efforts are highly fragmented within and across countries and there is significant scope to improve and expand digital services for agriculture. Since weather and soil health information are very relevant for farmers, these are good starting points to build and evaluate digital platforms. Once the basic elements of these platforms are built, there is the potential to dynamically expand them in terms of thematic coverage, types of users, and number and types of service providers.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: 2.7 The focus of this TC will be on three countries in the region: Bolivia, Peru and Colombia because of: (i) their proximity to the weather patterns of the Pacific Ocean, which will be the focus of the weather predictions; (ii) the presence of viable extension systems in which digitally provided weather and soil information will complement the existing extension efforts; and (iii) the relevance of digital agricultural services and improved weather and soil recommendations to strengthen food security and the IDB operational portfolio in these countries.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: 2.8 The specific objectives are (i) to assess farmers' technical assistance needs and digital agriculture extension readiness in Bolivia, Peru and Colombia, in particular as they relate to weather and soil health, with a gender and diversity approach; (ii) to assess weather forecasting capacities, soil health data generation and use capacities in the three countries; (iii) to design pilots that include digital solutions and tailored farmer- centered information products around weather forecasts and soil management in the three countries with a gender and diversity approach; (iv) to strengthen local capacities to produce and disseminate farmer-centered forecasts and soil health information; and (vi) to implement and evaluate the pilots designed in order to test different approaches of digital agricultural extension service provision focused on weather and soil health.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: A GDI specialist will be included as part of the team and consulted during the execution of this TC. 2.9 The activities to be implemented will benefit from the experience and ongoing work led by a broader farmer-focused weather initiative promoted by the Innovation Commission for Climate Change, Food Security and Agriculture (IC), chaired by Nobel-laureate Michael Kremer, and the Agricultural Innovation Mechanisms for Scale (AIM4Scale) launched at COP28. 2.10 The TC is consistent with the Bank's Institutional Strategy, Transforming for Scale and Impact (CA-631), which provides a roadmap for 2024-2030. The TC focuses on scaling weather and soil information through digital services to enhance results in the Institutional Strategy's goal areas of reducing poverty and inequality and addressing - 5 - climate change among small-scale producers in LAC.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: It will incorporate cross-cutting issues around climate action, gender equality and inclusion, institutional capacity and productive development, and innovation through the private sector. The operation is aligned with the IDB Group's Country Strategy for Bolivia 2022-2025 (GN-3088) through its strategic objective of contributing to improving the productivity of selected sectors of the economy; and through the cross-cutting area of institutional capacity building, and it will contribute to the outcome of boosting family farming productivity. It is also aligned with the IDB Group's Country Strategy for Colombia 2024-2027 (GN- 3238-3) through its strategic areas focused on i) enhancing productivity and economic growth, and ii) increasing social and territorial inclusion (in particular, the strategic objective of promoting the inclusion of diverse groups such as women, indigenous and afro descendants).

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: Similarly, the operation is aligned with the IDB Group's Country Strategy for Peru 2022-2026 (GN-3110-1) particularly with the strategic objective of improving agro-industrial productivity and strengthening environmental management with a focus on sustainability and climate change, and through the strategic areas of productive development and environmental sustainability and climate change. 2.11 The TC is also consistent with the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. The TC is also aligned with the following Sector Framework documents: Agriculture (GN-2709- 16), Food Security (GN-2825-8), Climate Change (GN-2835-8), Gender and Diversity (GN-2800-13). 2.12 The objective and activities of this TC align with those of MAG's logic model. Specifically, this TC is aligned with MAG's intermediate outcomes 1200 and 1300.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: Alignment with the intermediate outcome of Increased Sustainable and Climate Resilient Productivity of Targeted Women and Men Farmers in LAC (1200) is achieved by assessing and strengthening the capacity of small and medium landholders to implement climate-smart agricultural practices (with a focus on women and ethnic populations), in order to increase agricultural productivity and climate resilience. Alignment with the intermediate outcome of Improved sustainable and gender- responsive natural resource management by targeted governments and farmers in LAC (1300) is achieved by increasing access to good practices related to soil management for climate resilience. 2.13 This TC is aligned with the immediate outcomes: 1210. Increased capacity of women and men farmers to implement sustainable agricultural practices including climate- smart agriculture; 1220. Strengthened capacity of governments, private sector and academic institutions to provide gender-responsive, climate-smart agricultural services; and 1320.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: Increased access to good practices related to land use planning sensitive to climate change and gender equality for public and private sectors. 2.14 The TC funds will be allocated to contribute to MAG's outputs: 1212. Agricultural services (applied research and extension, agricultural health and food safety, agricultural information, risk management, use of technology, income diversification activities, etc.) provided to targeted farmers. Support provided to government, private sector and/or tertiary agricultural service providers to design and deliver agricultural services (applied research and extension, agricultural innovation, agricultural health and food safety, agricultural information, risk management, use of technology, etc.) for farmers and agribusiness actors; 1221.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: Support provided to government, private sector and/or tertiary agricultural service providers to design and deliver agricultural services (applied research and extension, agricultural innovation, agricultural health - 6 - and food safety, agricultural information, risk management, use of technology, etc.) for farmers and agribusiness actors; 1313. Assessment of targeted current agricultural policies conducted to inform sustainable and/or climate-smart agricultural policy- making; and 1323. Capacity building for women and men on sustainable land management practices.

3.1Component I: Country assessment of technical assistance needs and digital readiness with a gender and diversity approach (US$130,000). This component aims to analyze small and medium landholder farmers' main needs in terms of weather and soil health information and asses the current capacity and needs of agricultural extension services to support farmers on these topics, with a focus on women and ethnic communities.

For this, the component will finance background research, focus groups and expert interviews in each country to elaborate: (i) an assessment of farmer priorities, including main crops and animals raised, input use, irrigation systems, etc., to identify the most valuable weather and soil information; (ii) an appraisal of agricultural extension services from the public and private sector to determine the reach and effectiveness of such systems in each country, including an assessment of governments' digital agriculture priorities to determine if/where digital agricultural tools and systems fit; (iii) a mapping of ongoing programs and projects (including IDB's) that aim to modernize agricultural extension through the use of digital tools, with a focus on the provision of weather and soil-related recommendations for farmers, iii) an assessment of farmers' and extensionists' access to mobile technologies and connectivity, considering farmers typology by land size and age, indigenous populations, afro-descendants and gender, (iv) a mapping of available databases with farmer contacts, georeferenced location, and other relevant characteristics, and (v) a proposal of local value chains to prioritize as part of the pilots to be implemented, with a solid justification.

3.2Component II: Country assessment of weather forecasting and soil data management capacities with a gender and diversity approach (US$90,000). This component aims to assess local government capacity for generating accurate and timely weather forecasts and soil health management recommendations, as well as the degree of digital readiness available to digitally provide weather and soil management information to small and medium landholder farmers at the country level. For this, the component will finance background research, focus groups, expert interviews and the application of relevant assessment tools (e.g.

from the World Meteorological Organization, WMO) in each country to: (i) assess weather forecasting capacities (including the use of AI), potential gaps in existing forecasting systems, in particular for weather risks that are relevant for the agriculture sector in the country; (ii) assess the existing data on soil quality and land degradation, as well as the generation and use of soil data as part of extension services; and (iii) map existing digital agriculture platforms and digital solutions in the areas of weather and soil that focus on local farmers' main information needs, and their penetration level. 3.3Component III. Strengthen local capacities to produce and disseminate improved weather and soil-related recommendations (US$60,000). This component aims to train relevant government technical staff in the production and dissemination of improved farmer-centered weather forecasts (e.g.

through the use of - 7 - AI) and soil health management recommendations, as well as to recommend policy innovations in this field. The component will finance: (i) virtual and in-person training activities that can target professionals from agrometeorology agencies, agricultural research agencies, extension agencies and other relevant institutions; and (ii) the production of relevant policy papers. 3.4Component IV. Pilots design with a gender and diversity approach (US$210,000). This component aims to design the pilot research projects to be implemented in prioritized value chains in each country, using as inputs the assessments conducted as part of components 1 and 2. Pilot value chains will be selected in consultation with local stakeholders. Criteria such as market orientation, size, farmer gender and belonging to indigenous communities will be considered.

The design of the pilots will consider current IDB operations and dialogue in the respective countries, as well as national rural development strategies. These pilots could be designed as part of hybrid (in person plus digital) extension initiatives or systems. It will finance in each country: (i) the design of the pilots, including targeted value chains, objectives and timeline; (ii) the design and development of a digital solution for dissemination (or the use of an existing solution) in line with the delivery channels -SMS, Whatsapp, etc.- that are considered the most adequate for each setting, and (iii) the production of farmer- centered information products (recommendations, alerts, forecasts) related to agrometeorological conditions and soil health management (including content, format, target farmers and triggers), which will require detailed agronomic research, focus groups and key informant interviews.

Differentiated needs and barriers faced by women and minority groups will inform the content, delivery channels, and user engagement strategies of the digital information products. Also, according to OP-619- 4, an ITE specialist is part of the project team and will be consulted related to the procurement of digital solutions. 3.5Component V: Pilots implementation, evaluation and dissemination (US$210,000). This component will focus on the implementation and evaluation of the three pilot projects in Colombia, Peru and Bolivia, as well as the dissemination of main findings.

This component will finance: (i) the implementation of the pilots, which will include feedback loops where farmers can provide input on the usefulness and accuracy of the weather forecasts in real time to improve the system's adaptability and precision; (ii) the design of the pilots' evaluation schemes (A/B testing, impact evaluations) in order to learn the most effective ways to improve the adoption of recommended practices and increase farmers' resilience and income; (iii) the implementation of the evaluations, which includes data collection, data analysis, development of data privacy guidelines, and the production of policy papers or research articles; (iv) the production of guidelines to design, implement and evaluate digital agriculture extension platforms that allow the dissemination of relevant weather and soil-related information products to smallholder farmers at scale in the three countries ; and (v) dissemination activities.

3.6 The total proposed budget for this TC is US$700,000 financed by the Multidonor Fund AgroLAC 2025 (MAG). There will not be counterpart funding. The disbursement period will be 36 months. - 8 - Indicative Budget (US$) Activity / ComponentDescriptionIDB/Fund FundingTotal Funding Component I. The expected impact is inducing behavior change that has a positive impact on farmers' agricultural productivity and climate resilience, which will be tested through the evaluations of the pilots, included in component V. The use of digital tools makes evaluations easier and cheaper to implement since digital delivery and interaction facilitate data collection.

3.8 The expected outcomes are: (i) three country proposals with gender and diversity approach completed (based on country assessments covering farmers' needs, weather forecasting, soil data use and ag extension capacities); (ii) at least 10,000 farmers beneficiaries of pilots of digital agricultural services provision implemented; (iii) at least 30 local technicians trained on weather forecasting, soil health data use and digital dissemination; (iv) three pilots implemented with evaluations completed; (v) three country policy guidelines to design, implement and evaluate digital extension platforms focused on weather and soil information that will serve to guide future policies and projects on digital agricultural extension. 3.9Monitoring and supervision. The Bank will manage the contracting of consulting services required for the execution of the operation.

The beneficiary institutions of the TC will provide technical input in line with their priorities and strategic approaches to the design of the terms of reference that will be produced and will participate in the review of the products obtained, the approval of which is the responsibility of the Bank. This will promote continuous coordination with the beneficiaries involved, which will facilitate monitoring of the expected achievements of the TC. The Bank's Technical Cooperation Monitoring and Reporting System (OP-1385-4) will also be used to properly monitor the operation.

4.1Executing Agency. The Bank will be the Executing Agency (EA). IDB activities will be carried out by the Agriculture and Rural Development Division (PTI/ARD), in close coordination with the ARD and CSD/DRM specialists in Bolivia, Peru and Colombia. - 9 - The main responsibilities of the IDB will be to: (i) develop the work plan and monitor the schedule of activities; (ii) perform the financial administration of the project; (iii) coordinate the preparation of the Terms of Reference for procurement of goods and the selection and contracting of consulting services following IDB regulations, policies and procedures; (iv) prepare/review progress reports; (v) prepare and update the Procurement Plan; and (vi) coordinate the contracting of independent external consultants.

4.2 The execution structure is justified by the Bank's experience in the preparation and development of regional activities that require a high degree of coordination among countries and are highly technical, such as those proposed in this operation. Regional coordination is needed to ensure consistency in the analysis and product quality that will result from the implementation of the TC. Also, a regional perspective will be important to evaluate the potential to share digital solutions across TC countries (adjusted to local contexts as needed) and to propose solutions beyond pilots. This regional coordination will be achieved through: i) a team leader and co-team leader that will lead all TC's activities in the three countries; ii) the continuous involvement of ARD and CSD/DRM specialists in the three countries; and iii) keeping CAN's regional coordinator informed and involved as appropriate. 4.3Procurement.

The activities planned within the framework of this TC have been included in the Procurement Plan (Annex IV) and will be contracted in accordance with the applicable Bank policies and regulations as follows: (i) Hiring of individual consultants, as established in the Complementary Workforce Standard (AM-650) and (ii) Hiring of services provided by consulting firms in accordance with the Institutional Procurement Policy (GN-2303-33) and its Guidelines. The consultants and consulting firms hired will be from member countries of the Bank. The execution and technical supervision of the TC products will be carried out by PTI/ARD. 4.4 The monitoring of the TC will be carried out by the Bank and will be based on the comparison between the planned and actual procurements and the products planned in each consultant's work plan and the products delivered.
4.5 The execution costs of the TC will be covered by the administrative budget of the Bank staff who are part of the project team.

5.1 The work involving several countries requires close coordination between consultants, and/or, firms, as well as the IDB team in different Country offices, and the respective country entities involved.1 In this context, difficulties in coordination might arise. To mitigate this risk, a core team of specialists from PTI/ARD has been assembled to lead and supervise the implementation of this TC and this team will maintain close coordination with the Country Offices throughout the execution of the TC to ensure alignment with national priorities and ongoing Bank operations. 1 Being a Research and Dissemination regional TC, non-objection letters have not been requested at this stage. However, the team plans to inform and/or request letters from national institutions in each country before field research activities are conducted.

- 10 - 5.2Also, as this TC aims to promote the digitization of extension services and this process remains disruptive to traditional operating practices, some institutions may encounter resistance to the adoption of digital tools or a lack of willingness to scale the results. To mitigate this, the relevant entities in each country will be considered, such as the relevant agencies of the Ministries of Agriculture (extension, agricultural research, animal and plant health) and the National Weather Agencies. Since they will be involved from the beginning of the projects, they will contribute to the design, dissemination, and use of the results.

Further, given the high turnover of authorities and the resulting change in priorities in these countries due to upcoming general elections, it will be key to involve as much as possible technical staff who are immune to such changes, in order to have wide technical support in the institutions to continue the execution. 5.3 The knowledge products and digital assets generated within the framework of this TC will be the property of the Bank and may be made available to the public under a Creative Commons license. However, at the request of the beneficiaries, the intellectual property of such products may also be licensed to the beneficiaries. All knowledge and digital assets generated will align with regulations AM-331 and AM-325.

Project Name: Continued Support to the Public Sector Transformation Programme Project Number: JA-L1094 Project Team: Benjamin Roseth, Team Leader; Sandra Naranjo, Alternate Team Leader; Laura Rodríguez; María José Martínez; Gastón Pierri; (IFD/ICS); Horacio Mendoza (LEG/SGO); Andrea Monje (SCL/GDI); Shirley Foronda; Veronica Benedettelli (VPC/FMP); Jodi Ho Lung (CCB/CJA) , Gerard Alleng ; Avagay Simpson (CSD/CCS) and Nikeisha Russell ( consultant ). Borrower: Jamaica Executing Agency: Ministry of Finance and the Public Service Financial Plan: IDB ( ordinary capital ): US$ 70,000,000 Total: US$ 70,000,000 Safeguards: Policies triggered: ESPS 1 , 2, 10 Classification: C

2.1 Background and justification. Jamaica has effectively managed the economic challenges posed by the COVID -19 pandemic, demonstrating prudent macroeconomic strategies. Notable achievements include reductions in public debt, inflation, and external deficits, as well as the implementation of a Fiscal Responsibility Law and the adoption of inflation targeting.1 However, fiscal space remains limited to absorb future shocks or increase expenditure in priority areas such as infrastructure, education, or health. D ebt service represen ts 48% of the 2024 public expenditure .2 The second highest expenditure is t he wage bil l, which in 2024 represented 43% of public expenditure ,3 higher than the regional average of 28%.4 Given such limited fiscal space , achieving spending efficiency is paramount .

2.2 The Government of Jamaica has room to improve policy implementation.5 Even in its best perform ing sectors, like education -PISA scores close to the regional 1 IMF (2023) 2022 Article IV Consultation Jamaica. 2 Government of Jamaica, " Fiscal Policy Paper FY 2024/25 ", February 15, 2024. 3 Government of Jamaica. 4 World Bank, " Worldwide Bureaucracy Indicators Dashboard" , World Bank, 2023. 5 World Bank, "Jamaica - Systematic Country Diagnostic: Boosting Recovery and Sustainable Economic Growth ", 2022. - 2 - average (377 vs. 374) -, there are opportunities for efficiency gains.

Jamaica's learning- adjusted years of schooling are 10 % lower than expected for its level of development, expenditure in education and population size.6 Improved strategic human resource management could suggest, for example, m echanisms to tie salary increases to performance or the implementation of workforce planning that could allow for the reallocation of teachers within education levels without increasing costs .7 2.3 The Government of Jamaica has demonstrated a commitment to increasing the efficiency and effectiveness of the public sector. The policy authority for these efforts is the Public Sector Master Rationalisation Plan, which was tabled in Parliament in 2010 , which remains in effect .

Recently, with IDB support, it completed the execution of the Public Sector Transformation Programme (PSTP) ,8 with achievements including: (i) the implementation of a cross -government online transactional human resources management tool (MyHR+) in 55 Ministries, Departments, and Agencies (MDAs), encompassing over 50% of public officers; (ii) supporting the restruc turing of the Government of Jamaica compensation scheme, including a reduction from 325 different salary scales to 16; and (iii) the implementation of four digital services .9 This work was spearheaded by the Transformation Implementation Unit (TIU) of the Ministry of Finance and the Public Service (MoFPS). During the same period, the TIU also began work towards the rationalization of public bodies - comprising companies, agenc ies, and statutory bodies - to eliminate duplicated functions and close entities that had achieved their mandates.

The TIU facilitated the reduction of the number of public bodies from 190 in 2017 to 152 in 2023. In parallel to PSTP, the government , with IDB support, undertook the creation of a national identification system , which will allow for simpler citizen interactions with public institutions, among other benefits. A precursor to PSTP was the Public Sector Efficiency Programme (PSEP) , which supported improvements in public sector human resource management , use of information and communications technologies in government, procurement processes , and budget oversight. The current project aims to build on the successes of PSTP and PSEP to address remaining challenges in the efficiency of public sector operations. For example, the shared services activities described under Component 1 are direct continuations of activities begun under PSTP. 2.4 Main problem.

The main problem this project will address is the inefficient management of public sector human, financial, and organizational resources .10 The specific problems related to the general problem are: 2.5 Specific problem 1. Duplication and inefficiency in government support functions. The main support functions, including payroll, finance and accounts, 6 World Bank (2021) PER Education Sector . 7 World Bank, " Public Expenditure Review of the Education Sector in Jamaica ", World Bank, accessed March 12, 2024. 8 4374/OC -JA. 9 Work Permit System for the Ministry of Labour and Social Services; Child Protection and Family Services Agency Childcare Management System; Fisheries Integrated Licensing and Registration Information System; and Customer Relationship Management System for the Passports, Immigration, and Citizenship Agency .

10 Jamaica scores 0.6 on the "Government Effectiveness" measure of the Worldwide Governance Indicators of the World Bank, compared to 0.85 for Uruguay, the LAC leader; Jamaica scores 4.7 on the Berteslmann Stiftung Transformation Index "resource efficiency" measure, compared to a LAC average of 5.0. - 3 - procurement, project management, ICT management, and non -financial asset management operate in a manual, decentralized way, without strategic direction, across most of the 190 Government of Jamaica Ministries, Departments and Agencies (MDAs) , impeding the effective implementation of government priorities .11 This fragmentation leads to heterogeneous execution due to the lack of cohesive and standardized policies, guidelines, and procedures.

For example, payroll processes are executed at each MDA, some of which have paper -based processes, leading to irregular payment schedules , payroll errors, and a general inability to assess the efficiency of payroll execution. In the case of finance and accounts, there are currently 1,493 public officer roles when projections indicate that under a centralized service delivery model these could be reduced to approximately 600. 12 In the case of procurement, the systems are different in each MDA, encompassing a mix of paper -based systems and local IT systems, impeding end- to-end process automation and whole- of-government procurement analyses. 2.6 Specific problem 2. The multiplicity of public bodies13 weakens oversight and efficiency.

The IMF has repeatedly cited the fact that the finances for the public bodies are managed off budget and the resulting difficulty in exercising prudent fiscal management as a risk to the government's overall fiscal position.14 The latest incorporation of public bodies into reporting systems is an improvement that needs consolidation. 15 This difficulty is compounded by a lack of oversight: under 60% of public bodies regularly submit their annual reports to Parliament as required under law. Lastly, out of a total of 152 public bodies, 50 are dormant , meaning that they exist legally and are subject to corporate governance requirements but do not have active personnel or produce any output. However, they persist in consuming budgetary resources, totaling around US$211,000 per year.

These funds cover expenses such as board of directors ' fees , auditing, and corporate secretarial services when required, among others. 2.7 Specific problem 3. Inadequate civil service management. Civil service management in Jamaica is characterized by inefficient, primarily transactional functions, and heterogeneous implementation across MDAs. This is evidenced in the results of the 201816 application of the Civil Service Quality Index, which revealed an overall score of 54 (compared to 73 for Chile, the LAC leader).

Some of the key problems highlighted by the application of the Civil Service Quality Index are: (i) insufficient capability of both central HR offices and MDA -level HR officers to perform strategic HR functions such as workforce planning and succession planning; ( ii) the job classification system and the associated competencies and skills is outdated and inconsistent with the compensation restructuring implemented in 2022- 2024; (iii) scattered sources of information on job openings in the Government of Jamaica ; (iv) limited information and tools to facilitate internal mobility within the public sector; and (v) the employee perfor mance management framework is inconsistent with the compensation restructuring implemented in 11 EY. 2018. In 2022, women represented 62% of the public sector workforce and held 62,1% of managerial positions in Jamaica.17 While evidence indicate compensation and occupational gender gaps persist in the country, detailed gender -disaggregated data on these aspects are lacking for the public administration.

Persons with disabilities experience exclusion from various societal aspects, including in employment.18 The 5% employment quota for persons with disabilities in the public sector remains unmet, with no specific research available.19 Additionally, one of the Government of Jamaica job listing websites,20 which is the closest to a public recruitment platform, is not accessible for persons with disabilities.21 2.9 Strategic alignment . The program me is consistent with the IDB Group Institutional Strategy: Transforming for Scale and Impact (CA -631) and is aligned with the objective of (i) bolster sustainable regional growth by strengthening the institutional capacity of the Government of Jamaica, which has been shown to be critical to productivity and growth.22 It also aligns with theoperational focus areas of: (i) Institutional Capacity, Rule of Law, and Citizen Security, and (ii) Gender Equality and Inclusion of Diverse Population Groups.

Similarly, it is aligned with the IDB Country Strategy with Jamaica 2022 -2026 (GN-3138), which includes as strategic objective 5.1 "enhancing the effectiveness of public administration". It is also aligned with the Sector Strategy on Institutions for Growth and Social Welfare (GN-25872) for contributing to the theme of Institutions for Innovation and Technological Development, specifically to the objectives: (ii) develop advanced human capital; and (iii) strengthen institutions and networks. It is consistent with the Gender and Diversity Sector Framework Document (GN -2800- 13), the IDB Group Gender and Diversity Action Plan 2022- 2025 (GN-3116- 1), and the Employment Action Framework with a Gender Perspective (GN -3057) , by mainstreaming frameworks to promote the inclusiveness of public sector human resources management practices for women and persons with disabilities .

This operation is included in the Operational Program Report 2024 (GN -3207) . Lastly, the operation is aligned with ONE Caribbean (GN -3201- 2), through both of its cross- cutting issues of digital transformation and strengthening of institutions. 2.10 The general development objective of this program me is to increase the efficiency of the management of public sector human, financial and organizational resources. The expected impact of the programme is an i ncrease in government effectiveness. Results will include : (i) reduction in expenditure on cross- government support functions (procurement, human resources and payroll, and finance and accounting), (ii) a reduction in procurement processing times, (iii) fiscal savings from public bodies rationalization; (i v) strengthened civil service management . 2.16 Programme beneficiaries. This operation targets upstream institutions (core ministries and agencies at the center of government and public institutions) with the aim of improving their efficiency and effectiveness. The direct beneficiaries of the program are public servants, who will experience more efficient processes because of the introduction of shared services and who will enjoy greater possibilities for career development thanks to the updating of the human resources management model. The executing agency will be the Ministry of Finance and the Public Service, through the TIU. The TIU has a proven track record of successfully executing IDB -financed programs, including the Public Sector Transformation Programme ( 4374/OC -JA, US$50 million), which concluded execution in February 2024. Furthermore, the Bank previously invested U$65 million in building the institutional capacity of the Ministry of Finance through an investment loan operation 2658/OC -JA, which concluded in 2018. An analysis of the Ministry of Finance and the Public Service (including the TIU ) institutional capacity to implement the project will be conducted using the Bank's Institutional Capacity Analysis Platform (ICAP) and the results will be fully incorporated in the development of the operation.

Moreover, the results will inform the risk analysis, the areas for improvement, the detailed execution arrangements, and the fiduciary actions needed to be in place for the program's successful execution. 2.18 Financial instrument. The operation will be an investment loan under the modality of specific investment loan of ordinary capital with a six -year disbursement period, executed by the Government of Jamaica through the Transformation - 7 - Implementation Unit (TIU) of the Ministry of Finance and the Public Service. This loan modality will allow for specific investments in hardware, software, advisory, and training, the financing of the personnel of the TIU as the Project Execution Unit to su pport implementation, and for continuous IDB technical and fiduciary support. 2.19 Complementarity with other operations in development.

This project will benefit from complementarity with the Government Digital Transformation Programme (in preparation) and Strengthening Cybersecurity in Jamaica (in preparation). The Government Digital Transformation Programme will finance investments in cross -government digital capability, allowing for the more efficient delivery of transactional public services for citizens and firms. Taken together, will significantly reduce the cos ts institutions face to manage their non -core business, such as building their online presence and managing the administrative support functions. Strengthening Cybersecurity in Jamaica will result in greater protection against cyberattacks on government digital assets, which will increase with the new operations . Furthermore, the Government Digital Transformation Programme will also be executed by the TIU, facilitating coordination between the two projects and generating economies of scale in programme administration. 2.20 Coordination.

Most of the programme will benefit different units within the Ministry of Finance and the Public Service (e.g. the Strategic Human Resources Management Division and the Office of Public Procurement), where the TIU is also located, thus facilitating coordi nation. Component 3 (talent) will also require coordination with the Office of the Services Commissions, which holds several responsibilities for human resources management. This would be conducted through the working groups established for the purposes of the public sector compensation review completed under PSTP.

4.1 Environmental and social considerations. In accordance with the Environmental and Social Policy Framework (ESPF), the operation was classified as Category "C" as it is expected to cause minimal or no negative environmental or social impacts. 4.2 Fiduciary aspects. It is intended that the TIU, as the project's Project Executing Unit (PEU), be responsible for overall project fiduciary oversight including procurement, financial management and disbursement arrangements. The PEU will be responsible for procurement, budgeting and planning, accounting, and reporting, ensuring flow of funds, internal controls, procurement and financial management staffing and external audits for the whole project. The overall fiduciary risk of the project at this stage is medium -low.

5.1 Risks. The following risks to project execution have been preliminarily identified: (i) If the implementation of innovative activities (e.g. the Public Sector Skills Marketplace, the automation of the job evaluation process) is slow, the overall pace of execution could be affected; (ii) If the PEU has difficulties in recruiting and retaining specialized staff to support the implementation of project activities, the technical quality of project activities could be compromised; and (iii) if there is a change in gov ernment priorities due to a general election, or a change in ministerial- level authorities in the pre- election period, high- level support for the project could be diminished, leading to reduced fiscal space for execution, a slower pace of execution, and/or a change in the activities to the financed.

The corresponding mitigation measures are: (i) build in time and procedures for iterative solution development to ensure user -oriented design and optimum functionality; (ii) offer flexible and competitive contracts (e.g. open to both local and international specialists and firms); and (iii) align project activities to both long- term development goals and institution -level strategic plans to maximize the probability of leadership buy -in should there be a change in government. - 9 - 5.2 Sustainability. The programme primarily supports the strengthening or permanent government institutions that have the mandate, strategic framework and capability necessary to continue the initiatives that will be executed under the programme once its resources are fully disbursed. The training activities are the most susceptible to unsustainability, despite Jamaica having a career -based civil service system.
Emphasis will be placed on the development of reusable tools and materials to maximize the possibility that skills d evelopment will continue beyond the life of the programme.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: 2.1 Objectives . The main objective of this Technical Cooperation (TC) is to strengthen the institutional capacities of national counterparts by enhancing the design, selection, and evaluation of Productive Development Programs (PDP) (especially, programs to promote technical -extension and creation/adoption of innovation in firms) through the application of Artificial Intelligence Generated Synthetic Data (AIGSD) and Machine Learning (ML) methodologies. This will be achieved by: (i) creating privacy -compliant synthetic dat asets that replicate the statistical properties of confidential administrative records, enabling robust evaluation of PDPs without compromising data confidentiality ; (ii) improving the selection mechanisms of PDPs to identify candidates with the highest potential for positive outcomes; and (iii) building institutional capacity within implementing agencies to apply these methodologies independently. 2.2 Justification . PDPs face two challenges that limit their effectiveness and evaluation.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: First, while administrative data (such as employer -employee payrolls, tax and trade records, and social security registries) can significantly enhance program evaluation, confidentiali ty restrictions often prevent access to these data sources (Koenecke and Varian, 2020; Nagaraj and Tranchero, 2023; Barrientos et al., 2024). Second, the - 2 - mechanisms used to select suitable beneficiaries typically rely on heuristics or theory - based (deductive) approaches, rather than on inductive methods that learn from complex patterns in relevant data (Fontagné et al., 2013; Buffart et al., 2020). 2.3 AIGSD addresses the first challenge by generating synthetic datasets that statistically mimic real administrative records while preserving privacy. Causal inference, combined with ML methods, addresses the second challenge by enabling the development of mo re effective selection algorithms using historical program data with known outcomes.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: The application of these methodologies is expected to significantly enhance the design, implementation, and evaluation of PDPs throughout the region. 2.4 For generating synthetic data from confidential administrative records, we will implement several approaches. A well -established method is based on Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs). GANs consist of two neural networks competing against each other - a generator that creates fake data and a discriminator that tries to detect fake from real data. Through this adversarial training process, the generator learns to create increasingly realistic outputs. Conditional Tabular GAN (CTGAN) (Xu et al., 2019) exce ls at handling heterogeneous tabular data (mixing numerical and categorical variables) and enables conditional generation (e.g., synthesizing firm -level data for specific industries or regions).

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: CTGAN has shown competitive privacy performance despite lacki ng differential privacy mechanisms that would add noise or randomness (Liu et al., 2025). More recent approaches include diffusion -based models and transformer -based models. Diffusion models learn to generate data by modeling the reverse process of gradual ly adding noise to data. They are trained to remove noise step by step, learning to transform pure noise into realistic outputs. TabDDPM (Tabular Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Model ) is one such model specialized in tabular data (Kotelnikov et al., 2023). Transformer -based models, such as Gretel Tabular Fine -Tuning, take a pre -trained language model and subject it to additional pre -training on diverse tabular datasets. 2.5 Challenges in synthetic data generation include preserving temporal dynamics and causal relationships.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: Regarding temporal dynamics, the synthesizers typically treat each row in a dataset as an independent observation missing the sequential logic and autoco rrelation structures that govern time series. As for causal relationships, while the synthesizers reproduce correlation patterns, they typically do not preserve the selection mechanisms, quasi -random variation, and unobserved heterogeneity structures that make causal identification possible in the original data. On both sides, methods have advanced. Modern methods implement training processes that attempt to preserve step -by-step temporal transitions and mimic real data -generating processes that maintain ca usal relationships. However, time series and causal synthesis are still developing without the robustness of cross -sectional analysis (Brophy et al., 2023; Amad et al., 2024).

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: 2.6 The quality of synthetic data generated by each method will be evaluated using both statistical similarity metrics (comparing distributions of key variables and their relationships) and utility metrics (the ability to derive similar conclusions from analys es performed on both real and synthetic data). This includes comparisons of marginal distributions of individual variables to test attribute fidelity (e.g., Kullback -Leibler (KL) divergence and chi -squared tests), joint distributions and correlations betwe en variables to test bivariate fidelity (e.g., Jensen -Shannon distance), performance of downstream regression and ML tasks (e.g., Train -Synthetic -Test-Real (TSTR) methodology) and validation of causal inference estimation to test application fidelity. - 3 - 2.7 Privacy evaluation metrics will also be examined.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: These include delta -presence analysis, which measures the maximum probability that a specific firm's data can be inferred from the synthetic dataset, and k -anonymization scores, which assess whether each sy nthetic record is indistinguishable from at least k -1 other based on key identifying attributes. Identifiability scores will be used to quantify re -identification risk by estimating how many original records can be uniquely matched to synthetic ones. Addit ional assessments will include membership inference attack simulations to test whether adversaries can detect the presence of a specific firm in the training data, and attribute inference evaluations to determine whether sensitive firm characteristics can be inferred from synthetic data patterns. 2.8 Prior work across a range of fields demonstrates how synthetic data can enhance analysis while safeguarding privacy and maintaining fidelity.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: In education, GANs combined with differential privacy have been used to replicate student performance patterns wit hout exposing individual records (Liu et al., 2025). In agricultural economics, synthetic farm -level datasets have reproduced real -world elasticities and efficiency scores (Wimmer & Finger, 2023). In autonomous driving, diffusion models have generated rare -condition road scenes to improve system robustness (Goel & Narasimhan, 2024). In healthcare, privacy -preserving synthetic patient records have been used to augment clinical cohorts for reliable predictive modeling (Giuffr√® & Shung, 2023). In finance, CTGA Ns have simulated transaction time series for stress - testing fraud detection and risk models (Assefa et al., 2020). To the best of our knowledge, however, these methods have not yet been applied to the research or evaluation of innovation policy.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: 2.9 To improve beneficiary selection, we will implement the following approach that combines causal inference, multi -program data integration, and synthetic data - augmented ML: (i) Treatment effect calculation: We will conduct causal impact evaluations using PSM (Propensity Score Matching ) to estimate treatment effects for the primary program under evaluation (e.g, Startup Perú or Crece), measuring impacts on key outcomes such as innovation performance, productivity, and sales.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: Simultaneously, we will incorporat e treatment effects from external programs implemented by the same or similar agencies, ensuring that each firm observation has both comprehensive characteristic data and a corresponding individual treatment effect measure ; (ii) Data assembly: The internal and external datasets will be merged into a unified database containing firm characteristics (size, age, sector, geographic location, education levels, etc.) as features and standardized treatment effects as the target variable ; and (iii) Synthesis: To ad dress sample size limitations and class imbalance issues, this combined dataset will be processed using the AI -based synthetic data generation methodologies discussed in the previous section. The synthetic data generation will expand the training dataset while preserving the statistical relationships between firm characteristics and treatment effects observed across multiple programs, creating a robust and balanced training set.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: 2.10 Model training and validation: Multiple ML algorithms will be trained on the synthesized dataset to learn patterns between firm characteristics and program success across different PDP interventions. Models will be validated using holdout samples of real data to ensure that insights derived from synthetic training translate effectively to actual selection decisions. 2.11 This TC is consistent with the Inter -American Development Bank (IDB) Group Institutional Strategy: Transforming for Scale and Impact (CA -631) and is aligned with the objective of: (i) Bolster sustainable growth, as the TC result will contribute with the - 4 - designing and implementing of better public policies to increase productivity in the LAC region.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: The TC is also aligned with the operational focus areas of: (i) Institutional Capacity and Rule of Law and Citizen Security; and (ii) Productive Development an d Innovation through the Private sector. The TC is also aligned with the CTI Sector Framework Document (SFD) (GN -2791 -13), and with the Ordinary Capital Strategic Development Program (OC SDP) Window 2, Priority Area 3: Effective, Efficient, and Transparent Institutions (W2C) (GN -2819 -14), which has as expected results strengthen the quality of institutions and policies as well as the provision of services and implementation of policies, to improve public management and promote the development of the private sector; and leverage digital transformation to promote more effective, efficient and transparent governments, better and more equitable opportunities for citizens, and more productive and innovative companies.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: The TC is also aligned with the IDB Group Cou ntry Strategy of Chile 2022 -2026 (GN -3140 -3) and Peru 2022 -2026 (GN -3110 -1) with the strategic area of strengthening the efficiency and quality of the public agencies and the strategic objective of increasing productivity by improving evaluability.

3.1 Component 1. Development and implementation of AI -based synthetic data generation methodologies (US$140,000). This component will advance the following activities: (i) Data collection and preparation of administrative records: Identifying and obtaining access to relevant confidential administrative datasets (such as employer -employee payrolls, tax records, and soc ial security registries) from participating institutions, establishing secure data handling protocols, and preparing the data for synthetic genera tion; (ii) Implementation and comparison of synthetic data generation methodologies; and (iii) Evaluation and validation of synthetic data quality. 3.2 Component 2. Development of ML -based beneficiary selection algorithms (US$80,000).

This component will carry out the following activities: (i) Causal impact evaluation and data integration: Implementing PSM to estimate individual treatment effects for firms from the primary program under evaluation, while incorporating treatment effect data from external programs implemented by similar agencies, creating a unified dataset with firm characteristics as features and standardized treatment effects as target var iables; (ii) Synthetic data generation and model development: Applying AI -based synthetic data generation methodologies to the integrated dataset to address sample size limitations and class imbalance, then creating and training multiple ML algorithms on t he synthesized data to learn patterns between firm characteristics and program success across different PDP interventions; and (iii) Model validation and optimization: Evaluating model performance using holdout samples of real data through cross -validation , fine -tuning parameters to ensure synthetic training translates to effective real -world selection decisions, and optimizing selection algorithms to identify candidates with the highest potential for positive outcomes across diverse program contexts.

3.3 Component 3. Institutional capacity building for AI methodology adoption (US$40,000). This component will develop the following activities: (i) Development of comprehensive training materials and documentation: Creating user manuals, technical guides, and tutorial materials for both synthetic data generation and ML - based selection methodol ogies ; and (ii) Implementation of hands -on training workshops: Conducting in -person and virtual training sessions with technical staff from participating institutions, foc using on practical application of the developed methodologies. - 5 - 3.4 Component 4. Data sharing and institutional cooperation (US$20,000). This component will establish and strengthen the institutional frameworks necessary for sustainable data access and collaboration between the IDB and partner institutions in Chile and Peru.

Activities will include: (i) developing and formalizing interagenc y cooperation agreements with data custodians such as Chile's SII and SERCOTEC, and Peru's SUNAT and ProInnovate, establishing clear protocols for secure data access, usage rights, and co nfidentiality provisions ; and (ii) creating standardized data governance frameworks that ensure compliance with national privacy regulations while enabling synthetic data generation activities. 3.5 Budget. Bank execution is justified because: (i) the TC requires - 6 - specialized expertise in AI and synthetic data generation that is not available within beneficiary countries' institutional frameworks; (ii) PTI/CTI has demonstrated technical capacity in innovation policy evaluation and beneficiary selection and can coord inate the complex, multi -disciplinary research required; and (iii) the IDB's regional mandate enables knowledge transfer and methodological standardization across Chile and Peru, facilitating future replication throughout the region.

4.2 For selection and contracting, the Bank's team will consider: (i) hiring individual consultants, in accordance with the provisions of the Complementary Workforce policy (AM-650); and (ii) contracting logistical services and other non -consulting services, i n accordance with the Institutional Procurement Policy GN -2303 -33 and its guidelines.

5 5.1 Data access: Gaining access to confidential administrative records presents both legal and bureaucratic hurdles. However, it is expected that the TC "Improving evaluability during execution through continuous evaluation with administrative data" ( ATN/OC - 21360 -RG) will facilitate this process. This TC aims to establish interagency cooperation agreements for administrative data sharing in both Chile and Peru -the same countries targeted by this TC -and to build capacity for exploiting these records. If successful, this TC will have already established the necessary legal frameworks and relationships with data custodians.

5.2 Privacy compliance: Despite the expected progress from TC ATN/OC -21360 -RG, additional measures will still be implemented: (i) establishing formal data sharing agreements with clear confidentiality provisions specifically for synthetic data generation; (ii) implementing secure data handling protocols that comply with relevant privacy laws; and (iii) engaging legal experts from participating institutions early in the process to address compliance requirements. 5.3 Institutional adoption and cultural resistance: New AI -based methodologies may face resistance due to organizational inertia, skepticism about "black box" algorithms, or concerns about replacing human judgment in selection processes. Mitigation strategies include: (i) demonstrating tangible benefits through pilot implementations; (ii) ensuring transparency in how AI models make recommendations; and (iii) framing the new methodologies as decision -support tools that enhance rather than replace expert judgment .

5.4 Synthetic data effectiveness for causal inference applications: While synthetic data generation methods excel at preserving distributions, correlations and enabling downstream prediction tasks such as ML, their effectiveness for causal inference applicatio ns remains less established in the literature. To ensure that synthetic data maintains the causal structures necessary for reliable treatment effect estimation, we will implement specialized methodologies that model the actual data generation process (Amad et al., 2024). However, these adaptations may reduce the data's utility for other analytical applications. Still, regardless of causal inference performance, the generated synthetic data will provide value for broader data analysis tasks and ML applicatio ns and can be released for use by other researchers and practitioners.

chunk_text: Cleaner Production and Industry 2.7 Faced with this urgent need for improved competitiveness for industry combined with a growing concern for environmental degradation, more a nd more companies throughout the world have begun adopting cleaner production techniques in th eir quest to improve their competitiveness through increased ecoefficiency. chunk_text: 4.1 The general objective of the proposed project is to assist small and medium enterprises improve their efficiency, productivity, and competitiveness and profitability through improved technological and environmental management. The purpose of this initiative is to facilitate the use and implementation of cleaner production through expanding the reach of the CMPL, allowing it to provide services to a larger number of SMEs in various parts of Mexico. 4.2 This project expects to encompass three components: a. Creation and development of regional CP centers -this component will seek to create and develop regional cleaner production centers through the provision of training in CP, energy efficiency, project management, promotion, and administrative management for the regional CP center staff. The CMPL will seek to become the nucleus of a network of regional centers dedicated to the promotion of CP.

chunk_text: This project would also seek to involve national and local environmental authorities, as a means to transfer knowledge about CP and exchange experiences, with the purpose of influencing the development of policies concerning CP. In addition, the project will also seek to raise awareness about cleaner production among relevant public and private sector institutions, especially those in the area of finance. In order to raise awareness among SMEs througho ut Mexico as to the business benefits of implementing cleaner production techniques, the project expects to have a series of awareness-training sessions on cleaner production in each of the regions during the three-year period of the project. b. chunk_text: 6.1 The Centro Mexicano para la Producción más Limpia (CMPL) will be the grant beneficiary and responsible for local counterpart resources. The CMPL was created in 1995 with the support of UNIDO, along with the local counterparts, the National Polytechnic Institute and CANACINTRA. In December 1998, UNIDO ended its support of the CMPL. The mission of the CMPL is to promote the use of cleaner pr oduction techniques among companies in Mexico as a means to improve competitiveness as well as assist in mitigating the deleterious impact of industrial activities on the environment. The CMPL provides technical assistance activities in cleaner production, energy efficiency techniques and environmental management systems to the private sector, along with training and information dissemination in these various themes.

chunk_text: In addition, the Center develops strategic studies c oncerning natural resource management including studies on policy and financing matters relative to cleaner production and other similar topics. 6.2 The CMPL has over six years of experience, having worked in over 10 industrial sectors and with numerous organizations such as universities, industry chambers, business associations and cleaner production centers in Latin America including El Salvador, Costa Rica, Guatemala, Nicaragua and Colombia. As mentioned previously, th e CMPL has maintained a focus on providing services to SMEs, allowing it to gain an expertise in overcoming some of the particular issues that often confront smaller enterprises. The CMPL consists of 16 professionals: 12 of which are trained CP specialists and four trai ned in administration and finance.

chunk_text: 11.1 The Bank Country Paper for Mexico identified a nu mber of challenges that are constraining the competitiveness of the private sector, which included issues related to the environment and urban development. Most notably, Country Paper iden tified the disconnect between natural resource use and efficiency, which has resulted in serious environmental problems such as water and air pollution, culminating in an adverse affect on human health and diminished availability of natural resources. In response to this, the Bank's proposed strategy for Mexico has as one its four basic elements: Improving competitiveness by lowering barriers that limit productivity and efficient development of the private sector . Moreover, the Country Paper identified the role of the MIF in Mexico to include improving the competitiveness of the private sector among its four major areas of possible operations.

chunk_text: 11.2 This initiative is linked to other efforts of the MIF in the area of ecoefficiency and cleaner production and will be specifically included in the MIF Cluster, Achieving Ecoefficiency Through Cleaner Production and Environmental Management (see MIF/GN-58-1) . 11.3 Another MIF project is currently under implementa tion in Monterrey, Mexico with the Instituto de Protección Ambiental (IPA) that is focused on assisting SMEs with ISO 14001 environmental management system implementation. The project in Monterrey is part of the ISO Cluster of projects. Given that the activities encompassed in the MIF project with IPA only pertain to the Monterrey area, there is no expected overlap w ith this proposed initiative with the CMPL. However, there may be some important initial less ons learned that would be infused into this proposed project, if deemed relevant by the project team.

• Country/Region: MEXICO/CID - Isthmus & DR • TC Name: Agricultural policies for Food Security, Competitiveness, and Sustainability in Mexico • TC Number: ME-T1549 • Team Leader/Members: BUSTAMANTE, CESAR TULIO (PTI/ARD) Team Leader; RONDINONE GONZALO (CSD/RND) Alternate Team Leader; SANCHEZ ALVAREZ, LOURDES FELICIDAD (VPC/FMP); DE DOBRZYNSKI, ESTEBAN (LEG/SGO); RESTREPO, LISA SOFIA (PTI/ARD); REYES RUGERIO JOSE MARTIN (CID/CME) • Taxonomy: Client Support • Number and name of operation supported by the TC:N/A • Date of TC Abstract: 06 Feb 2025 • Beneficiary: MEXICO • Executing Agency: INTER-AMERICAN DEVELOPMENT BANK • IDB funding requested: US$400,000.00 • Local counterpart funding: US$0.00 • Disbursement period: 24 months • Types of consultants: Individuals; Firms • Prepared by Unit: PTI/ARD - Agriculture and Rural Development Division • Unit of Disbursement Responsibility: CID/CME - Country Office Mexico • TC included in Country Strategy (y/n): • TC included in CPD (y/n):No Yes • Alignment to the Update to the Institutional Strategy 2010-2020:Social inclusion and equality ; Productivity and innovation ; Institutional capacity and rule of law

2.1 To contribute to the effectiveness of public policies in enhancing the competitiveness and sustainability of the agricultural sector and ensuring food security in Mexico. 2.2 The Mexican agri-food sector has transformed significantly since trade liberalization in the 1990s with NAFTA (now USMCA). Agriculture's share of GDP decreased from 6.7% in the 1990s to 3.1% in the 2010s, reaching 3.85% in recent years. Agricultural employment followed a similar trend, falling from 26% of total employment in 1990 to 13% by 2022. In 2024, the primary sector employed 1.91 million people (84.4% men and 15.6% women), with 23.2% in formal jobs and 76.8% in informal jobs. The structure of agricultural production changed significantly between 1990 and 2019. Poultry meat increased from 11% to 21% of agricultural output value, while beef declined from 28% to 25%, and cereals from 32% to 26%.

Corn remains Mexico's most important crop, representing 70-80% of cereal production value. However, domestic production only meets 55-60% of internal demand, with imports, mainly yellow corn from the U.S., filling the gap. In 2022, corn and corn products represented 3.5% of total household expenses and 8.6% of food expenditure, while corn tortillas accounted for 2.8% of total expenses and 7.1% of food expenditure. There is a clear income gradient: tortilla spending ranges from over 4% of household expenses in the lowest four income deciles to around 2.5% in deciles 5-8, and 1% in the highest deciles. - 2 - Policy support for the sector, measured by OECD's Producer Support Estimate (PSE), is relatively low but concentrated on Market Price Support (MPS). Since 2016, MPS has increased, reversing the downward trend following 1990s and 2000s reforms.

Recent agricultural policies prioritize small-scale producers of staple grains and vulnerable groups. The fertilizer program expanded nationwide, with its budget growing from $88.4 million in 2020 to $938.2 million in 2023. The SEGALMEX Guaranteed Price Program now supports over 117,000 small and medium-sized producers. Challenges persist in food security's four dimensions: availability, access, utilization, and stability. In Latin America and the Caribbean, food insecurity has risen due to crises like COVID-19 and the Ukraine war. By 2023, 28.2% of the region's population experienced food insecurity, and 6.2% faced hunger. In Mexico, 20.7% of the population suffers from moderate or severe food insecurity, increasing 2.5 percentage points over five years, though remaining between 19.5% and 24.8% for two decades. Agricultural productivity varies across crops and regions, with structural limitations in technology access, financing, and technical assistance affecting competitiveness.

Mexico faces significant agro-environmental challenges, including soil degradation, deforestation, biodiversity loss, and water pollution. Mexico has 25 of 32 soil groups recognized by the World Reference Base for Soil Resources, but over half show degradation. According to INEGI (2019), 28% of farmers report soil fertility problems. Deforestation, overgrazing, excessive agrochemical use, and inadequate toxic input regulation contribute to environmental deterioration. Understanding barriers and incentives for sustainable practices is crucial for long-term productivity.

3.1Component I: Agricultural Development and Food Security. This component will analyze agricultural support policies and their impact on food security in Mexico by: adapting the OECD PSE indicator to incorporate food security dimensions; analyzing value chains of key products (corn, milk, coffee, cocoa, vegetables) to assess their food security contribution and productivity potential; and evaluating programs like SEGALMEX's Guaranteed Price Program for their effectiveness in promoting food security and competitiveness. 3.2Component II: Agro-environmental Sustainability. This component will evaluate and strengthen Mexico's agro-environmental policy framework by: reviewing current agricultural policies, regulations, and programs to identify implementation gaps; and developing evidence-based policy proposals drawing from international practices, local research, and behavioral insights. The analysis will examine how incentives and social factors influence the adoption of sustainable practices to improve agro-environmental policy effectiveness

2.1Component I. Data Collection (US$125,000.00). The objective of this component is to compile and prepare the administrative and survey data necessary for the evaluation. Activities will include: (i) collecting and cleaning administrative crime and violence records from the National Police and the Ministry of Security for the period 2018-2025; and (ii) implementing a new round of a victimization survey, following the experiences carried out in 2017 and 2019. The IDB will be responsible for overseeing these activities, in close coordination with the relevant government entities. Procurement activities will involve hiring specialized consultants and firms for survey design, fieldwork, data processing, and data quality review. The expected output is a comprehensive dataset -both administrative and survey-based-covering pre- and post-intervention periods, providing the empirical foundation for the impact evaluation of the policing reform. 2.2Component II. Analysis and Reporting (US$15,000.00).

The objective of this component is to conduct the impact evaluation and prepare knowledge products to disseminate findings. Activities will include: (i) applying quasi-experimental methods, such as difference-in-differences and event-study models, to estimate the effects of the metropolitan police stations on crime and gender-based violence; (ii) carrying out robustness checks and sensitivity analyses to validate results; (iii) producing a detailed technical report that summarize the findings and implications - 4 -for citizen security and gender-based violence prevention and (iv) communicate and disseminate the report. Procurement activities will include hiring a research assistant or researcher to support the activities. The expected output is a set of rigorous, policy-relevant knowledge products that inform decision-making in Honduras and contribute to the regional evidence base on integrated policing models. 2.3Expected Results.

By the end of the TC, the project will deliver a validated dataset and a set of analytical outputs that provide robust evidence on the effectiveness of the metropolitan police station model in Honduras. The evaluation results are expected to assess whether integrated improvements in police infrastructure, staffing, and specialized services contribute to reductions in crime, enhanced safety for women, and increased public trust in law enforcement. These findings will help shape national policy decisions and inform the design of similar interventions in other countries in the region. 2.4Beneficiaries. The direct beneficiaries of the TC are the Government of Honduras-particularly the Ministry of Security, the National Police, and agencies responsible for gender-based violence prevention and victim services-who will receive actionable evidence to guide policy and operational decisions.

Indirectly, other countries in the region may benefit from the knowledge generated, as the evaluation's findings can inform similar citizen security interventions elsewhere. Ultimately, the final beneficiaries are the residents of Honduras and the broader LAC region, especially women and vulnerable populations, who are expected to benefit from improved safety, justice services, and protection from violence.
