chunk_text: The key sectors being considered are: mining, paper and pulp, civil construction, transport, petroleum and gas, timber, sugar and alcohol, chemicals, textile and electricity. Similarly, the project will dissemi nate best practices and "models of excellence", especially at the SME level, which would provide a tremendous boost to CSR efforts in the country. 2.10 This program is part of the MIF Cluster on CSR a nd it aims to complement the regional "Promoting Corporate Social Responsibility" project, which in cludes Brazil as participating country and Ethos as co-executor. This regional project is mainly focused on generating CSR awareness and training local service providers, both important efforts that will contribute to the implementation of the proposed program.

chunk_text: I. Basic Project Data

2.1 This technical cooperation aims to support the Ministry of Health and Social Protection in the design and implementation of the Digital Transformation Program for Effective Access to Health in Colombia. Specifically, the cooperation will focus on supporting: (i) support the Ministry of Health and Social Protection (MSPS) for the design and implementation of the digital transformation program for the Health System and (ii) provide technical assistance for the development and deployment of digital mechanism to optimize the workflow for medical-claims auditing processes carried out by the Administrator of the Resources of the Social Security Health System (ADRES). 2.2 First, the concentration of healthcare provision, infrastructure deficits, and geographic barriers affect effective access to health services.

For example, 26% of the total population and 28% of the rural population lack access to healthcare providers within a 30-minute drive, and 6.9% of the indigenous population did not seek medical attention due to the distances they must travel, compared to 1.2% of the rest of the population. 2.3 Second, governance and information management issues affect the efficiency and sustainability of the sector. There are different actors involved in the process of collecting, analyzing, and monitoring information. Weaknesses in coordination stem from the lack of specific regulations that allow interoperability and information flow. For example, healthcare providers bill payers (public and private) for services rendered, but health and financial information for the services provided is not integrated. This delays payments and increases debt with hospitals, limits investments in infrastructure, personnel, and technology to improve access and quality.

For this purpose, this technical cooperation will support the creation of a governance framework, an adoption plan by payers and healthcare service providers, and technical assistance to the MSPS for the development of the four modules in the Comprehensive Financial and Assistance Information System (SIIFA). Additionally, it will include the design of a model to facilitate the ADRES's registration and transmission of information, ensuring the traceability of transactions in SIIFA. 2.4 Third, ADRES manages the different sources of financing of the Colombian health system (USD $22 billion annually), which represents more than 412,000 annual transactions. The entity needs to strengthen the auditing of claims for health services to detect fraud and irregularities, promoting efficiency, transparency and sustainability of the resources managed.

Despite the investments in technological infrastructure and human talent made by ADRES, there are opportunities to strengthen its capabilities, especially in the workflow for medical-claims auditing processes. 2.5 The Government has prioritized expanding access to quality services by proposing investments in strengthening particularly in remote areas. To address access gaps, the strategy includes: (i) strengthening Primary Health Care (PHC), prioritizing rural and dispersed areas; (ii) forming comprehensive and integrated health networks; (iii) improving coverage and relevance of human resources; (iv) developing the unified information system; and (v) expanding digital health. 2.6 Improving access, outcomes, and coordination among system actors can be enhanced with investments in digital health.

Currently, the Bank is designing an investment loan program (CO-L1298) that will support the Government's health service expansion strategy through investments in digital tools that complement service provision and contribute to equity and quality in access. Investments will focus on: (i) strengthening institutional capacity at the central level for digital project management through enterprise architecture and data governance; (ii) promoting effective access by strengthening PHC and non-communicable disease management, through the development of digital services for primary care and tools such as telemedicine; and (iii) improving surveillance systems by enhancing the management of public health events.

3.1 Component I: Design and implementation of the digital transformation program for the Health System (US$280.000). This component will support: (i) definition of a governance framework and design of common data models between the information systems of the MSPS and ADRES to facilitate interoperability; (ii) diagnosis of essential digital health infrastructure needs in primary-level healthcare providers; (iii) creation of use case diagrams, sequences, and models for the development of SIIFA; and (iv) design of proposals for the development and integration of a Unified and Interoperable Health System. 3.2 Component II: Development and deployment of digital mechanism to optimize the workflow for medical-claims auditing processes carried out by ADRES ($370.000).

This component will support: (i) design a digital strategy intervention for the medical-claims auditing process of ADRES, informed by insights from HIRA (ii) implement specific digital tools to support the digital strategy interventions (iii) deploy a change management strategy to be used for the adoption the digital mechanisms by ADRES staff, including a training program delivered in collaboration with HIRA oriented toward the timely detection of fraud and irregularities in medical claims.

2.1 The general objective is to evaluate the HEARTS model of care for cardiovascular risk management in Suriname. 2.2 Countries in Latin America and the Caribbean have implemented or are considering (often with IDB engagement) the HEARTS model of care for cardiovascular risk management, to improve control of hypertension in primary health care. The HEARTS initiative, whi ch is a global initiative supported by PAHO, provides a package of standardized clinical tools that represent global best -practice including modules and guidance for diagnosis, treatment protocols, clinical decision support, a software application to as sess patient risk, counseling and patient education materials to promote a healthy lifestyle. HEARTS is an evidence -based approach to reducing cardiovascular risk, built on pillars from the establishment of clinical guidelines to patient engagement.

These activities are expected to improve the timely diagnosis and treatment of hypertension (including medication and behavior change, as well as prevention in high-risk individuals). 2.3 Noncommunicable diseases represent an important burden of disease in Suriname, accounting for 78.6% of all deaths. Overweight and obesity are major risk factors; the prevalence among people aged 15 and older in Suriname was 58.1% and 44.4% of the populatio n reported insufficient physical activity. Uncontrolled hypertension is a major risk factor for cardiovascular morbidity and mortality; in 2020, hypertension contributed - 2 - to 134 deaths in Suriname -3.31 % of all deaths and overall hypertension prevalence affects 26.2 % of adults.

2.4 As part of Component 2: Expansion of the Chronic Care Model (CCM) of the HSIP operation, the Ministry of Health in Suriname decided to adopt the HEARTS model in 2021 to address the growing rate of non -communicable diseases (NCDs) in the country, with a foc us on hypertension . Previously, health providers had used their own variation of clinical protocols, but HEARTS presented the critical opportunity to standardize and align all the country's health providers with global best practices to improve accessibility and quality of clinical pathways for non -communicable diseases. Since the inception of HEARTS in Suriname, a staged implementation of the initiative in health facilities has been underway with the final goal of adoption all public primary health care clinics.

To date, a pproximately 80% of primary health care clinics (about N=160) have implemented the HEARTS protocol; plans are underway to bring on 36 additional health care clinics over 2026. Overall, the initial experience with the HEARTS initiative in Suriname's health facilities has been positive and the Ministry of Health is eager to scale -up. The implementation is already underway with diabetes management and the Ministry expects to consider expanding to other diseases, including asthma, cancer, and mental health through interventions like PAHOs Better Care for NCDs Initiative. Although HEARTS is widely advocated by PAHO, there is little rigorous ev idence on the impacts of this approach on the stated outcomes at scale. Most of the existing evidence has come from before -and-after studies in pilots across some countries as well as some from qualitative evidence (Giraldo et al, 2021).

2.5 This project aims to evaluate the medium -run effects (up to 5 years) of the HEARTS model of care on the control of hypertension, using Suriname's early and staggered implementation and leveraging the countries unusually well -developed health information sy stem.

3.1 Component 1: Quantitative impact evaluation (US$50,000 ). We will implement a staggered difference -in-difference analysis. We will apply recently proposed and evaluated approaches. We expect to examine key intermediate and final outcomes such as registry coverage, blood pressure control rates, differences across urban/rural clinics and medication adherence and follow -up processes, in combination with approaches to control the false -discovery rate, as well as composite indices to mitigate the effects of multiple hypotheses testing. 3.2 Component 2: Qualitative impact evaluation (US$50,000 ). We will conduct a cross - sectional qualitative study in areas that already implemented HEARTS and those that have not yet adopted the program.

In each of these two groups, we will select 4 locations where we will conduct 1 focus groups with patients who have or ar e at-risk of hypertension and 2 semi -structure interviews health professionals. The total sample will be 8 focus groups and 16 individual interviews. 3.3 Component 3: Implementation study (US$30,000 ). This component will finance an analysis of program data, documentation of the HEARTS initiative rollout, and interviews with key stakeholders to assess how the program was introduced, what strategies were effective, and which challenges emerged. The findin gs will inform future scale -up efforts, and lessons learned. 3.4 Component 4: Other Costs (US$10,000 ). This component will finance generation of final report and evaluation, administrative support and coordination costs such as translations, graphic design, and interpretation. - 3 - IV.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: 2.1Investment in economic and social infrastructure in the region has been insufficient and inefficient to date. Alongside the development of an agenda that implies efficiency improvements to public investment processes, there is a need to develop mechanisms that encourage more active private sector participation. The infrastructure gap in Latin America and the Caribbean (LAC) is estimated to be 3.12% of the region's GDP in terms of investment effort relative to the size of the economy. This figure represents - 2 - over a 70% increase compared to the current level of investment.1 Additionally, there are investment needs in social infrastructure.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: For hospitals, the estimated investment required in the sector is around USD 153 billion, which is designated solely for new hospital construction and the modernization of existing facilities and equipment.2 2.2Infrastructure investment has a direct impact on economic growth as part of gross fixed capital formation, and an indirect impact to increase productivity.3 Investing in resilient infrastructure has an estimated net benefit of four dollars for every dollar spent. 4 Although developing infrastructure and delivering related services can be costly and carry certain risks, failing to invest has negative repercussions not only on GDP growth but also disproportionately affects the poorest individuals in the income distribution. 3 2.3Public investment in LAC has been insufficient to address the region's infrastructure gap.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: Historically, the public sector has contributed two-thirds of total infrastructure investment, with some economies experiencing a more significant involvement from the private sector. However, public investment in infrastructure has proven to be highly inefficient. According to studies by the Inter-American Development Bank (IDB), the efficiency of infrastructure spending in LAC is below the international average. The region effectively wastes one out of every two dollars allocated to public infrastructure investment due to issues such as cost overruns, time delays, and poor planning, among other factors (Suárez-Alemán, Serebrisky, and Perelman 2019; IDB 2020). This inefficiency is especially challenging given the current fiscal constraints.5 Closing infrastructure gaps and achieving growth goals cannot rely solely on increased public investment. Instead, a more effective approach focuses on improving the efficiency of public spending while promoting active and diversified participation from the private sector.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: Well-structured and properly implemented Public-Private Partnerships (PPPs) offer a valuable opportunity to address both of these issues. By enhancing innovation and efficiency in infrastructure development and service delivery, PPPs can ultimately drive economic growth and productivity. 2.4Recognizing the positive impact of upstream interventions on mobilizing private resources for public infrastructure development - and subsequently on economic growth, productivity, and competitiveness -6the PPP Unit has been actively supporting the enhancement of enabling environments for the implementation of PPPs in three key areas: 2.4.1The diagnosis of the enabling environment for identifying and implementing PPP, which involves two key components: (i) the regional Infrascope, a tool 1 https://publications.iadb.org/es/la-brecha-de-infraestructura-en-america-latina-y-el-caribe-estimacion-de-las- necesidades-de 2 IDB Health Sectorial Framework https://www.iadb.org/en/who-we-are/topics/health/sector-framework-health 3 Cavallo, E. and Powell, A., 2019. Building Opportunities for Growth in a Challenging World. Latin American and Caribbean Macroeconomic Report. Washington, DC, United States: Inter-American Development Bank.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: 4 Hallegatte, S., Rentschler, J. and Rozenberg, J., 2019. Lifelines: The resilient infrastructure opportunity. World Bank Publications. 5 IDB ( 2023, 2024) shows how total debt in Latin America and the Caribbean has increased significantly, rising from USD 3 trillion in 2008 to nearly USD 5.8 trillion after the pandemic-almost double that amount. This represents 117% of the region's GDP and up to 140% of the GDP of its five largest economies. Public debt soared to over 70% in 2020, but due to fiscal adjustment efforts in the region, it is now decreasing and approaching pre-pandemic levels of around 60% of GDP in 2023. However, these levels remain high, as prudent debt levels for the region are estimated to be between 46% and 55% of GDP. The elevated debt levels in many countries are also hindering growth.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: The IDB's flagship report, "Dealing with Debt" (2023), indicates that peaks in debt are associated with significant reductions in growth, with the impact being especially pronounced during more prolonged periods of high debt. This situation can lead to increased financing costs and a decrease in both public and private investment. 6 Evidence developed by World Bank confirms significant correlation between PPP regulatory reforms and PPP investments.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: World Bank Document - 3 - developed by the IDB and Economist Impact to assess the capability of Latin American and Caribbean countries in implementing efficient PPP, which encompasses 26 member countries of the IDB and has been updated and published biannually since 2009, and (ii) the subnational adaptation of the Infrascope, currently being piloted in Brazil for the first time, with results expected to be presented in 2025.7 This has been complemented not only with country specific diagnosis for each of the 26 IDB member countries, but also with sector based PPP diagnosis, such as ports, airports, hospitals, environmental assets, water or sanitation, among others currently in development (railways, roads, schools). 2.4.2The development of solutions primarily through the Network for Analysis and Best Practices in PPP (PPP Network).

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: This initiative has effectively systematized knowledge and experiences that were previously scattered across the Region. To date, it has produced a wide range of analytical outcomes and methodological tools that have contributed to generating evidence and best practices for the regulatory, institutional, and planning enhancement of infrastructure development through PPPs in the region. In 2023, the PPP Network shifted its focus to the evaluation of PPP policies, programs, and projects, following the recommendation from the Infrascope report. This report highlighted that LAC is missing an opportunity to learn from its experiences due to the lack of systematic ex-post evaluation. From 2024 to 2025, the newly formed PPP Evaluation Network has been collaborating with Peru, Brazil, and Colombia8, as well as regional universities and think tanks, to improve their capacities for conducting ex post evaluations.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: Concurrently, the Network is implementing performance evaluations of programs and projects in each country.9 7 Brazil has been selected as the first pilot for the implementation of the subnational Infrascope since majority of the PPPs and concession are being developed at the state level and most of the states have its one institutional and regulatory framework with differences in performance that make it worth to analyzes and learn from. The methodology of the regional Infrascope is being adapted to the subnational level and could be use in the future to analyze other countries with similar characteristics. 8 The selection of Peru, Brazil and Colombia on how advance the PPP programs are in those countries, the availability of data and the support of the government to the evaluation initiative 9 In 2020, the IDB.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: with the support of governments and research institutions across Latin America and the Caribbean, successfully established the Network for Analysis and Best Practices in Public-Private Partnerships (PPP Network). This initiative was recognized as a Regional Public Good, aimed at enhancing infrastructure development in the region by improving quality and efficiency. Prior to its creation, valuable knowledge and experiences related to public-private partnerships were scattered throughout Latin America and the Caribbean. Since then, the PPP Network has conducted three annual cycles. These cycles involve identifying key public policy issues in the area of PPPs that require practical, applied knowledge.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: This identification process is carried out through public consultations with regional governments and is organized into five thematic categories: 1) regulation and institutional framework; 2) preparation of sustainable projects; 3) project financing; 4) risk management, monitoring, and supervision; and 5) evaluation, impact, and performance. The Network has launched open calls for proposals, inviting knowledge institutions capable of addressing these challenges. It has also produced more than twenty analytical documents and methodological tools, contributing to the generation of evidence and best practices for strengthening regulatory, institutional, and planning frameworks related to infrastructure development through PPPs in the region. The Network has established a strong community of practice, comprising over 2,000 participants. Additionally, it has launched the First Knowledge Portal on PPP Analysis and Best Practices (www.reddeapps.org) for Latin America and the Caribbean.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: Initiated under Technical Cooperation RG-T3545, this initiative has been recognized as a success, both in terms of its impact and scope. It has not only motivated engagement from numerous stakeholders but has also laid the groundwork for a Technical Assistance agenda focused on Upstream PPP, which includes enhancing regulatory and institutional frameworks, and project planning. Notable examples of this agenda include TC RG-T4199, CH-T1285, and CH-T1326. Moreover, the efficient use of resources has been demonstrated, with analytical outcomes nearly tripling expectations. Recently, the PPP Network has concentrated on evaluation initiatives, leading to the creation of the PPP Evaluation Network, funded by RG-T4644. The work of the PPP Network is currently active with a focus on evaluation of PPP projects in Latin America and the Caribbean through the technical cooperation RG-T4344.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: - 4 - 2.4.3 The implementation of PPP Upstream technical assistances to LAC countries, with more than 20 technical assistance solutions across 15 economies in the region encompassing both mature environments, such as Brazil, Peru, Colombia, and Chile, and those with relatively less experience, like Guatemala, Trinidad and Tobago, Paraguay, and Belize. In mature economies for instance, following the diagnosis and recommendations from the Infrascope, the Chilean government with IDB support has been actively working to enhance its project preparation process aimed at mobilizing sustainable financing for concession projects. Meanwhile, in less experienced economies as an example, the IDB has supported the Belizean government in developing its PPP policy, which was approved in 2021 and is now being utilized to attract private investment in the transport sector. 2.5 Results so far and challenges.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: The latest edition of Infrascope 2023/202410 highlights significant progress. Investment in infrastructure PPPs across LAC has reached $160 billion in the period 2014-2023, marking a 14% increase from $141 billion during the 2011-2020 period analyzed in the previous edition. Additionally, the number of PPP projects has grown by over 25%11.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: Although most of these projects are concentrated in the transport (37%) and energy sectors (52%), there is a notable increase in interest and activity in areas such as water and sanitation (6%) and social infrastructure (4%).12 In the inaugural edition of the Infrascope in 2009, only one country had a developed regulatory and institutional framework for the preparation, implementation, and supervision of PPP.13 By 2024, the majority of the countries analyzed have established some regulatory framework to facilitate PPP implementation, and 13 of these countries have fully operational PPP units in place. 2.6On a country level, Brazil and Chile continue to excel, followed by more established countries like Colombia, Uruguay, and Peru. Other nations are also making progress; for instance, Panama is strengthening its regulatory framework and improving its PPP project preparation process.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: Jamaica has demonstrated outstanding leadership in developing resilient PPPs, while Ecuador has made recent advances in planning and prioritizing PPP projects. Paraguay has seen positive developments in its PPP program as well. Additionally, countries like Belize and Suriname are working on establishing a PPP regulatory framework, showcasing a growing commitment from smaller and emerging markets. 2.7However, and despite the overall positive trends in the region, challenges and disparities still exist. Infrascope's results indicates that there is still considerable room for improvement, which could significantly benefit their citizens, especially in developing economies.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: 2.7.1Regulations and Institutions - Strengthening institutional capacity: The ability of institutions involved in the PPP process to effectively support project identification, preparation, and implementation is a critical and ongoing challenge across the 10 To know about the Infrascope visit: https://impact.economist.com/new-globalisation/infrascope-2024/en/about/ 11 The data comes from the Infrascope 2023/2024 and correspond to the period 2014 - 2023. 12 For example, Chile has already three PPP programs of hospital including 14 different projects of individual and hospital networks. Also, Colombia is leveraging its experience in the transport sector to implement PPP in the social sector. 13https://impact.economist.com/new-globalisation/infrascope-2024/downloads/Latin- Americva_Infrascope_Report_2009_English.pdf - 5 - region. Currently, only half of the 26 countries in the region have fully operational PPP agencies, 27% have a PPP Unit but with limited activity and the rest of the countries don't have a formal unit.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: The situation with the availability of dedicated resources to facilitate project preparation or to assist with the associated costs is even more complicated with only 11 countries having such facilities. As an example, Guatemala needs to improve their capacity for contract management and monitoring and their coordination mechanisms between the different institutions involved in the PPP process (EI, IDB, 2024).14 2.7.2Planning and Preparation - Improving project structuring: The percentage of tendered PPP that have achieved successful financial closure is under 60%. The primary obstacles include increasing financing costs, deficiencies in risk management, and insufficient project preparation. As an example, Dominican Republic needs to enhance its planification process and technical capacities for project preparation aiming to improve the success rate of their PPP (EI, IDB, 2024).15.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: 2.7.3Monitoring and Evaluation - Developing Performance and impact measurement capabilities: Many countries in the region are not actively learning from past experiences, which limits their ability to create impactful projects. As an example, Ecuador has a mandate to perform evaluations of PPP process, but these are not being conducted, losing the opportunity to include the lessons learned into the projects under preparation (EI, IDB, 2024).16 2.8Recognizing these challenges and building on the success of previous technical cooperation projects ( RG-T3545, RG-T4199, RG-T4344), the aim of this initiative is to enhance the enabling environment for PPP in the 26 IDB countries. This will support regional economic growth, productivity, and competitiveness by fostering the development of efficient infrastructure.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: To achieve this, the initiative will be structured around a solid diagnostic approach at regional, country and sectorial levels to keep track of the advance of the challenges presented above and identify new ones. This will lead to the identification of specific areas for improvement in each country and regional needs that will guide our agenda for development of evidence and tools. As illustrated in the previous examples, the Infrascope provides detailed information through 106 specific indicators that assess how countries can effectively develop PPP by enhancing regulatory, institutional, planning, and evaluation frameworks. This information will establish roadmaps for potential improvement in each of the 26 IDB countries. This updated diagnosis will serve as the basis for implementing technical assistance through this Technical Cooperation.

chunk_text: 2.8.1Regional, Country-level, and Sector PPP Diagnosis: The Infrascope is the primary diagnostic tool for LAC countries to assess the enabling environment for PPP. section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: This framework is essential for mobilizing private capital for infrastructure projects and developing more efficient infrastructure that positively impacts economic growth. In terms of operational focus, the TC is connected to the sustainable, resilient, and inclusive development of infrastructure. By creating and strengthening the enabling environment for PPP implementation, we can help countries close their infrastructure gap in both quantity and quality. Furthermore, this initiative is aligned with the operational focus on productive development and innovation through the private sector. The proposed activities aim to foster the development of more efficient infrastructure that enhances productivity. 2.9.2 The recently approved IDB Group Synergies Framework (GN-3159-3) recognizes that PPP are crucial for enhancing IDB Group synergies. To support this initiative, the Bank has established a dedicated team to implement PPPs in the region.

chunk_text: This approach has proven effective in helping countries develop strong institutional, legal, and regulatory frameworks to attract private investment in infrastructure through transactional advisory services and transparent procurement processes. This TC will help maintain the successful trajectory of the PPP Unit by focusing on strengthening regulatory and institutional capacities in the countries involved and developing valuable knowledge products. This proposal also aligns with the IDB Infrastructure Strategy (GN-2710-5), which underscores the importance of enhancing countries' abilities to establish public-private partnerships. The Caribbean region presents both opportunities and challenges in developing effective PPP for economic and social infrastructure. chunk_text: PPP interventions play a special role in the One Caribbean implementation, and the development of a regional Project Preparation Facility, which states how "Strengthening technical capabilities and institutional capacity will contribute, among other issues, to building the local technical expertise necessary to implement impactful projects in the Caribbean". 2.9.4 It is also aligned with America en el Centro Program that mentions that building on the supported provided to several program's beneficiary countries, the Bank will increase its support for PPP project preparation in Central America, Panamá and Dominican Republic (CAPDR), with a focus on integration-infrastructure projects aligned with América en el Centro. To achieve this, technical assistance resources will be used to finance increased upstream and downstream PPP support, considering each country's challenges and PPP-market development stage.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: Alternative mechanisms for strengthening project preparation capacity will also be considered, such as supporting or creating PPP Project Preparation Facilities at a national level. 2.9.5 Finally, the TC aligns with the Window 2 of the Ordinary Capital Strategic Development Program (W2F) priority area, inclusive economic growth. This TC aims to create opportunities for public-private partnerships in economic and social infrastructure within Latin America and the Caribbean (LAC). Additionally, it focuses on improving the quality and performance of infrastructure services, sharing lessons learned in the sector, and promoting best practices in infrastructure. The development of more and better infrastructure and the improvement of the quality of the services due to the efficiency and innovation that the private sector can bring have a direct impact on economic growth and the reduction of inequality.

3.2 Component 2: Development of evidence and tools to strengthen regulatory, institutional, planning, and project preparation PPP frameworks - U$S 400,000 3.2.1 The PPP Evaluation Network - currently active in Brazil, Colombia, and Peru - is being expanded to include evaluations of the PPP programs in three additional LAC countries that have established PPP programs with projects that are either finalized or in advanced operational stages, which have sufficient and comparable historical data, necessary for effective evaluation exercises. These evaluations will include analyses such as ex-ante versus ex-post assessments of investment decisions, procurement methods, contract characteristics, performance, and impact. According to our Infrascope results, the eligible countries that meet these criteria include Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Uruguay, Peru, Jamaica, Panama, Mexico, Ecuador, Costa Rica, Guatemala, the Dominican Republic, Paraguay, and Argentina.

Notably, Ecuador has officially expressed interest in joining the PPP Evaluation Network and benefiting from a comprehensive evaluation of its PPP program, as well as an in-depth assessment of its port sector. This will help gather evidence for future projects in that sector. The selection of the other two beneficiary countries will be based on the presence of an active PPP program, the advancement of PPP projects, the availability of information, and the government's commitment to pursuing the evaluation agenda. 3.2.2 Resources will be utilized to collaborate with universities and think tanks in the region. This collaboration aims to support the collection of data regarding the country's performance during the preparation, procurement, and implementation of PPP. 1.1 The Rural Productivity and Connectivity Program with a Territorial Approach (PAPAIR; HA-J0002) has been approved by the Bank on December 2021 and is implemented by the Ministry of Agriculture, Natural Resources and Rural Development (MARNDR) of Haiti. It is financed through a US$60 million grant from the Bank and a US$18.3 million grant from the Global Agriculture and Food Security Program (GAFSP). The general objective of the program is to improve food security among rural households, including rural workers, farmers, fishers, and seafood merchants, primarily in Haiti's North and Northeast departments.

This objective will be pursued by: Increasing food - 2 - availability through improved productivity, adoption of agricultural technologies, and development of rural infrastructure (Specific Development Objective 1); and Improving food access for beneficiary farmers, fishers, seafood merchants, and rural workers by increasing their incomes (Specific Development Objective 2). Political, institutional, and security instability in Haiti has affected the implementation of ongoing IDB operations including PAPAIR which currently shows a disbursement rate of 17.42%. In this context, it is required to strengthen the capacity of the executing agency to improve implementation and monitoring and evaluation of the project.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: 2.1 Haiti benefits from a diversity of ecosystems due to variations in altitude, soil type and exposure to prevailing winds, representing an opportunity for national agricultural production. The agricultural sector accounted for 15,7% of Haiti's GDP (BRH, 2022) and employs between 50% and 60% of the active population (WB, 2024). Its growth rate has been respectively -5% in 2018 and 2% in 2019 (FAOSTAT, 2021). However, according to a study conducted by the IDB on agricultural productivity in Latin America and the Caribbean (1961-2021), Haiti experienced declines in agricultural productivity, while most other countries made significant progress. For instance, Dominican Republic achieved a productivity growth rate of approximately 2%, aligning with the rate observed in Andean Community (CAN) countries. Meanwhile, Haiti's productivity growth remains close to zero, like Jamaica, which shows a comparable trend.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: 2.2 The Haitian agricultural sector is highly vulnerable to climate change. Haiti is in a very high-risk position with respect to the occurrence of adverse climatic phenomena such as hurricanes, tropical storms, waves and tropical currents. Measured through the ND- GAIN index, its degree of exposure is 35.5 in 2021 (position 169 out of 185 countries). Over the period 1981 to 2020, the country was hit on average, by 2.1 tropical storms and 0.8 major hurricanes per year (Karnauskas, 2022), causing significant material damage and loss of human life (CIAT, 2012). Climate models for Haiti predict temperatures to increase up to 2.3°C by 2060, precipitation to decrease up to 20% in the mid-2030s, and frequency and intensity of extreme weather events to increase. This implies important adaptation challenges for the agricultural sector.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: 2.3 Moreover, Haiti is a country in a fragile situation, with low-income levels, socio- economic challenges, high insecurity context and political upheaval. Haiti is ranked 10th out of 178 countries on the Fragile States Index (2023). It is expected that the fragile and conflict-affected states (FCS) will disproportionately suffer from climate change, including because of their geographical location and dependence on agriculture and drought will increase hunger, from already high levels (IMF, 2023). This could contribute to both malnutrition and increased dependence on imports to meet food security needs. According to the IPC Acute Food Insecurity Analysis, covering the period from August 2024 to June 2025, nearly 5 million people- approximately half of the analyzed Haitian population-are facing high levels of acute food insecurity.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: Of these people, 6,000 experience catastrophic levels of hunger and livelihood collapse, classified as IPC phase 5 (catastrophe). The impacts of climate change, criminal violence, and political instability exacerbate this challenge by reducing agricultural productivity and undermining families' ability to secure their livelihoods. According to CNSA data from August 2024, the Haitian economy experienced a general inflation rate of 48.3% in 2022, with an increase of more than 47% in the prices of essential food items. - 3 - 2.4 In this context, the Government of Haiti aims at addressing part of the challenges that impact the agricultural productivity in the context of climate change through PAPAIR operation. In this sense, the project includes investments in infrastructure for fisheries and transportation, as well as direct support to farmers to promote agricultural technology transfer.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: Impact evaluations of the current PAPAIR project and former PITAG operation (HA-L1107) are currently under way to assess their effects on agricultural productivity, resilience to climate change, and food security. 2.5 The current Bank strategy for Haiti includes agricultural sector as a major pilar for economic and social stability, and the Government of Haiti and the Bank agreed to increase investment efforts in this sector through new financing opportunities based on lessons learned from past and ongoing operations. In that context, the Government of the Republic of Haiti requested the Bank's technical and financial support through a non-reimbursable technical cooperation to support the execution of the PAPAIR operation (HA-J0002) and explore new sustainable investment opportunities to improve agricultural productivity in Haiti.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: PAPAIR operation has been delayed for several reasons such as lack of competent staff for procurement processes, delayed importation of civil works equipment for rural roads, and some weaknesses in overall project planning and operational management. 2.6 The objective of this Technical Cooperation (TC) is to support the Ministry of Agriculture efforts to promote sustainable agriculture, food security and resilience to climate change in the northern region of Haiti. The specific objectives are to: (i) strengthen the Ministry's capacity to implement HA-J0002 (PAPAIR) operation; (ii) elaborate on lessons learned from past and current operation in execution, including financing mechanisms implemented through public and private sector initiatives and, (iii) support the design of new strategies and investments to boost agriculture productivity, sustainability and resilience to climate change.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: 2.7 The TC is consistent with the Updated IDB Group Institutional Strategy: Transforming for Scale and Impact (CA-631) and aligns with the objectives of: (i) reducing poverty and inequality; and (ii) addressing climate change, as it will strengthen the capacity of the Ministry of Agriculture (MARNDR) to implement the PAPAIR operation (HA-J0002) and to identify new sustainable initiatives aimed at improving agricultural productivity and resilience in Haiti's northern region. The TC is aligned with the following operational focus areas: (i) biodiversity, natural capital, and climate action; (ii) sustainable, resilient, and inclusive infrastructure; and (iii) productive development and innovation through the private sector.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: It is also aligned with the Country Engagement Note for Haiti 2024-2026 (GN-3199-2), specifically with the strategic axis: "Improving the business climate to enhance productivity", as it will contribute to strengthening the quality of agricultural support services, thereby promoting agricultural productivity, increasing household income, and combating food insecurity. In addition, the TC contributes to two cross-cutting themes of the Country Engagement Note that are essential for the sustainability of development outcomes: First, supporting the most vulnerable segments of society, especially women, youth, and internally displaced persons, who face multiple forms of discrimination, violence, and exclusion. Second, increasing Haiti's resilience to external shocks, such as earthquakes, climate-related hazards, pandemics, and economic crises, by investing in prevention, preparedness, and mitigation measures to avoid future losses.

section_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk_text: The TC is also aligned with the identified funding source: (i) OC SDP Window 1 - Operational Capacity and Policy - 4 - Dialogue for OC-concessional eligible countries (W1D) since it will contribute to strengthening the capacities of the Government of Haiti in managing public investments in agriculture and, (ii) OC SDP Window 2 (W2B), since it will support the agricultural sector and climate resilience. This TC is consistent with the Agriculture Sector Framework Document (GN-2709-16).

3.1Component 1: Support to PAPAIR's implementation (US$108.000). This component aims at providing technical assistance to the MARNDR project's team to strengthen the ministry's capacity to implement PAPAIR project and other initiatives in a more efficient way. The support will be provided through the contracting of consulting services that will focus on: (i) procurement and contract management, (ii) rural infrastructure management (civil engineering); (iii) monitoring & evaluation, (iv) gender and diversity, among other aspects. Consultants will be recruited to assist the Ministry project team in these fields to provide coaching, training and assistance to foster project management processes, based on an action plan validated by the Ministry and the Bank. The main expected result of this component is the improvement of the execution path of PAPAIR operation, measured through the Bank's PMR system. 3.2Component 2: Lessons learned (US$15.000).

This component will finance: (i) qualitative assessment of the effectiveness and efficiency impact of incentive mechanisms, subsidy programs, and technical assistance provided in the framework of several past and on-going operations (HA-L1059; HA-L1107; HA-L1096; HA- J0002). Consultants will be hired to analyze the support provided by these instruments to smallholder farmers and agro-industries, identify gaps and inefficiencies in the current subsidy system, and formulate recommendations to improve access to modern equipment and technologies; (ii) Previous and ongoing experiences from the agro- industrial private sector in creating market linkages with small and medium size farmers in the north will also be assessed; (iii) identification of alternative incentive models suited to beneficiaries and local context.

The main result of this component will be a shared vision of the Ministry of Agriculture about instruments and methodologies to support agriculture production in the northern region of Haiti. 3.3Component 3: identification of new strategies and investments (US$177.000). This component will finance consulting services for the following activities: (i) identification of key investments for the development of sustainable value chains, including technology transfers, resilient and innovative infrastructure, equipment, and agro-processing units. The assessment will also explore technical assistance mechanisms that can support sustainable agricultural growth, address institutional and regulatory challenges affecting investments, identify opportunities for public-private partnerships and innovative financing, and propose strategies to enhance resilience to climate change, economic fluctuations, and food insecurity.

Particular attention will be given to high-potential value chains identified as strategic by local stakeholders to guide investments toward sectors with strong growth and sustainability potential. The results of this analysis will help develop new investment strategies aligned with national priorities and best regional practices in Latin America and the Caribbean (LAC); (ii) feasibility study of future investments in the rehabilitation of irrigation infrastructure in the northern departments, to be potentially financed by a new grant IDB operation. This study will include the necessary environmental and social studies following the Bank Environmental and Social Policy Framework, including disaster risk assessment. The main result of this component will be the preparation of new public - 5 - investments in agriculture in the north available to feed the design of a potential now investment operation.

3.4 The key findings and outputs of this technical cooperation will be shared with government authorities, public institutions, private sector actors, and development partners to ensure ownership and impact. This approach will maximize the visibility and practical application of the findings, supporting evidence-based decision-making for future interventions. Indicative Budget 3.5 The indicative budget for this Technical Cooperation (TC) is US$300,000. This includes US$200,000 from OC SDP Window 1 - Operational Capacity and Policy Dialogue for Countries Eligible for PO Concessional Financing (W1D), and US$100,000 from OC SDP Window 2 - Support for the Preparation of Innovative Projects (W2B). 4.1 Upon request of the Government of Haiti, the Bank will execute the TC through the Agriculture and Rural Development Division of the Productivity, Trade and Innovation Department (PTI/ARD). The main beneficiary and counterpart will be the Ministry of Agriculture, Natural Resources and Rural Development (MARNDR), the public entity responsible for sectoral policy, which will participate throughout TC implementation. The MARNDR will provide, among other contributions: (i) the information required for the preparation of the expected outputs; (ii) support for potential field visits and interviews; and (iii) the convening of relevant stakeholders in the sector. 4.2 According to OP-619-4, the execution by the Bank can be justified by the fact that the beneficiary has limited operational capacity to duly and timely execute the activities provided in the respective project.

In particular, the MARNDR's current limited capacity stems from the country's prevailing social and political instability. Under these conditions, TC activities would be at risk of delays or inadequate implementation, jeopardizing the achievement of the objectives. Additionally, the current unstable political and institutional situation deter firms and consultants from participating in local public procurement processes or signing contracts with the Haitian public administration. Direct execution by the Bank will ensure that procurement processes, - 6 - including the contracting of consultants, proceed without delays or uncertainties associated with government execution mechanisms. Furthermore, financial execution will not depend on the availability of public budget funds. Part of the consultancy is essential to provide timely technical inputs and public policy recommendations, which will support the preparation of a new investment operation planned for 2026.

To mitigate these risks and ensure the timely and effective completion of the TC objectives, the MARNDR has formally requested that the Bank act as the Executing Agency. 4.3 PTI/ARD will be responsible for TC implementation, with support from the Haiti Country Office (CID/CHA), which will serve as the Disbursement Unit (UDR). 4.4 Final terms of reference of the consultancies and all technical outputs will be prepared in dialogue with the Haitian Ministry of Agriculture and Natural Resources. A technical focal point will be appointed in the Ministry to facilitate coordination with the Bank's team. The Bank's team and the Ministry of Agriculture focal point will meet at least monthly to monitor the execution of the TC and take the relevant decisions to ensure that the technical staff and consultants in charge will deliver in a timely manner.

4.5 The activities to be executed under this operation will be included in the Procurement Plan and will be executed in accordance with the Bank's established procurement methods, namely: (i) hiring of individual consultants, as established in the Complementary Workforce Document (AM-650); and (ii) contracting of services provided by consulting firms in accordance with the Institutional Procurement Policy (GN-2303-33) and its associated guidelines. 4.6 The knowledge products generated within this technical cooperation will be the property of the Bank and may be made available to the public under a creative commons license. 4.7 There are no conditions to be fulfilled prior to first disbursement nor for the execution of the TC.

5.1 Unstable political and civil context may hinder TC implementation in the field. In this framework the temporary relocation of IDB Haiti team to the North (Cap-Haitien) will facilitate the organization of field missions and provides a more reliable level of security to mobilize international experts closer to the stakeholders. If the sociopolitical situation remains conflictive, fieldwork would be very difficult; in that case, the consultancy will be implemented virtually.

2.1 The objective of this proposal is to evaluate the impact of the new electronic procurement procedures on public procurement efficiency, competition and savings through the development of electronic tools for the simplified procedure "Agile Procurement" and Circular Economy. 2.2 A pesar de que los sistemas de compra electronica (eGP) llevan mucho tiempo en uso, las herramientas de contratación agil y la economia circular son nuevas y aún no se ha evaluado su eficacia para lograr una compra optimizada, un ahorro de costes y una mayor sostenibilidad medioambiental, especialmente en un segmento de compras menores muy utilizado por las entidades públicas. La CT seria importante para llenar ese vacío analizando sus contribuciones y sus implicaciones más amplias para la modernización de la contratación pública en Chile.

3.1Component I: Investigación. Este componente financiará un estudio de evaluación sobre el impacto de las nuevas herramientas de contratación pública, concretamente el módulo de contratación ágil y la plataforma de economía circular, en la eficiencia, la competencia y el ahorro de la contratación pública. 3.2Component II: Diseminación. Este componente financiar las actividades de diseminación para compartir los resultados del estudio. - 2 - IV. Despite being one of the larger English-speaking Caribbean nations, Trinidad and Tobago attracted only 1.4% of the 26 million international tourists in the region in 2019. The sector was already facing a slowdown before the COVID-19 pandemic, with only 388,000 international arrivals in 2019, reflecting stagnation since 2010 and a growth rate of just 0.16% annually compared to 3.4% in the Caribbean. The pandemic exacerbated these issues, causing arrivals to plummet to 95,000 in 2020 and resulting in a -43.8% contraction in tourism GDP, dropping from 7.9% to 4.8% of the total economy. Recovery has been slow, with tourism's GDP contribution still 30% below pre-COVID levels in 2021 and international arrivals 42% below 2019 figures in 2022. Tobago, in particular, relies heavily on tourism for economic stability, with many residents and businesses depending on it.

However, the island faces challenges from national and sub-national crises, as well as the broader impact of global events on travel trends. Recent unforeseen events, such as the unprecedented oil spill off Tobago's Atlantic coast in February 2024 and a shark attack involving a British visitor, have prompted tourism and emergency management authorities to reassess and enhance their crisis management protocols for the island. This reassessment is crucial in the post-pandemic era, where global travelers are particularly sensitive to perceived risks and require a strong sense of safety and security. Currently, Tobago's tourism crisis management is coordinated between the Tobago Emergency Management Agency (TEMA) and the Division of Tourism, Culture, Antiquities, and Transport (DCAT). However, the roles and responsibilities between these agencies are not formally defined, and TEMA's crisis management functions are not specifically tailored to the tourism sector.

This oversight may result in gaps in essential protocols related to visitor relations and destination communications. Additionally, the absence of a comprehensive, tourism-specific crisis management policy or plan represents a critical vulnerability. To address these challenges effectively, it is imperative for Tobago to establish robust, well- defined policies and planning frameworks. Engaging with a mature tourism destination that already has established, effective protocols and procedures for tourism crisis management would provide valuable insights and best practices. Such collaboration could enhance 2Tobago's preparedness and response capabilities, thereby mitigating potential damage to its reputation in the global tourism market. The Bahamas is recognized as a leading example of effective tourism crisis management in the Caribbean due to its comprehensive and well-structured approach.

This effectiveness is demonstrated through the development of robust crisis management plans and protocols specifically tailored to the tourism sector, as well as the seamless coordination among government agencies, tourism stakeholders, and emergency services. For instance, the Bahamas Ministry of Tourism and Aviation collaborates closely with the National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA) to ensure a unified and efficient response to crises. Additionally, the Bahamas excels in crisis communication, with established systems for providing timely and transparent updates to both tourists and the global public. This commitment to clear communication helps maintain traveler confidence during emergencies. Further supporting these efforts is the Visitor Relations Unit, established in 1972, which addresses visitor complaints promptly and provides hospitable assistance to those facing challenges while visiting the destination. These well-coordinated practices collectively underscore the Bahamas' proactive and effective approach to managing tourism-related crises.

The objective of the technical cooperation is to contribute to the institutional strengthening of the THA through the exchange of experiences, knowledge, and learnings based on the experience of the crisis management unit of the Ministry of Tourism, Investments, and Aviation (MTIA) of The Bahamas. In particular, this study tour is expected to provide participants with firsthand insights into best practices for destination crisis management.

The goal is to review and analyze The Bahamas' tourism crisis management strategies, with a particular emphasis on the operations and effectiveness of their Visitor Relations Unit.The goal is to review and analyze The Bahamas' tourism crisis management strategies, with a particular emphasis on the operations and effectiveness of their Visitor Relations Unit.objective of the technical cooperation is to contribute to the institutional strengthening of the THA through the exchange of experiences, knowledge, and learnings based on the experience of the crisis management unit of the Ministry of Tourism, Investments, and Aviation (MTIA) of The Bahamas. In particular, this study tour is expected to provide participants with firsthand insights into best practices for destination crisis management.

The goal is to review and analyze The Bahamas' tourism crisis management strategies, with a particular emphasis on the operations and effectiveness of their Visitor Relations Unit. The insights gained will be used to enhance crisis management practices and improve visitor relations in Tobago. Ultimately, the exchange may 3lead to the request for additional assistance and support for building the Tobago tourism industry. This objective is consistent with the objectives and standards of the Ordinary Capital Strategic Development Program (OC SDP) in relation to Core Commitment 5 - Intraregional Technical Cooperation (CT/INTRA) (GN-2819-14, Section IV.E).

section_title: Concordance with the Country's Development Policies and Strategies
chunk_text: This technical cooperation is aligned to the 2021-2025 IDB Country Strategy with Trinidad and Tobago (GN-3071) as it aims to achieve improve the business environment to enable digital transformation and enhance the delivery of services on the island of Tobago, particularly during a crisis. This Technical Cooperation (TC) is consistent with IDB Group Institutional Strategy: Transformation for Scale and Impact (CA-631) and aligns with the objectives: (i) reduce poverty and inequality by addressing citizen security concerns, (ii) addressing climate change by strengthening countries' climate resilience and adaptation capabilities, including disaster risk management, and (iii) bolster sustainable regional growth by improving regional integration.

section_title: Concordance with the Country's Development Policies and Strategies
chunk_text: The TC also aligns with operational focus areas of: (i) biodiversity, natural capital and climate action, (ii) gender equality and inclusion of diverse population groups; (ii) institutional capacity, rule of law, and citizen security; (iii) social protection and human capital development; and (iv) regional integration. It is also aligned with the objectives of Priority Area 3: Effective, efficient and transparent institutions of the Ordinary Capital Strategic Development Program (OC SDP) (GN-2819-14). The project is aligned with the priorities defined in the Tourism Sector Framework Document (GN-2779-12) as it related to Line of action 2. Increase tourism's economic benefits and contribution to the local economy, Line of action 4. Strengthen environmental and climate management in tourism, Line of action 5. Improve the regional tourism governance framework, as well as contributing to the Framework's overall knowledge agenda.

3.1Budget. The Technical Cooperation totals US$200,000, fully financed through IDB grant resources from two complementary funding windows. 3.2W3B-OC Strategic Development Program Window 3 - Transitory Emerging Need for Sustainable Development in the Caribbean: US$100,000 to support Component I activities focusing on laboratory infrastructure essential for regional phytosanitary standards and trade competitiveness. 3.3W3A-OC SDP Window 3 - Sustainable Development in the Amazon: US$100,000 to support Component II activities addressing irrigation infrastructure critical for climate-resilient agriculture in coastal areas. 3.4 Resources will be allocated equally between components: US$100,000 for accelerating SU-L1020 laboratory infrastructure and US$100,000 for advancing SU-L1052 irrigation systems. The IDB will execute all resources directly, ensuring efficient procurement of specialized expertise consistent with Bank procedures. No local counterpart funding is required.

LVV and associated institutions will provide in-kind contributions through staff time for coordination, technical review, and knowledge transfer activities, ensuring sustainable capacity building and institutional ownership of developed solutions. 4.1 The Government of Suriname, through the Ministry of Finance and Planning, has formally requested that the Inter-American Development Bank execute this Technical Cooperation directly. This request reflects the Government's recognition that the specialized nature of required interventions and the urgency of addressing implementation bottlenecks necessitate direct Bank management of technical resources. 4.2 The rationale for Bank execution stems from three critical factors. First, the technical expertise required (i.e., international specialists in laboratory biosafety infrastructure and complex irrigation engineering) exceeds current market availability in Suriname and requires procurement through specialized international networks where the Bank maintains established relationships.

Second, the compressed timeline for delivering solutions before the June 2028 deadline for SU-L1020 and November 2026 for SU-L1052 demands streamlined procurement processes that Bank execution enables through more efficient contracting mechanisms, avoiding the 90-day average processing delays currently experienced through government systems. Third, the coordination complexity of managing consultants across two separate loan operations with different executing arrangements benefits from unified Bank oversight, ensuring consistent technical standards and integrated delivery of complementary solutions. 4.3 LVV acknowledges that while IICA serves effectively as the Program Execution Unit for fiduciary management, the institution lacks the specialized technical capacity and procurement agility required for rapid deployment of highly specialized consultants.

The Ministry's request for Bank execution represents a strategic decision to leverage IDB's technical expertise and procurement efficiency for targeted problem-solving, while maintaining LVV's substantive engagement through technical review, validation of deliverables, and participation in all consultant activities. This arrangement ensures optimal use of limited TC resources while building sustainable capacity within national institutions through structured knowledge transfer embedded in consultant terms of reference. 4.4 Thus it is established that this TC will be executed by the Inter-American Development Bank (IDB), based on a request by the beneficiaries, in accordance with the Bank's Technical Cooperation Policy (GN-2470-2) and the Procedures for the Processing of Technical Cooperation Operations and Related Matters (OP- 619-4), through the Division of Agriculture and Rural Development (ARD). 4.5Procurement.

All procurement to be executed under this Technical Cooperation have been included in the Procurement Plan (Annex IV) and will be hired in - 12 -compliance with the applicable Bank policies and regulations as follows: (a) Hiring of individual consultants, as established in the regulation on Complementary Workforce (AM-650) and (b) Contracting of services provided by consulting firms in accordance with the Corporate procurement Policy (GN-2303-33) and its Guidelines. 4.6Execution and Disbursement Period. The Technical Cooperation will be executed over 24 months from the date of approval, with full disbursement expected within this period. This timeline aligns with the critical implementation phases of both associated loans: supporting SU-L1020's laboratory construction activities through its June 2028 completion date and accelerating SU-L1052's infrastructure works before its November 2026 closure.

Consultant mobilization will occur within 30 days of TC approval to maximize impact during the 2025-2026 construction season, with Component I activities concentrated in months 1-12 to expedite laboratory procurement, and Component II interventions spanning months 1-18 to support the full irrigation infrastructure construction cycle. The 24- month execution period provides sufficient time for delivering all technical products while ensuring knowledge transfer and capacity building activities achieve sustainable institutional strengthening. 4.7Monitoring, Reporting, and Supervision. The Agriculture and Rural Development Division (CSD/RND) specialist assigned to the Country Office in Suriname (CSU) will serve as focal point and responsible for technical execution. Semi-annual progress reports will be submitted through the Technical Cooperation Monitoring and Reporting System (TCM) tracking outputs and financial execution against the Results Matrix and disbursement projections.

Monthly coordination meetings with LVV, IICA, and IDB will review progress and address challenges. A completion report documenting results and lessons learned will be submitted within 60 days of closure.

5.1 The primary risk facing this Technical Cooperation stems from the limited resource envelope relative to the magnitude of implementation challenges across both loan operations. With only US$200,000 available to address bottlenecks affecting US$24.6 million in undisbursed funds, the TC faces inherent constraints in scope and duration of interventions. This resource limitation may restrict consultant deployment to brief diagnostic missions rather than sustained implementation support, potentially resulting in technically sound recommendations that lack the hands-on accompaniment necessary for successful execution. The mitigation strategy requires rigorous prioritization of interventions based on impact potential and implementation readiness, focusing on bottlenecks where targeted technical inputs can unlock multiple downstream activities. Additionally, consultant terms of reference will emphasize practical tools and frameworks that extend impact beyond direct technical assistance periods, creating multiplier effects through replicable solutions.

5.2 The availability of specialized expertise presents significant execution risks given the narrow technical requirements for laboratory biosafety infrastructure and coastal irrigation engineering. The global shortage of consultants combining - 13 -technical depth with practical experience in Caribbean small island contexts may result in recruitment delays or compromised selections that affect deliverable quality. Furthermore, short-term consultant engagements risk producing generic solutions insufficiently adapted to Suriname's institutional and market constraints. Risk mitigation includes initiating recruitment processes immediately upon TC approval to maximize candidate pools, establishing framework agreements with specialized firms for rapid expert deployment, and requiring demonstrated experience in similar developing country contexts as primary selection criteria. Consultant contracts will mandate in-country presence during critical phases to ensure solutions reflect ground realities rather than theoretical approaches.

5.3 Technical complexity of the infrastructure involved poses risks to successful TC outcomes, particularly given the sophisticated nature of laboratory biosafety requirements and hydraulic engineering for coastal agricultural systems. Inadequate technical specifications could result in procurement failures, construction defects, or operational deficiencies that emerge only after TC completion. The risk compounds when considering that current LVV staff lack experience managing such specialized infrastructure, potentially misunderstanding or incorrectly implementing consultant recommendations. Mitigation requires selecting consultants with proven track records in similar facilities, mandating detailed technical documentation with step-by-step implementation guidance, and including validation mechanisms where draft specifications undergo peer review before finalization. Technical products will incorporate quality assurance protocols and commissioning procedures to identify and address deficiencies before infrastructure acceptance.

5.4 Finally, sustainability risks emerge from the temporary nature of TC interventions without established mechanisms for maintaining enhanced capacity beyond consultant departure. Solutions developed through external technical assistance may not become institutionalized within regular operations, resulting in gradual regression to previous implementation constraints. This risk intensifies given uncertain government budget allocations for maintaining coordination positions or technical functions created through TC support. The mitigation approach embeds knowledge transfer requirements throughout consultant engagements with verified capacity building milestones, development of institutional tools integrated into mandatory operational procedures, and seeking formal government commitment to sustain critical positions using loan savings from improved execution efficiency. Documentation of all technical products in user-friendly formats ensures institutional memory persists beyond personnel changes, while establishing communities of practice creates peer support networks that reinforce new competencies.
6.1 No need for exceptions to the Bank's policy has been identified.
